title: Palo Alto overlay
name: Palo Alto overlay
description:
A Map by Paloaltohistory

This map is a project of the Palo Alto Historical Association documenting the history of Palo Alto in map form.  The map&apos;s webmaster is Matt Bowling (mtb324@gmail.com)

properties.name: 1201 Webster (1917-1996)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "To many neighbors, the blue-gray shingled house at 1201 Webster exemplified the character of the older Palo Alto neighborhoods and had historic importance. And in the end, its fate symbolized the problem that is plaguing residential areas. Designed by renowned Bay Area architect Julia Morgan, the house was built during World War I for Camp Fremont in Menlo Park, according to the Julia Morgan Conservancy. Moved to Palo Alto after the war, the house had double arches over the front door and other classic Morgan features. But to Ovadia Mizrahi, a Palo Alto resident and builder who bought the property in June of 1996, the house was "a shack." Mizrahi tore it down Aug. 13, a deed that angered neighbors and preservationists and accelerated the groundswell of residents demanding better protection of the city\'s older homes. The city "wouldn\'t give us one day in saving a magnificent example of a Julia Morgan that hadn\'t been tampered with since the day it was built," said Gladys Woodhams, a longtime preservationist who lives a block away. While Woodhams said the house was in "splendid condition," owner Mizrahi said, "In my opinion the house is worth nothing. It was a shack. It was below code. The house was falling apart. The plumbing was bad. The electricity was dangerous." -Palo Alto Weekly 9/25/96

properties.name: 129 Emerson
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The Elm Apartments now occupy the site at 129 Emerson. Photo #2: 129 Emerson after the 1906 Earthquake as its second floor balcony collapsed.

properties.name: 1525 Waverley (1969)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Firefighters attend to a blaze at 1525 Waverley Street in 1969. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: 1531 College (1891-1997)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Built in 1891-92, the house is an ornately decorated Queen Anne-style cottage that was built as a "Come on" house--a model home to entice Stanford University professors to move to the young neighborhood. But for the last 10 years or so the house has been vacant and has fallen into serious disrepair. In January 1996, the city ordered the house to be stabilized or torn down. However, since the structure was classified as a Category I structure by way of its "exceptional architectural merit," the historic board urged that every effort be made to save it. The City Council then voted unanimously to extend the automatic 60-day moratorium to one year." -Palo Alto Weekly 7/4/97 The house was demolished in 1997.

properties.name: 1635 Bryant
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This is the site of the well built by the South Palo Alto Water Works, owned by Alfred Seale and Mabel S. Laumeister. When Alfred Seale began to subdivide his property early in the last century, he was first required to provide his own utilities because the area was still outside the city limits. This he did in part by digging an artesian well at this location. (Thanks to Peter Danner)

properties.name: 165 Channing

properties.name: 1979 College Terrace Rapist Scare
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In Palo Alto, the burdens placed on crime-fighting were at hand in the “College Terrace Rapist” case of the 1970s. During those years, the close-knit 24 block Palo Alto neighborhood was terrorized by a serial rapist who raped some 20-25 women in the area in less than a decade. For the whole story, click on the link.

It was commissioned by Leonard Aker, a mechanical and electrical engineer who lived in Palo Alto and nearby towns from 1927 to 1951." Photo taken in 1978.

properties.name: 271 Addison Avenue
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "This modest vernacular cottage survives from the city\'s earliest year as an incorporated community. It was built for Alexander C. Thompson and his wife, Anna. He was a Mayfield shoe merchant who moved to Palo Alto when the town was permanently established. Mrs. Thompson, a popular local landscape painter, remained in the home for a few years after her husband\'s death in 1913. In 1927, the cottage was divided into two apartments and occupied by a series of tenants. Mrs. May Vincent, widow of L.H. Vincent, and her family were the occupants from 1937 to 1958. For a number of years prior to its acquisition by the present [1985] owners in 1984, and restoration as a one-family dwelling, it was rental property of the Palo Alto Medical Foundation." -PA Historic Buildings Inventory The Photo was taken in 1978.

properties.name: 300 Hamilton Building

Eventually he appealed their decision to deny the color to the larger City Council and won 7-2. Source: PA Weekly 7/27/94 Photo #2: The Palo Alto Savings Bank at 300 Hamilton in 1968. Photo #3: The 300 Hamilton Building with the Laning Chateau just beyond. Photo #4: In this 1994 shot at the Centennial Celebration, the Great Western Bank occupies the building. Photo #5: Construction of the new 300 Hamilton Building. Photo #6: One opinion clearly expressed, 1984. Photo #7: The Palo Alto Savings Bank circa 1962. Photo #8: From another angle.

properties.name: 390 Lytton Avenue
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The office building at 390 Lytton Street has been cited as an example of poor PC trading. Palo Alto\'s "Planned Community" process (PC in government lingo) enables developments that offer outstanding civic benefits, but do not conform to standard zoning regulations. In the case of this 18,921 square-foot law firm headquarters, it was the size that did not conform --- it was some 80% bigger than Palo Alto zoning allowed. The PC process essentially allows the developer to play “Let’s make a deal” with the city. In some cases, this does result in beneficial construction that might not ordinarily be built, such as when a city is able to use their leverage to pull for affordable housing units in new apartment complexes. Other times, the process can feel a bit like “zoning for sale.” At 390 Lytton, developer Jim Baer offered a whole laundry list of “public benefits” in order to get around the usual regulations. The list included replacing four street trees, providing a 10-foot-wide public passageway to the west of the building, putting in a new bus stop bench, erecting a new sign, putting in a trash can, repairing a few tree wells, planting six street trees, and building a frieze above the building’s main entrance. In addition, the offer included 0,000 for a study of traffic in the area--- ironic to opponents who said the project would bring 50-75 new employee cars to Lytton Avenue everyday. Many residents were upset with the city’s PC trade. They said that a “3 story monolith would not outweigh the traffic and parking problems the 18,921-square-foot development would create.” More public criticism from Downtown resident Irv Brenner: “PC ‘benefits’ are frequently modest or meaningless. Some are hilariously silly -- check out the toy cars framing the doorway at 390 Lytton Ave., official "public benefits" of that souped-up PC office development. Whatever would our town do without them? It reminds me of the Manhattan Indians trading their island for a handful of beads." On that toy car frieze, however... While the “history of the automobile” does not seem to have a whole lot to do with the law firm inside (Townsend and Townsend and Crew), 25,000 did buy a rather interesting and fanciful piece of sculpture. It depicts the history of the “automobile” from the early days on foot to a futuristic kind of flying "car-pod," with various stages of the car along the way. It’s kind of nice to be able to walk down a street and find such a whimsical piece of public art on an otherwise completely nondescript building.

properties.name: 44 Encina (1949-2009)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "An house-turned-office building at 44 Encina Ave. in Palo Alto, former home to such notable start-ups as Healtheon, Atheros Communications and VMWare, will soon be torn down to make more parking space at Town and Country Village. Though a shopping-center manager said there was no specific date for the deconstruction, she indicated it would likely happen in 2009. The two-story, 5,300-square-foot yellow structure, built in 1949 and remodeled in the 1960s, was headquarters for health care technology start-up Healtheon (which later merged with Web MD) in the mid 1990s, virtualization-software company VMWare in 1998 and Atheros Communications (a leading WiFi chip company) from 1998 to 1999. From 1999-2007, the building was home to Jag Accounting, now located on Sherman Avenue. That business left the location after being informed of the demolition plans, Jag employee Barbara Chow said." -Palo Alto Weekly 1/16/09

properties.name: 800 High Street Parking Garage
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: In April 1997, Palo Alto built this enormous parking structure. It cost 2 million, bringing the cost-per-space to a stunning 5,476---and the city already owned the land. Palo Alto gained 905 new parking spaces, but also had to relocate the city’s teen center to do it. Photo #2: Former location of the Stanford Auto Company as seen here in the early 1940s. The signs indicate that they sold Buicks and used Standard Oil products. Photo #3: Looking south down Alma Street with the Don Hampton Dodge and Plymouth dealership to the left at this location. (1940s)

properties.name: 814 Melville
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "The home is the former residence of the late Major Don Nichols, founder of Harker School (now in Cupertino) and the Palo Alto Military Academy, both located there. Nichols sold the two blocks where the schools and his home were located to Joseph Eichler in 1973. Eichler left Nichols\' home but built new "Eichlers" on the rest of the property." Palo Alto Weekly There was a fire at the home in 2008.

properties.name: 841 Alma
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In this 1985 photo, Lawson Brothers Laundry and Dry Cleaner and D&B Automotive are visible. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: 850 Middlefield
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This image from the late \'50s or early \'60s is of the dental office complex that still resides at 850 Middlefield.

properties.name: A & W Drive-In Restaurant (1966)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The drive-ins were a prime social hangout for teenagers before the days of big indoor malls. Slicked back boys and their poodle skirted dates would pull up at speaker-accompanied parking stalls to order “Mama” or “Papa Burgers,” Chili Dogs and 11 cent French fries. Brightly attired “carhops” zipped out the food, allowing the kids to remain in their car to eat “on the drive.” In 1966, the A&W which stood at 4127 El Camino Real (the current site of the Tofu House) became the subject of city council inquiries when neighbors complained of drunken rowdiness, burning rubber and “uncontrolled pandemonium.” A police crackdown quieted down the kids but also brought some 31 citations in less than a month.

properties.name: AT&T Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This rather bulky Hamilton Avenue building is the annex to the telephone building on Bryant. In this photo of a car parade from the 1980s, the company was not At&T, but Pacific Telephone.

properties.name: Abel Avenue (ca. 1946-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Abel Avenue was named soon after World War II. Abel is the first letter of the military phonetic alphabet in use at the time. The next street, Baker, the second letter of the alphabet, was named for the property owners, Linda and Clark Baker. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Abundant Air Cafe (1999-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Abundant Air Cafe is located at the Palo Alto airport. "The cafe\'s logo is a fat Buddha wearing an aviator hat, goggles and a big pair of wings. And in fact there is something Zenlike and meditative about Abundant Air\'s location. The food, on the other hand, consists of wholesome, Earth-bound California-style sandwiches and salads. A wide brick deck is crowded with handsome teak furniture and pale-aqua sun umbrellas. Inside, only a few square tables run along two walls of windows. A long display case anchors the room, adjacent to a pretty, stainless-fronted espresso bar. The rest of the contemporary interior, with its riveted sheet metal and open beamed ceiling, echoes the body of an aircraft and an airplane hangar. Clearly the cafe has found an avid following beyond the would-be-aviator set. We arrived early on our recent visit and just avoided a long lunch line. Business people from nearby institutions waited patiently for a crack at one of Abundant Air\'s sandwiches or salads, displayed in the glass-fronted case." -Palo Alto Weekly 10/10/99

properties.name: Acacia Avenue
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Formerly known as Forest Avenue until Mayfield was annexed by Palo Alto in 1925. Named for an exotic type of tree. Source: Streets of Palo Alto (PAHA)

properties.name: Addison Antique (2005-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Addison Antique, is an antique store that houses everything from old airplane propellers to 18th-century armoires." -Palo Alto Weekly

properties.name: Addison Elementary School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Addison School in 2008. Photo #2:The class picture is from 1955 of a 6th grade class. Photo #3: The school in 1931. Photo #4: Addison Elementary with wet sidewalks. Photo #5: Undergoing renovation. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Aerial Photos of Community Center (1950s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Looking east from above at the future site of the main library and city hall. Below we see Rinconada Park, the swimming pools, tennis courts and municipal water and light plant. Photo #2: Looking west at the future site of the main library and city hall. There is a substantial lack of trees compared to today. (early 1950s) Photo #3: In this aerial photo looking north we see that the city hall is well under construction, but the library area is still a blank slate.

properties.name: Airport Flood (1958)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A flood at Palo Alto Airport as seen on the morning of April 3rd, 1958. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Albert Hopkins Incident (2003)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 2003, the Palo Alto Police Department had its Rodney King moment, as two officers were arrested for beating a black resident on Oxford Avenue. The incident touched off a firestorm of debate over the PAPD’s treatment of African-Americans in Palo Alto.

properties.name: Albert W. Miller Groceries (1940)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In the 1940s this was home of Albert W. Miller Groceries. Today it is the Patxi\'s Chicago Pizza Restaurant.

properties.name: Albuquerque
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "“Albuquerque” by GALE WAGNER is located at the Palo Alto Art Center at Embarcadero and Newell Road. "Albuquerque" was purchased in 1983 in response to a community vote as part of a sculpture invitational exhibition. The work was funded by the City of Palo Alto." -City of Palo Alto

properties.name: Alester Avenue
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The street was named by combining the first names of property owners, Al and Esther Spielberger.

properties.name: Alexandria Hotel
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Alexandria Hotel stood at the corner of Emerson and Lytton until it was torn down in 1937. This photo is from the previous year. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: All Saint's Episcopal Church (1895-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1:The current church was built in 1968, but All Saints has occupied this location since 1895. Photo #2: A postcard of the old All Saint\'s church. Photo #3: Father Peet, rector, All Saint\'s Episcopal Church, circa 1893. Photo #4: All Saint\'s in the 1970s. Photo #5: Portrait of Reverand James McLeod of Palo Alto\'s All Saint\'s Church in 1980. Photo #6: Circa 1966. Photo #7: The previous church. Photo #8: A model of the modernist church.

properties.name: All-American Market (1966-1998)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This is the former site of the All American Market. Dell Ralls cleans up after the 1989 earthquake. (PAHA Collection) In 2009 this is the location of a Blockbuster Video. It was also the home to the old Chat & Chew Restaurant between 1932-1966. That restaurant then moved across the street.

properties.name: Alma Plaza
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory in 1997, Lucky’s proposed rebuilding their antiquated 13,000-square-foot grocery store at Alma Plaza near Meadow Drive. They felt their store could not compete with larger markets in Menlo Park and Mountain View. Originally, Lucky’s proposed restructuring their store at 50,000 square feet, but neighbors had major objections. Lucky’s later asked for 44,777 square feet and then just 37,489. By 1999, Lucky’s was no more, but the new store, Albertsons took up the reverse bidding at 29,000 square feet, plus an umbrella-covered outdoor gathering area to get around the size ban. The plan was approved by the Planning and Transportation Commission, and support from the public (77% in a Palo Alto Weekly poll), but just as it was about to become reality it was held up by traffic concerns. Albertsons, by then in dire financial shape,bailed out, closed the store and sold the property. Today the plaza looks like a ghost town, but will soon be renovated --- after a long and at times, bitter fight to decide what should replace it.

properties.name: Alma Street
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Alma Street was named by landowner Timothy Hopkins for a friend of the family. The street predates Palo Alto, although it was originally just a path alongside the railroad.

properties.name: Alma Street  (1970s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking south on Alma Street in the 1970s as a biker takes a rather dangerous route. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Alma and Hamilton SE
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The building at the corner of Hamilton and Alma in the 1980s. A virtual view of the corner in 1996: http://www.virtualparks.org/scenes/ZKOgIRPxGi2GjnUHC2enKLA.html (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Alma at California (1940)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Alma at California in 1940 before the underpass was built. Photo #1: Looking south. Photo #2: Looking north. Photo #3: Looking east. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Alma at Everett (1963)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The current site of the Alma Street Fire Station in 1963. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Alma at Hamilton (1939)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking north toward The Circle from Hamilton on Alma Street on January 1st, 1939. The Southern Pacific Railroad tracks are at left and the automobile dealerships and garages are at right. The flagpole at The Circle towers right out of the shot. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Alma at Lytton (1939)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking south down Alma Street toward The Circle. A placard in the photo says that it is January 1st, 1939. The second University Avenue train station can be seen at far right. A Chrysler dealership is along the east side of Alma Street. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Alma at The Circle (1939)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking north from The Circle down Alma Street in 1939. El Palo Alto can be seen in the distance at center. The tracks of the Southern Pacific Railroad are at left and Campus Garage and other automobile establishments are at the right. The awnings of the Palo Alto Hotel are also visible at the corner of Lytton and Alma. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Alma at The Circle (1939)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking south on Alma Street from The Circle on January 1st, 1939. Packard and Buick dealerships can be seen at left while the tracks of the Southern Pacific run at right. Plenty of parking on New Year\'s Day. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Alta Mesa Memorial Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A photograph of a large statue of the Mother Mary in 1981 and the office building at Alta Mesa Memorial Park in the 1950s.

properties.name: Amarillo Avenue
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  In the 1950s, the Palo Alto Planning Commission began to urge builders to select more appropriate street trees. Because Amarillo means yellow in Spanish, mimosa trees were planted here due to their golden color. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Ananda Church
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory 2171 El Camino Real, Palo Alto, CA, United States2171 El Camino Real is home to the Ananda Church of Self-Realization, a religion (some say cult) that has a worldwide membership, including some 100-200 Palo Altans. But in 1996 the Ananda commune in Palo Alto became the heart of a curious sex scandal that led to the resignation of its leader, the Swami Kriyananda (aka J. Donald Walters). The Swami has written more than 60 books about Ananda, the religion he co-founded in 1968.

properties.name: Anderson Honda
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Anderson Honda wants to move to a location along East Bayshore Highway and put up a freeway sign. The plans are under environmental review. From Palo Alto Weekly 5/08: "Planning is quietly proceeding on the complicated east-of-Highway 101 project that would give Anderson Honda its long-desired freeway frontage and the City of Palo Alto a much needed new animal shelter. The city is close to hiring a consultant for the nine-month environmental review of the project, interim planning director Curtis Williams said Thursday. City leaders hope Anderson could move into a new, 23,000-square-foot showroom with 225 parking spaces at the current animal shelter site at 3281 E. Bayshore Road by 2010, Williams said. First, however, the city needs to annex and clean up the 13-acre Los Altos Sewage Treatment Plant at 1237 San Antonio Road, which is part of unincorporated Santa Clara County, according to Williams and Steve Emslie, acting deputy city manager."

properties.name: Andrus Taxi Service
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Andrus ran a three car taxi service in the early 1900s. Photo #1: A driver stands by his "black and white" taxi. Photo #2: The Andrus taxi stand at the north end of The Circle. A billiards hall is upstairs and a "quick service" cafe to the right. Photo #3: A driver stands by the magazine kiosk at The Circle where the taxis wait. Photo #4: At the Alma Street stand, "phone 15."

properties.name: Annual May Fete Parade
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Since 1922 Palo Alto has welcomed in Spring with a May Fete Parade down University Avenue. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Anti-War Rally (Late '60s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  An anti-war rally down University Avenue in the late 1960s. This is at the intersection of Bryant and University looking West. The Pacific National Bank and Condon & Chrome can be seen to the left. The sign that the protesters are holding says "End the War Now." Another sign says "Women\'s International League." (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Antonio's Nuthouse
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The current home of Antonio\'s Nuthouse was once the site of a Safeway in the 1940s.

properties.name: Arastradero Fire Station (1965)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The fire station at Arastradeo and Ciemo in 1965 and 2007. The old Mayfield fire bell also resides here. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Arastradero Road (1969)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Students walking to Gunn High School. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Arbor Real
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Arbor Real apartments replaced the Rickey\'s Hotel in 2008. One photo shows the apartments under construction in 2007.

properties.name: Arboretum Road
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This road commemorated Senator Leland Stanford\'s arboretum. In 1888, he wrote of his wish to establish an arboretum that would exhibit "all the trees and woody plants of the world that may be expected to grow to maturity in the locality." At the request of Stanford University, the street on the site of the original arboretum was named Arboretum. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Babson Realty
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Former site of Babson Real Estate. Southeast Travel Services now stands at that address. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Bailey's (1950)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This fire at Bailey\'s in 1950 resulted in over 50,000 dollars in damages. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Bank of America
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Bank of America Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: 1997 Photo #2: In the mid-1980s Photo #3: After the earthquake in 1906, the spirit of Palo Altans was not badly shaken. This sign announces the future bank building: "A modern building for the First National Bank will be erected on this corner. The earthquake has not impaired our capital or shaken our confidence in the growth of Palo Alto.” Photo #4: The First National Bank Building stood on this corner, as vowed after the 1906 earthquake. The telephone storefront is at far left. Photo #5: The newer building. Photo #6: Workers are doing construction work on Ramona Street next to the bank. In 2009 it is the home for Fidelity Investments

properties.name: Bank of Palo Alto
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The bank was founded in 1892 at the corner of University and The Circle on the south side. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Barbara Drive (1939-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  When the Leland Manor tract was opened in 1939, the developers held a contest to name the streets. Walter Vogel, a friend of the Seale family, won 0 for the suggestion that the street be named Barbara Drive to honor Barbara Seale. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Barclay Court
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Realtor Roy Stevens named the street Barclay in belief that an English name lent dignity. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Barron Park Elementary School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo is of the old Barron Park Elementary School.

properties.name: Barron/Wallis Mansion
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Originally constructed in 1857 at Mayfield Farm, the Barron/Wallis Mansion had served as a mansion for Sarah Wallis, one of the most prominent suffragettes in California. In 1878 it was sold to Edward Barron, the mining company executive. He added a locally famed octagonal fourth-floor cupola, as well as an enormous two storied west wing. The house also had two dining rooms, a billiards room, a two story back wing for servants and a wide central staircase that welcomed visitors into the interior of the Victorian mansion. By 1936, the 26 room building had begun a new life as the Interdale School for Boys. But in the late afternoon of November 29th, 1936, a fire began in one of the towers of the 80 year-old wooden house that would change Barron Park forever. While the cause of the blaze has long remained a mystery, electrical wiring was the likely culprit. Writer Joaquin Vienna first saw smoke pouring out of an upper-floor window while driving down El Camino Real, he turned into the estate, ran into the building and called the fire in to three local fire departments. Soon, fire crews from Redwood City, Menlo Park, San Mateo, County headquarters, and Moffett Naval Air Station were all racing toward the burning house. But it would be the reaction of the nearby Palo Alto Fire Department which would linger in the memories of Barron Park residents for decades. Upon strict orders from the City Council, Palo Alto firefighters were not allowed to cross into other cities to fight fires because they might not be covered by insurance. In the end, despite the valiant efforts of various other fire departments, the mansion was totally lost.

properties.name: Baskin Robbins
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: In the 1920s, this was home to the Italian-American Grocery Company and Ambrosia and Nectar Sandwich Shop --- quite a fanciful name for a restaurant that specified on their sign that their 10 cent hamburgers came "on bun." Photo #2: In this 1940s photo during a parade, this location was home to Barry\'s. Photo #3: In the 1980s, this address was home to Baskin-Robbins.

properties.name: Baskin-Robbins
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  2615 Middlefield Rd, Palo Alto, CAThis is a Baskin-Robbins in 2009. It is the former location of Toy World.

properties.name: Bayshore Highway (now 101 Freeway)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory As the car culture boomed in California in the ‘40s and ‘50s, city planners and lawmakers struggled to keep up with the pace of the ever growing traffic. The roads had not been built to handle the hordes of cars that now swarmed the roads, creating traffic and safety nightmares. On the Peninsula, no road had the dismal safety record as the highway that led to Palo Alto. It was known as “Bloody Bayshore.” Where the 101 Freeway now runs the length of the Peninsula, old Bayshore highway once connected San Francisco and San Jose. Completed in 1937, the four-lane highway -- divided by just a double yellow line -- contained so many dangerous intersections and potential driving dangers that Bayshore fatalities were constantly in the news. In the 1940s and ‘50s, the accident rate on Bayshore was twice that of the average California highway.

properties.name: Beckman Instruments (1981)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The building at 1117 California Avenue under construction in 1981. It was later occupied by Beckman Instruments. In 1982, the company merged into SmithKline to form SmithKline Beckman. Palo Alto Square is visible behind the construction. Today the space is used for a variety of offices. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Bell's Books
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Bell\'s Books on Emerson Street in Palo Alto is an old-style two floor bookstore with requisite nooks and crannies --- a place where you can find dusty out-of-print books and signed copies of aging hardcovers. Dating back more than 70 years, the store hangs on as an independent downtown bookseller even with the big Borders dominating all on University. In 1935, Herbert Bell came north from L.A. during the Depression ready to sell the textbooks he had accumulated in the back seat of his car. Setting up shop near Stanford, he began importing college texts from back East, later purchasing used books from local attics and eventually buying up old libraries. What resulted --- and still remains today --- is an uncomputerized, stack house of books you can find nowhere else. Photo #1: Bell\'s in 2007 Photo #2: Bell\'s back in 1985. Photo #3: Mr. Bell, the bookstore\'s founder. Photo #4: This is the former location of the Palo Alto Pleating Company. The building to the left, housing "F and F" is still there in 2009.

properties.name: Bella Luna
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Bella Luna at 233 University. This is the former location of Bennington\'s Cafeteria.

properties.name: Bellview Drive
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Was called Barry Court until 1957 when the Fire Department requested the name be changed because of the similarity to Gary Court. Source: PAHA\'s Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Bergmann's (1956-1992)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory When Bergmann\'s Department Store closed in July 1992, it signified a dangerous omen for the Midtown shopping district clustered around Middlefield Road. Sadly, by the time it closed, Bergmann\'s reeked of the past. An old style department store (with the Woolworth\'s style lunch counter and everything), Bergmann\'s couldn\'t compete with the big box giants (Walmart, Target, Kmart) that were increasingly sprouting up just outside Palo Alto\'s borders. The older photos are from 1956 (PAHA Collection).

properties.name: Bernthal Model T Ford Dealer
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Historic Buildings Inventory as revised in 1985: "The one-story brick buildings at 525 and 529 Alma have been resurfaced to present a more"modern" appearance in the late \'twenties, but in the \'seventies were rehabilitated, with some alterations to accommodate current uses. The earliest building on this site was a livery barn built by M.P. Madison in 1895 for J.W. Paulsen\'s University Stables. The Vandervoort family took over the stable in 1901. Dora Vandervoort, formed a partnership with W.S. Vandervoort and established a Ford agency at the location, the first of a long series of automobile establishments on the site." In 2009, Patagonia and Pampas are located here. Photo #1: In 1978 Photo #2: The Great American Frame Shop in 1985. Photo #3: Porcelain by Paula in 1985. Photo #4: This shot from the 1920s shows workers standing outside the Stanford Auto Company and a Good Year shop. The train tracks run along the front of the photo. Photo #5: Selling used Packards. Notice the 1940s-era motorcycle parked on the street. Photo #6: In 1940 as a Packard dealer. The window says "New 1940 Packards, New, Low Prices!" Photo #7: Next door in 1940 was the Charles Pogue Garage selling Chrysler, Plymouths as well as "auto repairing" and "retreading." (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Big Blue
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In the mid-90’s, when the Silicon Valley economy was roaring, small houses from a bygone era were being torn down at an alarming rate all over Palo Alto. In their place, speculators were building castle-like mansions (called Taco Bells by some) for the nouveau rich. These new neighborhood additions --- dream homes for developers and their new stock-trading owners --- were more like oversized monstrosities to many of their new neighbors. While the battle for preservation was most contentious in the historic neighborhoods of North Palo Alto, the big fight would actually begin over an abandoned house in the College Terrace neighborhood. For preservationists, it was the last straw and it came in 1996, when a 97 year-old College Terrace Victorian house, affectionately nicknamed Big Blue, was bulldozed by the new owner on the same morning that he signed the deed. The two-story, light blue house had been built in 1899 by Christopher Ducker, who operated Mayfield\'s only brewery on California Avenue. But the once majestic house now had weeds, car batteries, paint cans and a big bus in its yard. It had also become a hangout for homeless. But when it came down, outrage over the destruction of Big Blue was intense. Preservationists were especially incensed because a Palo Alto couple --- Katie and Tom Ritchey --- said they had a verbal agreement with the owner to buy and restore the house. The owner reneged on the deal, sold it for 100 grand more to speculator John Low, who then had the bulldozers in the front yard before the Ritcheys knew what was happening. They only learned of Big Blue’s destruction from the story appearing on the cover of the Palo Alto Weekly days after it came down. Low built two 4-bedroom houses on the property at a substantial financial gain (he did claim that he would have tried to move Big Blue if he had known that the Ritcheys were willing to pay for it). And as one Big Blue defender predicted, “The new houses will have little character, huge garages and no front porches just like all the others springing up in our neighborhoods: maximum square footage for minimum cost.” (See the picture to decide for yourself)

properties.name: Bill's Auto Glass (1985)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Former location of Ideo. Photo #1: Bill\'s Auto Glass in 1985.

properties.name: Birge Clark Houses
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Clark designed all the housse on Coleridge Avenue between Webster and Cowper.

properties.name: Bistro Elan Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Bistro Elan oat 448 California Avenue.

properties.name: Bistro Maxine
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Teeny-tiny Bistro Maxine which opened in the summer of 2006 has room for just 13 chairs and 5 tables and counts itself as the smallest place in Palo Alto to hold a liquor licence. Sharing a tiny corner of the Cardinal Hotel building and just a few paces away from Coupa Café, Bistro Maxine has done well in its first year in town. Their specialty is the crepe and they have received strong reviews for such French fare. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Black & White Cab (ca. 1942)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A driver helps a passenger into his Black & White cab in the 1940s. The University Avenue Train Station parking lot is behind them. A 4-digit phone number is on the car. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Bol Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Barron Park, the southwest section of Palo Alto, has always had a rustic, pastoral feel. It was not incorporated into the city of Palo Alto until 1975 (despite the kicking and screaming of some residents) and much of the area still lacks sidewalks and gutters. Located west of bustling El Camino Real, a trip to Barron Park can seem like a step back in time. The back roads of the neighborhood pass by tall redwoods, babbling creeks and overgrown bushes. Although Silicon Valley has boomed around it, Barron Park has been able to keep much of its old-time character.

properties.name: Bonanders Drive-In
properties.description: Posted by PaloaltohistoryThis is the home of the Olive Garden in 2009.

properties.name: Boronda Lake
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Swimming is not allowed at Boronda Lake, but with a fishing licence you can practice your skills with the rod. Here is a wonderful 360 degree panorama of what it is like to be on the dock at Boronda Lake: http://www.virtualparks.org/scenes/ZaGWby2wpOyFjSmknUxxhzw.html

properties.name: Boulware Park (1965-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Acquired in 1965, this one and a half acre park is bounded by Matadero Creek off Fernando Avenue. It is named after John Wesley Boulware, an early Mayfield pioneer who made it to California from Kentucky traveling by ox-team. Once here, he became an inventive farmer, patenting a ventilated fruit box for transporting berries and devising a number of techniques to usually become the first to get berries to markets in San Francisco. Later on the Board of Trustees he was one of the main leaders who helped determine the route of Embarcadero Road.

properties.name: Bryant Street (late 1940s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking down Bryant Street towards University Avenue, circa late 1940s. The Telephone Company Building can be seen with a flag flying at far left. A camera shop and valet service are also visible. This side of the street now has diagonal parking. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Bryant Street Trees (1910)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Bryant Street in 1910 when live oaks stood in the way of passing vehicles. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Bryant Street at Lincoln Street
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Many trees along Bryant Street remained in the middle of the road through the beginning of the automobile age. A 1914 vote to "Save the Oaks" kept many of these trees around for a while. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Bryant at Everett (1986)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The intersection of Bryant at Everett in 1986 during a flood. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Bryant at Kingsley (ca. 1941)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Looking at the western corner, circa 1941.

properties.name: Bryson Avenue
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This street\'s name honors Bryson "Biddy" Hills, a Palo Altan who was shot down in an Air Force mission in Europe during World War II. Source: PAHA\'s Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Buena Vista Mobile Home Park (1926-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "Buena Vista began as a tourist camp for travelers, part of a 5,392-acre property purchased by R.E. Ashley in 1926. A historical photograph of the Buena Vista Auto Camp shows a row of tiny wooden cabins built on raised platforms with narrow spaces built between them, ostensibly for parking, according to Doug Graham a Barron Park neighborhood historian. The site had a store, lunch room, gas station and hot and cold showers. In 1932, Fran Weiler purchased the property, including the café, gas station and trailer park. The café was renamed the "Chat & Chew" in the late 1930s." -Palo Alto Weekly 7/17/08

properties.name: Bullock's Department Store (1972-1984)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Bullock\'s Department Store was replaced in 1985 by Neiman-Marcus, which is still there, as of 2009.

properties.name: Bus Stop Waiting Area
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: A bus pulls up to pick up passengers. Notice the Peninsula Times-Tribune newspaper box. (1980s) Photo #2: Two women get on a bus headed for the Stanford Shopping Center in 1975. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Buses Lined Up Near Train Station (ca. 1960)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Buses are lined up in the rear parking lot of the Palo Alto Train Depot circa 1960. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Byxbee Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Byxbee Real Estate
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory John F. Byxbee stands in front of his real estate and insurance building at the corner of Alma Street and Lytton Avenue in this undated photograph. A girl sits in an early automobile parked on Lytton Avenue. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: C.W. La Peire and Son Groceries (1901)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory La Peire and Son Grocery with staff including William Ramos, G.W. La Peire, and James La Peire. Circa 1898. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: CVS (2009-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This CVS was a Longs until 2009 when the chain store was bought out. Formerly it was John\'s Market and Lee Bros. before that

properties.name: Cafe Verona (1984-2003)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo # 1: After 19 years in business, Café Verona closed its doors in August of 2003. Since then the old building on Hamilton Avenue has sat empty --- upsetting many in town who feel the landlord forced the Café to fold for no reason. Known for its espresso, open mike Thursdays, art exhibits and delicious panini, Café Verona won the Weekly\'s 2003 award for "Best Solo Dining Experience." Photo #2: Reposado Mexican Restaurant (2009) Photo #3: City Hall looms over these storefronts on Hamilton in 1985

properties.name: California Avenue Fountain
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The California Avenue Fountain at the end of the street in the 1970s. There was talk in 2008 that the fountain might be replaced due to faulty plumbing. Local pranksters often fill the fountain with laundry detergent and colored dye. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: California Avenue Looking West (1970s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A biker rides west on California Avenue. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: California Avenue Train Depot
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The small building that hosts the California Avenue Railroad Station where Mayfield got its start. Photo #2: 1984. Photo #3: 1940 at right. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: California Avenue from Palo Alto Central
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Looking at the Park and California intersection from newly opened Palo Alto Central circa 1985. The building with the rounded roof was once the Purity Market.

properties.name: California Park Apartments
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: California State Employment Service Building (1939)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The photograph is from February of 1939. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: California Youth Symphony (1952-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "Founded in 1952, the Palo Alto-based youth orchestra performs here at Spangenberg Theatre in Palo Alto, Foothill College, Flint Center and San Mateo Performing Arts Center. Many local participants are among 500 students enrolled in nine ensembles. Directed by composer-conductor Leo Eylar." -Palo Alto Weekly

properties.name: California at Alma
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Looking west toward the Southern Pacific train tracks and Alma Street down California Avenue. In those days, you could drive across this grade crossing. The Mayfield Water Tower is in the distance to the right. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: California at El Camino Real from above
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory #1: An aerial view of the El Camino Real and California Avenue intersection circa 1945. A gas station is on the northwest corner. #2: Looking down at South Palo Alto in the 1960s. The North County Courthouse is the boxy building in the middle of the photo near the top. El Camino Real runs along the bottom of the photograph. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Cambridge Avenue Parking Garage
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The parking garage in the 1960s on Cambridge Avenue that provides parking for the California Avenue shopping district. Note the sign offering a rather liberal 4 hours of free parking. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Cambridge Avenue Post Office
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: This is the Cambridge Avenue branch of the U.S. Post Office. Photo #2: Resident Josephine Breven buying two-cent and twenty-two cent stamps while other postal customers wait in line in 1985. Photo #3, 4: A 1960s-era "electrically powered" mail truck. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Cameo Club (1960s-1993)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The City Council banned card casinos in 1993, leading to the downfall of the Cameo Club.

properties.name: Cameron Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Donaldina Cameron was a legendary figure in San Francisco\'s Chinatown through her fearless rescuing of young Chinese girls, victims of the "yellow slave trade." Later she moved to Palo Alto and lived at 1020 California Avenue in College Terrace until her death in 1968 at the age of 98.

properties.name: Campus Barber Shop
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Campus Barber Shop on California Avenue shares a building with Izzy\'s Brooklyn Bagels.

properties.name: Canopy (1996-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Canopy is a Palo Alto-based non-profit advocate for the urban forest and works to educate, inspire, and engage the community as stewards of young and mature trees. Canopy was established in 1996 based on the recommendations of the Tree Task Force" -Canopy.org

properties.name: Carnegie Library (1904-1967)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Palo Alto\'s main library in the early part of the 20th Century. It now stands on the ground occupied by the Palo Alto Civic Center. Photo #1: Circa 1910s. Photo #2: In the 1960s with the Laning Chateau behind. Photo #3: On a rainy day. Photo #4: A sad ending. Photo #5: Inside the library Photo #6: Inside the library in the 1950s. Photo #7: In the 1930s. Photo #8: Just before its demise. Photo #9: Just after opening and before expansion. Photo #10: Palo Alto officials watching the end of Carnegie Public Library.

properties.name: Casa Olga (1973-2009)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory An intermediate nursing care facility that is closing after 35 years due to state budget cuts. During its tenure it has served over 9,000 seniors and persons with physical and mental disabilities. A mosaic of El Palo Alto is on its eastern side. Photo #1: Circa 1993 with a mural of El Palo Alto. Photo #2: 1985 Photo #3: Circa 1975 Photo #4: This is the former location of the old Associated Service Station, complete with "flying A." (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Casa Real Apartments
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1941, as the United States was inching toward an eventual war with Germany, U.S. authorities attempted to deport a member of The Fuhrer’s inner circle, the so-called “Nazi Princess,” Stephanie Hohenlohe. Her hiding place: An apartment building on Forest Avenue in Palo Alto. Read more: http://paloaltohistory.com/princessstephanie.html Photo #1: In 1985. Photo #2:In 2007. Photo #3: Circa 1935. Photo #4: This building stood at 360 Forest before Casa Real was constructed. It appears to have a tennis court in the rear. Photo #5: Casa Real is prominent in this aerial photo. Laning Chateau is across the street from Casa Real with the Christian Science Church at the bottom of the frame. The wide expanse of Channing House can be seen in the distance. The photo appears to be circa, 1980. (PAHA Collection) (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Cashel Brothers
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: In 1985 as the Smith Andersen Gallery Photo #2, #3"This utilitarian structure was built in 1905 by H. L. Upham for the Cashel brothers as their plumbing shop. It was constructed with narrow clapboard, and has remained largely unchanged to this day. A clearstory provides natural light. The 2-story stable at the rear was once a separate structure, but the two buildings were joined in the late teens or 20s. The gambrel stick still protrudes above the upper opening. It would have been used to haul up feed for the horse which pulled the early plumbing wagon." Source: Homer Avenue Walking Tour

properties.name: Castilleja School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Miss Mary Ishbel Lockey founded this girls school in 1907 after encouragement from Dr. David Starr Jordan, first President of Stanford University. The school moved to this location in 1910. The older photograph dates to 1930. Source: castilleja.org

properties.name: Centennial Walk (1994-present))
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Centennial Walk was erected for the 100th anniversary of Palo Alto in 1994. Photo #2: Dressing up. Photo #3: The unveiling of a tapestry depicting the Centennial logo at a meeting of the Centennial Committee at the Lucie Stern Community Center fireside room. Photo #4: Gatherers at the festivities of the Centennial Celebration in 1994. Photo #5: An overhead shot of the gathering for the Centennial Celebration on Hamilton Avenue between City Hall and Centennial Walk. Photo #6: Admirers looking at the wall near City Hall. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Cesano Liquors
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This is the former home of Cesano Liquors, run for years by James and Clotilda Cesano. The street is named for them.

properties.name: Challenger School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "In 1960, while teaching in a public school, Barbara Baker became alarmed that her 1st grade students had received no academics in kindergarten, depriving them of the best years for establishing a foundation for learning. In Barbara’s first class, there were only six paying students. Her intention to teach half a day did not last long. Two years later, as fascinated parents witnessed their children singing songs and bubbling with excitement about learning, the tiny preschool had grown to 100 half-day preschool students with 100 students waiting for admission. Challenger has expanded slowly in order to maintain high standards. Challenger now has 20 campuses in four Western states offering preschool through 8th grade." Dource: Challenge School Website

properties.name: Chandler's Shoes (1939)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: Chandler\'s Shoes as seen in 1939. A price sign in the window advertises a price of .98. Photo #2: Inside Chandler\'s Shoes with the hosiery department to the right. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Channing Avenue
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Channing Avenue was the name given by Wilbur Mills or his daughter, Mary Mills. They were both ardent Unitarians and named the street after Unitarian minister and author William Ellery Channing. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Channing Market (1900-1981)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Long-time local market that was run by Butros Nijmeh just before it closed. The third photo is from 1980.

properties.name: Channing School (1894-1920)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Channing Avenue, the center of education in Palo Alto in the 19th Century. The elementary school is on the left and the high school on theright. Photo #2: Across the street from the high school in this wide photo. Photo #3: Palo Alto\'s first grammar school graduating class, 1895. Photo #4: The sign on the school reads "Palo Alto Public School." Photo #5: From Channing Street. Photo #6: 1897 photo of Channing School students. Photo #7: Students out in front of this strangely cropped photo.

properties.name: Chapel in the Sky (1941, 1946)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This spectacular Christmas decoration was erected at the University Avenue underpass in 1941 and again in 1946. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Charleston & Middlefield (ca. 2000)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The corner of Charleston and Middlefield in the early 2000s.

properties.name: Charleston Cleaners
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The gas station at Charleston Plaza (now cleaners) handed out gifts when you bought gas there; things like steak knives and mugs. Source: PA Weekly Town Square

properties.name: Charleston at Middlefield (ca. 1975)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Older children acting as crossing guards at the corner of Middlefield and E. Charleston during the 1970s. These kids are probably from the nearby Ohlone School (which is called Hoover today). (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Chaucer Street Bridge
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The 1998 San Francisquito Flood nearly caused a citizen revolt in Palo Alto as well as a successful lawsuit by attorney John Hanna. The bridge that many blamed for the floods still stands on Chaucer Street. Photo 1: 2007 Photo 2: 1907 Photo #3: Lloyd Crawford checks out high waters at the Chaucer Street Bridge in 1982. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Christmas Floods of 1955
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The San Francisquito Creek had been flooding for centuries, but it wasn’t much of a concern to anyone. Three days before Christmas 1955, however, it became a major problem for everybody living in the new housing developments that surrounded Greer Park. The 1955 flood was not the largest San Francisquito flooding ever seen. Floods in 1911 and 1862 had been more extensive, but with few homes having yet been built, damage was minimal. After all, flooding was good for undeveloped apricot orchards. But by the mid1950s, an enormous housing boom had taken place to the west of Bayshore Highway. The new residents living in those recently constructed Eichler housing tracts found their Christmas plans drenched in flood waters. Photo #1: A car submerged. Photo #2: Christmas trees were not spared. Photo #3: A house deluged. Photo #4: Jordan Junior High School acting as shelter. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Christmas Tree Lane (1940-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Nothing Palo Alto has to offer can out-Rockwell Christmas Tree Lane --- also know as Fulton Street --- where, in 1940, neighbors spontaneously decided to decorate the 2 blocks from Embarcadero to Seale Avenue with Christmas trees and lights. More than 60 years later, on any night during the holiday season, you can see dozens of cars slowly rolling down Fulton Street with just their parking lights on, children’s noses pressed against the back window, taking in the small town Christmas cheer. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Circle at Castilleja School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: City Hall Construction (1968-1970)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Turning the spade full earth are an unidentified man and Jerry Keithley. Mayor Frances Dias looks on. The photo was shot in March of 1968. (PAHA Collection) Photo #2: Construction begins even as Carnegie Library remains open. Photo #3: Digging underway in November, 1967. Photo #4: By October of 1968 the frame was up. Photo #5: March of \'68 looking east. Photo #6: A lone man stands in the wide expanse. Photo #7: Looking west, the Cardinal Hotel at far right. Photo #8: At full height.

properties.name: City of Palo Alto Animal Services
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The city\'s animal services building is located here on East Bayshore Road.

properties.name: City of Paris
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This Mission-style building was designed by Roy Heald and occupied by the City of Paris until 1985. Notice the egg and dart detailing at the cornice, and the decorative tiles. Source: Walking Homer Avenue Photo #1: 1985 shortly after City of Paris closed Photo #2: 2006 In 2009, it is the home of Kennan Land Company.

properties.name: Clemo Avenue
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This street was named after William Clemo, Palo Alto\'s first full-time fire chief. He was known as a "fireman\'s fireman." Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Co-Ed Beauty Salon
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This photo from a May Fete Parade in the 1940s show that this location was once the Co-Ed Beauty Salon. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: College Terrace From Above (Circa 1930)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This shot shows the Palo Alto School of Aviation bordering College Terrace in the 1930s. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: College Terrace Library (1936-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Many residents treasure College Terrace Library, the smallest of the Palo Alto libraries. It is a quaint little neighborhood library that recalls an earlier age. Literally standing in the middle of Wellesley Avenue, the College Terrace Branch has been in this location since 1936. Originally, it was built to serve the residents of Mayfield --- the part of South Palo Alto that had been recently annexed. But it has not grown much since those early days. The older photograph is from 1956 (PAHA Collection). Photo #1: 2007 Photo #2: Same angle in the 1950s Photo #3: In the 1930s, shot from behind. Photo #4: Shot straight on from the middle of Wellesley Street.

properties.name: College Terrace Library Construction (1936)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Construction of the College Terrace Library (then known as the Mayfield Library) in 1936. St. Aloysius Church on Page Mill Road can be seen in the background. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: College at Wellesley (1980s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  At the corner of Wellesley and College in the College Terrace neighborhood of Palo Alto in the 1980s. A man walks down Wellesley Street towards the back of the College Terrace Library. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Colorado at Alma (1941)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Looking East down Colorado from Alma in the 1941 flooding.

properties.name: Colorado at Clara (ca. 1955)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The intersection of Clara and Colorado during severe flooding, probably during the Christmas Floods of 1955. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Concrete Chevrons
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "The concrete Chevrons point down the hill towards the Palo Alto Municipal Airport runways. They serve as a guide for pilots, as well as slowing hillside erosion." -Source: Baytrail

properties.name: Congdon & Chrome
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  An office supply store. They still have a downtown location in 2009 at 552 Waverley St. This is currently the site of Jos. A Bank Clothiers.

properties.name: Congregation Etz Chayim (1995-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: In 2009 this is the home of Congregation Etz Chayim. Photo #2: The former home of the YWCA. This photo is from 1989. Photo #3: Ladies of the YWCA doing their part. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Construction of Freeway Overpass
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Construction workers building the overpass at Embarcadero and the Bayshore Freeway. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Construction of University Avenue Overpass (1940)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A variety of photos of the overpass being constructed at University Avenue. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Continental Salt and Chemical Company
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1926, this area was home to the Continental Salt and Chemical Company.

properties.name: Cooley's Block
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  County Supervisor Charles Cooley would remain in that office for 28 years. But the farmer turned banker got his start in 1914 by organizing his neighbors to pave the 400 Block of Webster Street where the "mud in winter was six inches deep, 36 feet wide and 400 feet long." Source: Palo Alto: A Centennial History

properties.name: Cork Oak Way
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Dr. Emory Evans Smith, a Stanford professor of Horticulture hoped that cork oaks would become the new cash crop of Palo Alto. While that didn\'t exactly happen, a Cork Oak grows at 3400 Cork Oak Way. Source: PAHA\'s Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Cornish & Carey
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The longtime Palo Alto real estate firm, Cornish & Carey. Included is a 1982 photo of Scott Carey and Jim Cornish (right). Carey was a Palo Alto city council member for many years. This address also served as the home to the Palo Alto Times in its later years. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Coronet Motel
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory 2455 El Camino Real, Palo Alto, CAPhoto #1: A postcard of the Coronet Motel, AAA approved. Photo #2: A postcard of the Coronet Motel in perhaps the 1970s. Photo #3: The Coronet still stands just a block from the California Avenue shopping district.

properties.name: Country Sun Natural Foods
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Country Sun is a local natural foods store. A painting of the store logo is on the side of the store as well as a larger sunflower-themed mural. Here is some information on the large mural: "UNDER THE SUN In 2004, Mohamed Soumah, a talented artist from Guinea created an elaborate California-inspired mural that graces the side of our building to the delight of people of all ages. Funded by City of Palo Alto Art in Public Places, Country Sun Natural Foods and CAADA." -Country Sun Natural Foods Website (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Covenant Presbyterian Church (1966)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Covenant Presbyterian Church as seen in 1966. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Cowper at Colorado
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Cowper at Colorado in April of 1941.

properties.name: Cowper at Forest (1996)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A link to a 360 degree panorama of Cowper at Forest: http://www.virtualparks.org/scenes/Zw-eEKtQ5XSqX0egy6F1cog.html

properties.name: Cowper at North California (1941)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Cowper at North California in 1941 during floods.

properties.name: Craig Hotel (1964-2005)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: This 63 room low-rent hotel was demolished in 2005. It is at far left in those 1985 photo. Photo #2: The Craig Hotel at left in this 1960s view. Photo #3: These old ads were discovered when the hotel was torn down in 2005. PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Crandall's Bicycles & Morris Real Estate
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: This photograph shows Crandall\'s bicycle shop at left, J.J. Morris Real Estate in the center and the Bank of Palo Alto at right. Photo #2: In th early days of Palo Alto, this was the location of Crandall\'s Bicycle Shop and later the Crandall\'s Automobile Garage. It was badly damaged in the 1906 earthquake. Photo #3: W.D. Wasson Real Estate in the old J.J. Morris location. The bunting and "Welcome Home" sign suggests the photo may have been taken in 1918. Photo #4:Next to Crandall\'s small bicycle shop stood the Morris and Mershon Real Estate Building. A sign on the window indicates that their San Francisco office is at 830 Market. Note the small office for the Palo Alto Times to the right and the wooden sidewalks. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Crescent Drive Houses
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This is an aerial view of the first residences constructed on the arc of Crescent Drive. The street in foreground is University Avenue. The trees behind the houses mark the banks of San Francisquito Creek. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Cubberley Community Center Fields
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Players play cricket on the fields of the Cubberley Community Center in the 1980s. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Cubberley Grandstand
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The grandstand at the Cubberley Community Center athletic fields near the track in 1992. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Cubberley High School (1956-1979)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1979, the Palo Alto School Board faced such a political Catch-22. There were three high schools in town and one of them was going to have to close --- and it was pretty clear that the school that was shut down would have a lot of angry parents, students and staff members holding a serious grudge. In the end, that school would be Cubberley High School, which never saw the 1980s. Today it stands as the Cubberley Community Center. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Cubberley Pavilion
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Cubberley Pavilion in 1994 during the Centennial celebrations. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Cubberly Community Center
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Palo Alto Unified School District established Hoover Elementary School in 1974, during a time of progressive and alternative educational experimentation district-wide. Hoover was established as a balance to these new schools by highlighting more traditional forms of skill-based education.

properties.name: Currier Motel
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A postcard showing the Currier Motel at 3200 El Camino Real, "Palo Alto\'s newest and finest." In 2009, this is a Super 8 Motel.

properties.name: Dan Brown's Lounge & Sports
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Dana Ave at Center Dr.
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A photograph from the 1940s looking west at Dana Ave from Center Dr.

properties.name: Dana Morgan's Music Shop
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Grateful Dead\'s Jerry Garcia had a job as a guitar and banjo teacher at Dana Morgan’s Music Shop on Bryant street. On New Year’s Eve 1963, Garcia met future Grateful Dead guitarist, 15 year old Bob Weir, who later described the fortuitous encounter: “I was wandering the back streets of Palo Alto with a friend when we heard banjo music coming from the back of a music store….It was Garcia waiting for his pupils, unmindful it was New Year’s Eve. We sat down and started jamming and had a great old rave. I had my guitar with me and we played a little and decided to start a jug band.” Photo #1:In 1985. Photo #2: The Bryant Street Gallery is in this location in 2009. Photo #3: In 1916, this was the site of the F.J. Commerford Horse Shoer...slight departure from its current tenant.

properties.name: Datasafe
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A records management firm founded in 1946.

properties.name: De Anza Elementary School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This is the former site of De Anza Elementary School. The photo shows the staff during the 1978-79 school year.

properties.name: Delight Lighting (2006-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "A native of Israel, Shimon Avrahami has been in the lighting business for 20 years. Delight Lighting was a fixture on Birch Street off California Avenue for nearly eight years, but he moved the shop to its present location in August 2006 where he has a bigger space." -Palo Alto Weekly The store was located at 2323 Birch Street from 1998-2006.

properties.name: Delta Tau Delta Fraternity House (1897-1976)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: A crowd of onlookers watch as the old fraternity residence falls to the ground during the demolition process at the corner of Forest Avenue and Bryant Street. It was built in 1897 at a cost of 500 in the Queen Anne style. Photo #2: The Delta House, notice the outside stairwell. Photo #3:Color photo of the Delta House in the 1970s. Photo #4: Looking across a parking lot at the Delta House. Photo #5: Looking down Bryant Street past the Christian Science Church. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Deluxe Hall
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Deluxe Hall burned in this fire seen here. This is the 2009 site of the Aquarius Theater. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Dental Clinic (1945)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The dental clinic at Forest Avenue and Webster Street in 1945. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Diddams (1990-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This was the first of the local chain of party and toy stores.

properties.name: Digital DNA
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 2004, controversy revolved around two rather spectacularly odd pieces of artistic work approved by the Palo Alto Arts Commission---“Digital DNA,” a seven foot tall egg made of circuit boards destined for Lytton Plaza and “Rrrun,” a sculpture of a car with human legs, which ended up in Bowden Park. Both works have certainly turned a few heads, but they can also inspire op-ed diatribes, from those who favor the pen --- and even thuggish vandalism from those who do not.

properties.name: Dinah's Court (ca. 1995)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This street was renamed in the 1990s for Dinah\'s Shack, the restaurant that once stood on the corner. It used to be known as Tamarack Court. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Dinah's Garden Hotel (1957-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "Created by Raymond G. Handley in 1957, Dinah\'s Garden Hotel was originally known as "Dinah\'s Motor Hotel" and was located directly behind the famous Dinah\'s Shack restaurant, a favorite destination for generations of Palo Altans and many movers and shakers from Silicon Valley\'s early days." -Dinah\'s Garden Hotel Website

properties.name: Dinah's Shack (formerly)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory While the restaurant’s illustrious history ran for more than six decades, it’s hard today to look back on its mammy logo, black stable boy statues, and other slavery-era paraphernalia without feeling a little more than uncomfortable. While the history of Dinah’s Shack tells the story of an extraordinary restaurant, it\'s hard not to think that the more significant story here --- at least in a larger historical context --- is of its paternalistic and stereotypical symbols and the blindness of whites who could not see their significance. Today a Trader Vic\'s restaurant is located on the site. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Dinah's Shack Statuettes
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Dinah's Tower
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This tower is a bit of a mystery. According to a recent news story, nobody quite knows why it is here. It almost came down in 1974 after Palo Alto passed a citywide height limit. In the older photo, Dinah\'s owner John Rickey poses next to the tower.

properties.name: Dornberger's Grove
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  In the late 1800s, Dornberger\'s Grove was where many Mayfield clubs held outdoor meetings including the Woman\'s Social Club and the Cycling Club. The eucalyptus grove belonged to Lambert Dornberger and was the equivalent of the town\'s park. Source: Mayfield 1850-1925

properties.name: Downtown Library (1970-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The rather small Downtown branch of the Palo Alto Library was built in 1970-71. It has often been on the city\'s list of budget cuts, but has thus far survived all attempts at closure. Before that it was the location of the Stanford Laundry Company building in the 1950s and 60s. J.B. Blois was the owner and it was, according to their ads, the place where "Device and Care Prolong Wear." (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Downtown Palo Alto's First Legal Public Drink (1971)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory in 1970, Barry Amato, operator of a restaurant in the former Hotel President on University Avenue, successfully took the old Hopkins restrictions of hard liquor in Palo Alto to court. Superior Court Judge Peter Anello ruled the old restrictions “invalid and unenforceable” and on May 22nd, 1971, attorneys Crist and Jack Kava posed for photographers toasting Downtown’s first legal public drink.

properties.name: Draper's Music Center (1967-2005)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Formerly the location of Draper\'s Music Shop. Today it is the hair salon, Legar. John Leach and Jaime Garcia are the founders of Legar.

properties.name: Driftwood Deli & Market
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This Barron Park neighborhood market on El Camino Real has been in operation for over 50 years.

properties.name: Dudfield Lumber Company (Est. in 1900)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Site of the Dudfield Lumber company. According to the "Walking Homer Avenue" website, "lumber was felled in Memorial Park in San Mateo County and milled nearby. The milled lumber was then hauled to La Honda and down Old La Honda Road to Palo Alto, a trip that took 3 days." Photo #1: Ellison\'s Body Shop, on the same site in 1985. The business was founded in 1929 by Earl Ellison Sr. Photo #2: The Ellisons Photo #3: At the front of office at 100 Forest Avenue, Mr. Dudfield and a driver are sitting in a new lumber truck. Photo #4: A truck full of logs is parked by a sign saying "Everything in the building line. Branch yards at Mayfield and Mountain View." Photo #5: The sign says "established in 1900, incorporated 1902." Photo #6: The distinctive Dudfield company office on Alma Street. Photo #7: A Dudfield Lumber Company truck carries a small playhouse-sized bungalow and several people as it drives down an unidentified street. A sign on the truck promises that the bungalow will be sold at auction at the Community Center to benefit the Library Fund. Photo #8: The Dudfield Lumber headquarters circa 1915. Photo #9: The hardened faces of the Dudfield Lumber Company. Photo #10: Some men on the roof at Ellison\'s. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Duluth Circle (1950)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Contractors Edward Whitmyer and Leo Clemson enjoyed making up street names by combining the names of property owners --- as in this case. Duluth Circle was a combination of Dulleck and Luthy, two Rae Tract property owners.

properties.name: Duveneck Library
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Construction of the library at Green Gables Elementary, now known as Duveneck.

properties.name: East Meadow at Alma (1986)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Cars passing a hidden warning sign at the train tracks just past Alma on East Meadow in 1986. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Easterday Furniture
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: The Sports Gallery is one of the storefronts in 2009 at this location. Photo #2: After the 2007 Walgreen\'s fire at 300 University, the old Easterday Furniture inscription was revealed. Photo #3: Easterday Furniture circa 1910. Photo #4: Satura Cakes is one of the shopfronts at this location in 2009.

properties.name: Edgewood Plaza
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Edgewood Plaza has stood at the Embarcadero gateway to Palo Alto for more than 50 years now, but with a new ownership group taking over, its days appear to be numbered --- at least in its current form. Sand Hill Property Company has all but given notice to the small group of shops now huddled around an abandoned Albertson\'s on the plaza lot. But now as new blueprints are in the works, a number of potential controversies regarding the design and layout of the plaza linger over any future plans. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Edible Arrangements
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  2999 El Camino Real, Palo Alto, CAOne of 108 Edible Arrangement stores in California.

properties.name: Eichler Home Neighborhood
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory in Palo Alto, 1950s historic architecture means Eichler homes --- the oft-derided, oft praised, recently- funky, expression of a clean and sleek future. In 1948, developer Joseph Eichler began his Utopian quest to bring good architecture to the masses. His one-story house design is known for its clean lines, open floor plans, and glass walls that allow residents to look out onto garden areas. Eichler homes were considered forward thinking in their design. They came to symbolize the promise of a better tomorrow to a burgeoning middle class. But today some critics now believe the Eichlers have the appearance of the future misjudged. Like the Jetsons\' home, they represent a future that never came to be.
