They are most certainly dated --- the question is whether they are dated/historic or dated/badly mistaken. If the National Park Service is any judge, they are historic. In 2005, two Eichler-dominated Palo Alto neighborhoods, Greenmeadow and Green Gables were named to the National Register of Historic Places by the National Park Service. Indeed, Eichler homes are now beginning to be seen as pieces of history--- suburban tract history, yes. But history none the less.

properties.name: El Camino Looking North (1920s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking north up El Camino Real in the 1920s. The Currier Realty Company stands at the corner of Cambridge and El Camino at right.

properties.name: El Camino Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory When it was first developed in 1914, its location in between the two approaches to Palo Alto, El Camino Real and the train depot, placed it at the "front door" of the city. Over the years it has featured baseball, football, softball, and rugby fields. During the \'60s and early \'70s it was often used for be-ins, rock concerts and other large gatherings. Source: PAHA\'s Parks of Palo Alto

properties.name: El Camino Park Softball Field
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The former baseball field at El Camino Park has been a softball field since the mid-1970s. Photo #1: From the 1980s with Tower Well looming behind the train tracks. Photo #2: El Camino Park in 1935 when it was still used for baseball rather than softball. Notice El Palo Alto at left. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: El Camino Real (1979)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Traffic on El Camino Real in front of Town and Country Village lined up for gasoline during a shortage. Photo was taken May 8th, 1979. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: El Camino Real Looking North (1940)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This photo was taken February 27th, 1940 after a rainstorm. The view is northwest between College and Cambridge. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: El Camino Real at California (1980s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Police escorting a house being moved in the 1980s. Two men are standing on the house in this rather strange picture. The shot is looking south toward the California Avenue intersection. Wells Fargo Bank can be seen at right. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: El Camino Real at El Camino Park (1920s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Alongside the park circa 1920s looking at El Camino Real.

properties.name: El Camino Real at Matadero (1910s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Asphaltum-paved California State Highway at the concrete bridge over Matadero Creek. The Barron Estate lands are on the right and the Bartley Tract on the left. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: El Camino Real at Sheridan (1886)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Grimley\'s Hotel and Livery are on the right at Grant Street. The Mayfield Hotel is in the center in the distance.

properties.name: El Camino Real in Mayfield (1909)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory View at Mayfield\'s Main Street (now El Camino Real) near Lincoln Street, looking south. The interurban tracks and power line run down the middle of the street. Several early automobiles are parked at the curb. Businesses include Benson\'s Market and Mayfield Drug Store. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: El Camino Row of Stores (1948)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A row of stores in 1948 including the Fargo Barber Shop, the Stanford Court Hotel, the Purity Creamery, El Camino Electric Radio Service, a cafe and a shoeshine stand.

properties.name: El Camino Way
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Until the 1920s, El Camino Way was a portion of the original route of El Camino Real. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: El Camino and Page Mill Road (1973)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This 1973 photo shows the intersection of Page Mill and El Camino looking north. Notice the Mobil Station with 37 cent gasoline. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: El Camino at Embarcadero (1940s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking south down El Camino Real at Embarcadero Road. The tower of Palo Alto High School can be seen to the left. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: El Camino at Ventura
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  An aerial shot of El Camino Real at Ventura in November of 1960. El Camino runs across the top of the photo and Ventura Avenue runs perpendicular toward the right side of the photo. El Rancho Hotel is the large nearly rectangular shape at the center of the photograph. Today it is a Quality Inn. The entrance to what is now Buena Vista Mobile Homes can be seen at top left.

properties.name: El Camino near Cambridge (1920s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A photograph from the 1920s looking at the stores of Mayfield on El Camino Real. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: El Capitan Place
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The name of this street was inspired by Yosemite National Park\'s towering cliff. It was largely inhabited by African-American residents in the 1940s. Source: Palo Alto Times & PAHA\'s Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: El Carmelo Elementary School (1955-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory El Carmelo Elementary School just off Loma Verde Avenue in South Palo Alto. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: El Palo Alto Dedication (1926)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Native Sons of the Golden West dedicated a plaque to El Palo Alto Tree in 1926. Several men (some with NSGW garb) pose beside the plaque mounted on a large rock. Father James Gleason sits to the right of the plaque, which is dated November 7, 1926.

properties.name: El Palo Alto Tree
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory El Palo Alto, the tall redwood which still stands near Palo Alto’s northern border has truly been rooted to that spot for a millennium. It’s an amazing fact to consider. Today tree lovers can still walk into a small park and look up at this enormous redwood that was just a small sapling when Leif Ericson first set foot in the Americas. Indeed, El Palo Alto was past 500 years old when Christopher Columbus first arrived and it was nearing its 800th birthday in 1769 when most historians believe Don Gaspar de Portola and his band of explorers first “discovered” the tree while looking for Monterey Bay. The tree originally had two trunks as seen in the 1875 photo. Good 360 degree panorama of the tree and surroundings in 1996: http://www.virtualparks.org/scenes/ZvKcxpycRCcyxExRqYVl-uw.html

properties.name: Eleanor Pardee Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Eleanor Pardee Park is a 9.6 acre neighborhood park with a large grassy area and shade trees. The park has a toddler playground area with bucket swings and bright new climbing structures.. There is also a multi-purpose concrete bowl. The land was donated to the city by Emily Dixon in 1920 who wished to name it for her daughter who died at the age of 15. For many years, Dixon\'s house remained on the property in which four rooms were preserved with all their old-time furnishings and was open to the public. But the house was rarely visited and fell into disrepair. It was razed in 1972 and a passive park was landscaped including a community garden. Photo #1: 2008. Photo #2 is from 2001 Photo #3: A painting of Eleanor Pardee. Photo #4: 1980s. (PAHA collection)

properties.name: Elephant Express Bus
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory An "Elephant Express" bus stopped at the corner of Bryant and University. Notice the headlights at the front of the bus are surrounded by a painted trunk. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Elinor Cogswell Park (1924-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This small park is named after former Palo Alto Times writer and editor Elinor Cogswell. It was originally called City Hall Park when it opened in 1924, as City Hall was then next door. It was originally slated for removal in the 1970s under the Superblock plan, which was voted down by Palo Alto city voters in a referendum. Photo #1: Ms. Cogswell at work Photo #2: In 2008 Photo #3 :At a 1996 concert. Photo #4: Looking north through the park, circa 1986. Link to 360 degree view of Cogswell Park in 1996: http://www.virtualparks.org/scenes/ZawBY73p3CzaqlSzeQ0UmlA.html

properties.name: Embarcadero On-Ramp (1960s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Construction of the Embarcadero on-ramp to the newly built Bayshore Freeway. Lucky\'s supermarket at Edgewood Plaza is visible in the distance. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Embarcadero Road (1872-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Embarcadero is Spanish for landing place. Embarcadero Road was one of a number of early trails crossing the old Seale and Greer properties to a bay landing on San Francisquito Creek. It was declared a county road in 1872. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Embarcadero Road (1900)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory These two photos show Embarcadero Road in both directions circa 1900. The shot is taken between Bryant and Emerson. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Embarcadero Road (1930s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory At left an automobile heads eastward on Embarcadero Road past a sign warning that traffic laws are rigidly enforced in Palo Alto. At right is a more modern way to slow down speeders on Embarcadero. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Embarcadero Underpass
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Built in 1936, the grade crossing at Embarcadero Road allows pedestrians and students headed for Palo Alto High School to walk under the train overhead. Its construction was prompted by the 1927 deaths of Mary Collins Harris and Max Springer who were struck by a train as they crossed the tracks in a car. Photo #1: At the opening ceremonies. Photo #2: In 1971, somewhat confusing directional arrows indicated whether the middle lane was heading eastbound or westbound at a given time during the day. Photo #3: Circa 175 during a rainstorm. Photo #4: The underpass begins to take shape. Photo #5: This 1969 photo shows a tree that has blown onto the roadway. Photo #6: The Embarcadero Underpass in the 1960s. Photo #7: Cars head toward the underpass in the 1930s.

properties.name: Embarcadero at 101 Freeway (ca. 1960)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  An aerial photo (ca. 1960) of the intersection of Embarcadero and the 101. Notice the almost complete absence of trees surrounding the freeway. The city golf course, airport and Baylands lie beyond. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Embarcadero at Emerson (1936)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking west on Embarcadero at Emerson in 1936. The tower of Palo Alto Senior High School can be seen at far left. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Embarcadero at Middlefield (1992)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Kids and parents headed home from Walter Hays Elementary School in 1992 across the busy Middlefield and Embarcadero intersection.

properties.name: Emek Beracha
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Leading Jewish Orthodox church that backed the building of a Palo eruv. The most contentious debate in Palo Alto in the past ten years was the utterly fascinating and increasingly bitter “Eruv Debate” of 1999 and 2000. It seemed impossible that one issue could polarize two sides to such a vehement and vitriolic degree and yet seem so painfully irrelevant to so many others. But never doubt the ability of religious proclamations to stir up the passions of the soul, or in this case, the local op-ed page. Photo #2: Formerly a Blockbuster Video. This photo is circa 1993.

properties.name: Emerson & Lytton Parking Lot
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photos #1 & #2: The parking lot on the southeast corner of Emerson and Lytton, circa 1950. Today a Greg Brown mural is on the opposite wall of the Barker Hotel. A Buick dealership can be seen where the Aquarius Theatre now stands across Emerson Street. The building next to it is being torn down, a former "community motors." Notice the old "football upright" style parking meters. Photo #3: This was formerly the location of the house in which Ruth Squire Beaver was born. Here we see the house in March of 1897. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Emerson School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Emerson School, a private, non-sectarian program for grades 1-8, operates on a year-round full-day schedule providing superior academic preparation, international courses (Chinese, Spanish), and individualized Montessori curriculum." -Emerson School website

properties.name: Empire Tap Room
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Empire Tap Room, 2008 Photo #2: Le Meursault "Palo Alto\'s Wine Restaurant (1985)

properties.name: Encina Grande Drive (1946-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The name is Spanish for a large Live Oak. Early aerial photos show an unusually large oak tree near the corner of Encina Grande and Arbol, which was likely the inspiration for both names. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: End of California Avenue (1960s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking west from the base of California Avenue. The fountain is just beyond the flags. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Engle House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A very early photo of the corner of Cowper and Tennyson where the Engle house was located. It is the house to the right in the photo. The picture was taken from on top of a water tower. The four houses in the photo are all still standing, while almost all the other homes in the area have been replaced. The Engle house is 520 Tennyson, the one marked "Manning" is 604 Tennyson, Thorild is 1730 Webster, and Hagerty is 1734 Webster. Source: Peter Danner

properties.name: Ensign Way
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This street was named in 1976 by the members of the local Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, located on this street. Ensign is the name of the Church\'s monthly newsletter and the name of a mountain peak near Salt Lake City. Source: PAHA\'s Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Escondido Elementary School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Escondido School opened in 1960 and has served students from College Terrace and around the Stanford University campus. The photo of staff is from the 1968-1969 schoolyear. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Eton Corporation (1986-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Etón (then known as Lextronix) incorporated in 1986 as the exclusive licensee of Grundig in North America. They offered televisions, radios, VCRs and more from this European brand. Today, they make such products as the ClipLink and the Blackout Buddy.along with the Satellit 750, a radio that functions as a radio communication tower, with amplified antennas. Also its portable radio reaches the moon with the special edition Buzz Aldrin G6. -Eton Website

properties.name: Everett at Bryant (ca. 1941)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Looking southwest on Everett.

properties.name: F.L Worrill Feed and Fuel (1924)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This photo shows the view in 1924 from across Alma Street looking at the Worrill building and wood lot.

properties.name: F.W. Woolworth's (1917-1949)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1917, Palo Alto got its own Woolworth’s. The original location was at 222 University Avenue and its opening was a big event for a small town. A musical orchestra greeted customers at a special dedication in which hundreds of customers turned out just to “look over” the merchandise before the store officially opened for business the following day. In those early days, Woolworth’s sold many items recognizable today --- though at much cheaper prices. A look back at old newspaper ads reveals that you could get three pencils for a nickel, a baseball for a dime and a mirror for just fifteen cents. Today’s shoppers would be less familiar with other items for sale such as dust caps, jelly tumblers and tatting shuttles. Photo #3: In 1908, this was McKibben Furniture. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: F.W. Woolworth's (1949-1989)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1949, Woolworth’s moved from 222 University down the street to 352 University Avenue, the 185 foot-long building occupied in 2009 by CVS. The new opening was a big deal, bringing out the mayor, fire chief, chief of police and president of the chamber of commerce. They helped usher in the brand new building that featured such novelties as air conditioning, fluorescent lighting and a new lunch fountain. And with the longest frontage along University Avenue, this new Woolworth’s store would anchor the University Avenue shopping district for the next four decades. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: F.W. Woolworths (1956-1990)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory where the Banana Republic store now sits, once stood that five & dime icon of a bygone era: F.W. Woolworth\'s. These days it would be hard to imagine strolling past the L\'Occitane and La Belle Day Spa to pick up a Tupperware container at Woolworth\'s, but there it stood until 1990, as the clientele and ambiance of the "center” changed around it.

properties.name: Fairmeadow Elementary School (1955-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Fairmeadow Elementary School resides next to Mitchell Park in South Palo Alto. The staff photo is from the 1977-78 school year, the classroom photos are from 1986 and 1957. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Family Service Mid-Peninsula (1950-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "For the past half-century, Family Service Mid-Peninsula -- located at 375 Cambridge Ave. in Palo Alto -- has provided mental health care to the local community, with a special emphasis on the needs of families. Launched in 1950 by a group of Palo Alto PTA members, the organization first offered affordable therapy to out-of-hand teenagers and their parents. Today, changing economic and social forces in this area have created more diverse and complicated issues than the organization\'s founders probably could ever have imagined." -Palo Alto Weekly 3/22/2000

properties.name: Fandango Pizza
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Fandango Pizza was previously located at Alma Plaza until that shopping center closed. Controversy came to this site in 1953 when state authorities granted a license to a hard liquor store here despite the protests of the city government of Palo alto.

properties.name: Fanny and Alexander's
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  412 Emerson Street, Palo Alto, CAThe former home of European bar Fanny & Alexander\'s. It changed its name in 2008.

properties.name: Fasani Carpets
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1:In 1985 this was Fasani Carpets. Photo #2: Inside Art 21 during a poetry reading. Art 21 closed in the late 2000s. It won the 2003 Palo Alto Weekly staff pick for best art gallery in town. Photo #3: In 1940 this was the location of Don L. Morris Parts. The sign indicates that it was a machine shop that sold electrical parts and batteries. In 2009 it is Natalie Salon. Link to 360 degree panorama of the Hamilton and Alma corner in 1996: http://www.virtualparks.org/scenes/ZKOgIRPxGi2GjnUHC2enKLA.html

properties.name: FedEx Office
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This is the former location of Kinko\'s and Littleman\'s Market.

properties.name: Festival Cinema (1974-1985)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory When talking with the 40-something generation about days past in Palo Alto, there is one place that never fails to be mentioned --- the old movie theatre on Hamilton Avenue known as The Festival. It seems everyone has a story of this grizzled movie house that stood in a converted office building from 1974 to 1985. But the loyalty that people have to the Festival’s memory certainly wasn’t based on its appearance. Reading descriptions of the old place, it clearly wasn’t much --- a glorified screening room really --- with an aging 16mm projector, a seating capacity of just 114 and a screen about the size of some modern-day home plasmas. Plus without an angled floor, Festival-goers were always wise to look for a seat behind someone a little shorter in stature. Despite such deficiencies, however, there was always something authentic, down-to-earth and certainly a bit funky about the Festival --- and it has allowed the theatre to remain large in the memories of a generation of Palo Altans. Photo #1: A calendar of upcoming films. Photo #2: Stanley Dudek, co-owner of the Festival beginning in 1982. Photo #3: The Festival Cinema building is no longer on Hamilton. Photo #4: Some Bogie at the Festival. Photo #5: Brian Duckworth, a lawyer and cinema owner.

properties.name: Fields Before Stanford Industrial Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This aerial shot shows just how undisturbed this area was before the Stanford Industrial Park moved in.

properties.name: Fife Street
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Fife Street was a largely African-American neighborhood in the 1950s before red-lining forced many black families to move elsewhere.

properties.name: Fire Site at 1717 Middlefield Road (1984)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Palo Alto Fire Marshal, Bob Cleveland inspects the fire site at 1717 Middlefield Road on January 28th, 1984. Sadly, one person died in the fire. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Fire Station #2
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Fire Station #2 is at 2675 Hanover Street. Photo #1: Christmas time in the 1950s. Photo #2: The station is just off Page Mill Road.

properties.name: Fire at University & Bryant (1905)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This is an aerial photograph of a fire near University and Bryant in 1905. Onlookers and firemen look at Palo Alto Paint Company building, scene of a fire. Ladders reach the second-story windows of the corner building with turret. Several bicycles are left around while their owners have moved closer to the action. More than fifty people are looking at the building from all sides. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Fire near California Avenue Station (1978)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A Southern Pacific boxcar is on fire near the California Avenue station. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Firemen Races
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: In the 1890s a popular form of entertainment was human-powered fire truck races. This race is apparently taking place on July 4th. Fraternal Hall is at the center of the photo. Photo #2: The Mayfield Fire Department Team Photo #3: Reenacting younger days. Photo #4: Palo Alto Fire Department men compete on University Avenue. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: First Baptist Church
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The First Baptist Church on North California Avenue as seen in 1948. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: First Church of Christian Science (1916-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: 1985 Photo #2: Looking south past the Christian Science Church toward the Delta Tau Fraternity House circa 1950. Photo #3: An early photo of the church. Link to a 360 degree panorama of the corner of Forest and Bryant in 1996: http://www.virtualparks.org/scenes/ZcggC77o1E3SOGUoNgc1_8Q.html

properties.name: First Congregational Church
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The First Congregational Church of Palo Alto is on the corner of Louis and Embarcadero. The previous church structure is included here in 4 photos as well as the current church. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: First National Bank
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The current home of the Bank of the West on California Avenue was once home to the First National Bank as this photo circa 1960 shows. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: First Palo Alto Speed Limit (1905)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  In 1905, Palo Alto passed its first traffic law. Speed limit is "a slow trot:"

properties.name: First Presbyterian Church (1958)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The First Presbyterian Church as seen in 1958. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: First Southern Baptist Church
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: On December 13th, 1960, a roaring four-alarm fire completely leveled the First Southern Baptist Church of Palo Alto at Waverley Street and Forest Avenue. Although no one was injured in the fire, the event soon made headlines in newspapers all over the country. Why? Because as was eventually discovered, it was the church’s own pastor who had intentionally burned it down. Photo #2: The Waverley Surgery Center has been at this location since 2002. Photo #3: The same building circa 1970. Photo #4: Circa 1970. Photo #5: This was originally the location of the First Presbyterian Church of Palo Alto. This 1907 photo shows the laying down of the cornerstone to the church. Link to 360 degree panorama of Forest and Waverley in 1997: http://www.virtualparks.org/scenes/ZeR99ThblZoYWCCXvEa9bwQ.html (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: First United Methodist Church (1914-1961)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The First United Methodist Church dates back to 1895. This chapel served between 1914 and 1961, when it was dismantled (as seen in Photo #2) in favor of the Gothic style church that stands here now. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: First United Methodist Church (1961-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The First United Methodist Church of Palo Alto has been serving the community since 1894. Photo #1: The striking Gothic structure under construction in 1962. Photo #2: Inside the church. Photo #3 Looking up. Photo #4: This white stucco house of worship opened in 1914 and remained until 1961. Photo #5: Two shots of the inside of the stucco church. Photo #6: "Architect Carlton Arthur "Art" Steiner was chosen to be architect of the new sanctuary, he had not yet designed a church building. Holder of bachelor\'s and master\'s degrees in architecture from U.C. Berkeley, and for six years on the faculty there, his architectural practice included commercial and residential work. The selection committee, however, discerned that he had the creativity and vision needed to provide them with the bold, out of the ordinary design that they so wanted. He submitted "many, many" sketches; finally one was accepted. When asked what was the biggest challenge of the design and building process, Mr. Steiner replied, "Satisfying the building committee!" -firstpaloalto.com Photo #7: President Jimmy Carter at booksigning in 2001. Photo #8: Children at the chancel in 2003. Photo #9: Construction of the contemporary Gothic cathedral in 1962-63. During construction the membership met in the Varsity Theatre.

properties.name: First University Avenue Train Station
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: The original train station on University Avenue was little more than a sheltered bench. It was located south of the current station. Photo #2: Over the year it became more of an actual station. Photo #3: A sign reading "Palo Alto" can be seen next to the station.

properties.name: Foot Locker
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This is the site of Foot Locker in 2009. It was formerly Kinney\'s Shoes.

properties.name: Foothills Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory With the acquisition of Foothills Park, a new dimension was added to the traditional park concept: open space preservation. Both the profile of the landscape and the vegetation are to be kept in a state as close as possible to their natural condition. The park features Las Trampas Valley and a few man-made additions such as the Interpretative Center, the 12 acre Boronda Lake and a system of roads and hiking trails. Dr. Russel V. Lee, founder of the Palo Alto Medical Clinic, bought the property in 1941 and built a large A-frame barn which now houses the Interpretative Center. In 1958, he offered the park to the City of Palo Alto at a special price of 000 an acre so it could be preserved rather than subdivided. A public vote was held in 1959 on the proposed purchase. The vote was 6,542 for and 3,997 against. The park is restricted to Palo Alto residents to prevent overuse. Source: PAHA\'s Parks of Palo Alto

properties.name: Foothills Park Entrance
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Only Palo Alto residents and their guests are allowed into Foothills Park.

properties.name: Ford Aerospace (1976-1990)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This description came from a Palo Alto Weekly from 6/25/2007: "Walking through the Space Systems/Loral campus in Palo Alto feels a little like being an Oompa Loompa in Willy Wonka\'s fictional chocolate factory. Claustrophobic corridors the length of two football fields suddenly open up to seven-story clean rooms with 60-foot doors, dwarfing the robed, hair-netted workers and the huge satellites they assemble. Open another door and you\'re face to face with a giant orb known as the "blue pumpkin," where assembled satellites are alternately heated and cooled in a vacuum to simulate the temperature fluctuations of life in space. Employees call it the "shake & bake" room, because it also houses test equipment designed to simulate the conditions of a rocket launch." Photos #1-#3: President George Bush visits Ford Aerospace in April of 1989. The remarks he made there can be found in the link above. The company began life as the Western development laboratories of Philco in 1957 and launched its first satellite in 1960 -- a small repeater orb that barely resembles the huge communications satellites it builds today. It became Philco-Ford in 1966, Ford Aerospace in 1976 and finally Space Systems/Loral in 1990. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Foreign Friends (1989-1994)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory It was not exactly The Statue of Liberty, but Palo Alto was once given a statue in friendship from its sister city, Linkoping, Sweden. Known as “Foreign Friends” --- Fjareen Vanner in Swedish --- it was installed at the grassy corner of Waverley and Embarcadero in September of 1989 as a tribute to the bond between the two cities. The 11 foot wood plank statue depicted a couple sitting on a bench accompanied by a dog at their feet and a bird perched above on a street lamp. Opinions differed greatly on the statue --- some saw it as grotesquely ugly, others as charmingly original. But the tale of Foreign Friends would be a sad one --- in ten years time, Foreign Friends would be nowhere in sight, rotting away and buried in a Palo Alto landfill. Photo #1: Graffiti-stained Photo #2: Dressed up for the Black & White Ball, even the dog. Photo #3: A top hat was part of the outfit for this Black & White Ball. Photo #4: The statue was 11 feet tall. Photo #5: Foreign Friends was a popular photo site. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Forest Ave
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Forest Avenue was especially noted for its oaks, particularly the 400 block where several of the early residences were built --- hence the name. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Forest at Emerson NW
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Looking at the northwest corner of Emerson and Forest circa 1990. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Former Eichler Homes Headquaters
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Former Greer House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Greer House sat on the land in which Town & Country Shopping Center now resides. John Greer is pictured in the first photograph. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Former Location of A and W Rootbeer Stand
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The old A&W Drive-in was located where the Safeway now stands.

properties.name: Former Location of Arco Gas Station
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Site of proposed condos in 1984 that were rejected by Midtown residents. The gas station is currently boarded up.

properties.name: Former Location of City Water Tower (Early 20th Century)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The cooling pond for the water tower later became the children\'s pool.

properties.name: Former Location of Earle and Co. Food Market (1912-1933)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Former Location of Reed and McCauley Mart (1940s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This photo is circa 1940. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Former Palo Alto City Hall (1952-1970), Currently Art Center
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The building on Newell Road that now houses the Palo Alto Art Center served as city hall during Palo Alto\'s most tumultuous years. Most exciting of all was the 1967 Recall Election in which residentialists and establishment candidates waged an epic political battle. Video Link: http://blip.tv/file/2532468 Photo #1: City Hall Circa 1955. Photo #2 The Art Center in 2007. Photo #3: Looking across at City Hall soon after its opening. Photo #4: Inside the council chambers. Video Link: http://www.youtube.com/paweekly#p/u/89/3GeFB-k7-l8

properties.name: Former Site of El Cumbre nightclub
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This was also the location of a Hollywood Video in the 2000s.

properties.name: Former Stanford Eating Club
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory 1229 Stanford Avenue (now a residence) was one of three eating clubs for Stanford students, located in College Terrace.

properties.name: Former site of El Rancho Motel, now Quality Inn
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This area once was a beacon for police activity, at least by Palo Alto\'s rather tame standards. It was La Cumbre nightclub, much maligned by nearby esidents. Police recorded 82 disturbances or calls for service at the address in little over a year. The club was eventually stripped of its permit and shut down by the City Council. Live music (gasp!) seemed to be the root of all evil according to residents. It led to parking, litter, drunken behavior, urinating in public, noise and fighting. And in what must be considered a rather heavy exaggeration, Palo Alto Council member Gary Fazzino concluded that "it\'s practically like Dodge City out there on El Camino Real,and unfortunately Wyatt Earp isn\'t available." Dodge City also included the El Rancho Motel that once stood just behind the club on Ventura Street. Once a proud Highway 101 motel, the El Rancho took a turn for the worse in the 1980s and \'90s. Its shady clientele and rent by the hour policy did not make it a favorite in the neighborhood and earned it the nickname, "El Rauncho." Today a crispy-clean Quality Inn has replaced the motel and a Hollywood Video has replaced the rowdy club. It seems that when the address is in Palo Alto, Wyatt Earp usually prevails in the end. The older drawing is circa 1955.

properties.name: Formerly Bob's Donuts
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Fosters Freeze
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This is the former location of Foster\'s Freeze which was one of the first of the franchise locations to open in the 1950s. It later became Palo Alto Classic before closing. The building has since been replaced and is an eyeglass frame shop. In 1955, the first Foster Freeze franchise was started in Tulare, California.

properties.name: Fraiche Yogurt (2007-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "The frozen-yogurt trend in Palo Alto got a jumpstart last year, when Palo Altans Jessica Gilmartin and Patty Roj formed a partnership and opened Fraiche Yogurt at 644 Emerson St. The appeal was the quality of their product — they pasteurized their own yogurt and made it on-site, in the back of the store. Word spread quickly. Customers often are waiting in lines that spill out onto the sidewalk. Business became so prosperous that the two are about to open their second shop in San Mateo. "We had so many customers who traveled down here from Burlingame and San Mateo. There was a need and a great opportunity, so we took it. Opening a second Fraiche was the right thing to do," Gilmartin said." -Palo Alto Weekly 7/23/08

properties.name: Fran's
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Fran\'s, a convenience store on Lytton at Cowper. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Fraternal Hall
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Built in 1898, this was an early 20th Century meeting hall for such groups as the Palo Alto Elks. The lower floor is now occupied on the left by Miyake Sushi which opened across the street in 1985. This building was damaged in, but survived, the 1906 earthquake. (PAHA Collection) Photo #1: Circa 1900. Photo #2: 2007 with Miyake\'s on the corner. Photo #3: In 1985 with Copymat in the corner location. Photo #4: The University Drug Company and the Palo Altan newspaper on the first floor after withstanding the 1906 earthquake. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Freeway Wall (1988)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Workers putting up a freeway wall in 1988 at the Embarcadero on ramp. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Fremont Pharmacy
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This is the former location of the Fremont Pharmacy.

properties.name: Frenchman's Tower
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "Palo Alto Historian Steve Staiger says that whoever finally figures out the original purpose of Frenchman\'s Tower will get their 15 minutes of fame--at least in Palo Alto. This approximately two-story brick tower looks a lot like a displaced castle turret, except that its gothic-arched windows are all bricked over. Reportedly built in the late 18th century by the Peninsula\'s celebrated French pioneer, Peter Coutts, the tower now stands guard right off of Old Page Mill Road. A barbed-wire fence and "Private Property" sign encourages would-be puzzle-solvers to keeping their hypothesizing to the public side of the fence--as if the clump of poison oak clinging to the tower wasn\'t incentive enough." -Source: Metroactive Video Link: Steve Staiger discusses Frechman\'s Tower

properties.name: Friends Nursery School (1955-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Palo Alto Friends Nursery School (FNS) was started in 1955 by a group of mothers from Palo Alto Friends Meeting. In 1968, Friends became an independent non-sectarian program. But true to its Quaker roots, it maintained a philosophy of non-violence and a policy of decision making by consensus. Meeting allowed the school to remain on their premises on the condition it provide scholarships for needy families. They\'ve continued to sponsor the school by providing our facilities and helping with the cost of building upgrades. It\'s Meeting\'s generosity that allows us to keep our fees within a reasonable range. From 1968-1974, a variety of configurations for morning and afternoon programs were tried. FNS became a cooperative, with parents working on the Board, in the programs, and on fundraising to support the scholarship fund. During this period the children\'s programs were excellent but the business side of the school was unstructured, and the facilities were badly in need of maintenance and updating." -FNS Website

properties.name: Friendship Bridge (1885)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The bridge that crossed over San Francisquito Creek at Newell Road in 1885. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Fry's Electronics
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Frys is in a strange location is strange for a reason---this area was supposed to be housing---the City Council first said so in 1984. So when Fry\'s first located here in 1991, it was a gamble. The city\'s zoning plan called for the area to become housing in 1999. In a vote that favored tax revenue over housing, the City Council allowed Fry\'s to stay until 2019. Then in 2006, they wiped the 2019 date off the books completely---plus they gave Fry\'s a bigger sign. Those owning houses around Fry\'s have been furious, saying that they bought homes there under the agreement that the nearby property would revert to residential use in 1999 (presumably that would raise the value of their homes as well). Now, they claim the city is flip-flopping because of the 00,000 in tax revenues that Fry\'s generates annually.

properties.name: Fuller & Co. Food and Meats
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Tthe Fuller & Co. Market in the late 1800s.

properties.name: Fuller Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The collapsed Fuller Building on Alma Street in 1906 after the earthquake. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Fulton Street
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Fulton Street was named after a well-known Reno resident, Robert Lardin Fulton, author of Epic of the Overland, who purchased property in Palo Alto. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: G. Wigle Home
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Sign on the side of the house advertises "Houses Built on the Installment Plan...." Photo is from circa 1900 (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Garden Court Hotel (1986-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory 520 Cowper St, Palo Alto, CAThe Garden Court Hotel opened in 1986. The photo of construction was shot in the hotel courtyard. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Garden at Middlefield & Palo Alto Ave
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory City parks crew and Palo Alto Garden Club members are sprucing up the planting area at the north entrance to Palo Alto in 1987. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Garland Drive (1945-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  In the late 1920s John and Temperance Garland purchased Dr. W.H. Ketcham\'s fifteen acres of dairy land east of Middlefield Road and north of the present-day Oregon Avenue. In 1945, the acreage was subdivided into 72 lots. Winding through it was Garland Drive, one of the first curved streets in Palo Alto. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Garland Elementary School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory PAUSD plans to re-open Garland in 2010 to deal with increased enrollment. Currently the grounds are leased out to Stratford Schools, a private school founded in 1999 with locations throughout the Bay Area. Photo #1: Architectural plans for the new Garland. Photo #2: Top-down view of the new Garland to open in 2010. Photo #3: A Garland School 3rd Grade class in 1978-79.

properties.name: General Petroleum (1930-1939)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Historic Buildings Inventory as revised in 1985: The competent design qualities of this complex were applauded when it was built and it remains a handsome survivor of the early years of the automobile era. It was more carefully planned and developed than the typical "gas station" of the \'twenties and anticipated the expansive facilities of contemporary automobile service centers. As a consequence of changes in the financing and marketing policies of the major oil companies, most such early stations have disappeared. From 1930 to 1939, it was a General Petroleum Corporation outlet under several managers." Built in 1929. Photo #1: 2008 Palo Alto Bimmer Photo #2: Kwik Key (1975) Photo #3: 1985 Photo #4: The station was serving as a Mobilgas in this photo circa 1945.

properties.name: Geng Road
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Named for the dairy once located here belonging to Jacob Geng. In 1942 he sold his property to the city for the building of the golf course. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: George Hood Lane
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Named after City of Palo Alto employee and Superintendent of Parks George Hood who was known as "Mr. Arbor Day for planting more than 50,000 of Palo Alto\'s many trees. (1976) Photo #1: George Hood is presented with his own lane. Source: PAHA\'s Streets of Palo Alto Photo #2: George Hood, standing proud. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Gideon Hausner Jewish Day School‎ (1989-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A small private Jewish day school founded in 1989.

properties.name: Gilman Street
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Although Gilman Street was named for a property owner, there was a 1929 movement to honor Charlotte Perkins Gilman, an ardent feminist, with this name but the City Council refused to take any action. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Gilman Street Parking Lot (ca. 1960s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A photo looking northwest towards 300 Hamilton and Hamilton Avenue in the 1960s.

properties.name: Glass Slipper Inn
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Go Mama! (1999-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory California Avenue is an important economic viaduct in the city, but has also increasingly become a kind of drive-thru art gallery. Collector of contemporary art Gerald Brett, has been the driving force behind this Palo Alto “Avenue of the Arts.” As a member of the 7 member Palo Alto Public Art Commission he has helped raise money and spend city money on sculptures like Marta Thoma\'s bronze sculpture, "Go Mama!" Brett calls it a "fabulous piece of surrealism." It’s also a sculpture of a Mexican doll with a face is in its belly. ,250 of taxpayer money went for the statue and some folks have a laundry list of other things for which the money might be better spent.

properties.name: Gold Seal Creamery Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Built in 1927. Photo #1: The home to Krung Siam was the location of Celia\'s back in 1985. Photo #2: This was the site of the Gold Seal Creamery in the 1940s. Photo #3: Terra cotta at the former Gold Seal Creamery Building. Photo #4: In 2009, this is the home to Krung Siam, a Thai restaurant. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Gordon Biersch Brewery (1988-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Abandoned in 1985. Photo #2: The location of the old Bijou Theater is now the highly successful Gordon Biersch Brewery.

properties.name: Gospel Hall (1904-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Gospel Hall at 403 Florence was constructed in in 1904. Photo #1: After the 1906 earthquake. Photo #2:Circa 1905. Photo #3: In this photo, Gospel Hall is serving as the home to the California AAA. Photo #4: 1985 Photo #5: 1906

properties.name: Grant Avenue (1867-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Platted out on William Paul\'s map of Mayfield in 1867, the name was a typical choice of the time when cities were honoring Civil War heroes. Grant, Sheridan, Sherman and Lincoln (later changed to California) are all Mayfield examples. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Grant Street (1887)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This structure at the foot of Grant Street by the railroad tracks was used by Mayfield Catholics as a place of worship. Here we see it during the 1887 snowstorm. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Grateful Dead Hangout (early 1960s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The huge turn-of-the-century Victorian at 436 Hamilton Avenue was a popular hang-out for Jerry Garcia and the early incarnations of the Grateful Dead. The office building there now is seen in the mid-1980s in the photo. Photo #2: Cornish & Carey Real Estate had their offices here.

properties.name: Greater Bay Trust
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The Greater Bay Trust Bank. Photo #2: The bank was formerly known as the Cupertino National Bank & Trust. Photo #3: The bank features a Greg Brown mural of a "Secret Agent Man With Bird on Hat." Photo #4: This was once the home of the Live Oak Service Station. The station sold Mobilgas. (1920s or \'30s). (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Green Elephant Gourmet (2005-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Green Gables Elementary School (1950-1982)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The merger of Green Gables and Crescent Park elementary schools in 1982 resulted in a new name for the school. It was named after Los Altos Hills philanthropists Frank and Josephine Duveneck, founders of the Hidden Villa environmental education center. Photo #1: This was the only school seriously affected by the 1998 San Francisquito Creek Flood. Photo #2: Frank Duveneck at his desk Photo #3: the 1977-78 school faculty when still known as Green Gables. Photo #4: Duveneck in 2007. Photo #5, 6: Duveneck when still known as Green Gables. Photo #7: The Crescent Park school staff before merging with Green Gables. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Greendell School (Formerly)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This is the former site of Greendell School which closed when enrollment in PAUSD plummeted in the 1970s. Included is a photo of the 1971-72 faculty. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Greenmeadow Community Association (1954-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "From its start in 1954 Greenmeadow was designed to be a family community with easy proximity to shopping, libraries and schools. Inspired by principals of modern architecture conceived by Frank Lloyd Wright, Joe Eichler built homes featuring spacious living areas and lots, floor-to-ceiling windows and three or more bedrooms, which he located around a community center, pool, and park." -Greenmeadow.org

properties.name: Greenwood Ave (1981)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A photo of Gingko trees in early spring of 1981. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Greer Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory While many drive-in owners cashed out by selling their land for housing or office parks, Palo Alto’s drive-in became a park. After closing, the land sat dormant until in 1973, neighborhood activists rallied the city to purchase the land and combine it with bordering Amarillo Park to form a larger park. Over the course of the next 20 years Palo Alto would construct what came to be called Greer Park in a series of phases --- adding softball fields, basketball courts and eventually a skate park located at its southern edge.

properties.name: Greer Road
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Greer Road commemorates one of the pioneer families of Palo Alto. In 1850 John Greer, an Irish seafarer, leased land of the Rancho Rinconada del Arroyo de San Francisquito. He later married the window Maria Luisa Soto de Copinger, a daughter of Rafael Soto, gaining control of the Soto Ranch, now Palo Alto. During the 1860s, the Greer\'s large family house was relocated on the northwest corner of El Camino Real and Embarcadero Road. In 1951, it was razed to build Town & Country Village.

properties.name: Greer Skate Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Greer Skate Park is on the Southside of Greer Park. "The park opened in January 1991, a year after the City Council outlawed skateboarding on Palo Alto\'s busiest streets. It was one of the first such parks on the Peninsula, and cost approximately 00,000. Originally, the city hoped younger students would use it, but today it\'s more popular with high school students and other bikers and skateboarders. Because it\'s advanced and lacks features like bars for "grinding" and stairs, the park is not used much by younger skateboarders. Instead, they travel to other cities like Redwood City and Campbell, which both created newer skateboard parks in the past two years." -Palo Alto Weekly The last photo, of course, shows why the city built the park in the first place.

properties.name: Greg Brown Mural
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  At 136 Hamilton you can find a Greg Brown mural of a garbage man with an alien. Photo #1: Garbage man with alien Photo #2: Pedestrian passing the mural. Photo #3: The artist painting the mural with spectators about.

properties.name: Greg Brown Mural: Ailing Polar Bear
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This Greg Brown mural can be found at the Health Library at the Stanford Shopping Center next to Bloomingdales.

properties.name: Greg Brown Mural: Aliens Climbing Stairs to Milkman
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Another in local artist Greg Brown\'s "Palo Alto Pedestrians" series.

properties.name: Greg Brown Mural: Bank Robbers Mishap
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This Greg Brown mural was originally painted on University Avenue and the faces of the burglars were of he and his wife. When it was repainted on the 300 Hamilton building, he used the faces of his children instead. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Greg Brown Mural: Boy Fishing
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Greg Brown\'s mural of a boy fishing at the side of Birge Clark\'s post office.

properties.name: Greg Brown Mural: Crashing Alien
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Greg Brown painted this whimsical mural in 1986 on the rear side of the University Bank & Trust. The older photo shows the artist at work. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Greg Brown Mural: Spiro Agnew Pushing Alien in Stroller
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Spiro Agnew pushes an alien in a baby carriage. This mural is on the side of the building housing Restoration Hardware.

properties.name: Gunn Gymnasium
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: H+R Bookstore (1970s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory There was a time in the early 1970s when El Camino Real in the Barron Park area took on a seamy side. There were adult theaters, many "massage parlors," and the H+R Bookstore which billed itself as "Palo Alto\'s only adult bookstore."

properties.name: Hackett Pontiac
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The old Hackett Pontiac dealership Photo #2: It served as a location for the Athletic Shoe Factory in the 1980s. Photos #3,4 The dealership staff poses out front in the 1930s. A sign in the back says Weltner Auto Company. Photo #5: Hackett Pontiac.

properties.name: Hage's Music Shop
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1:Hage\'s Music Shop, also known as Stanford Music Shop, was located at 266 University Avenue. Side entrance to the Ramona Hotel is seen to the right. Photo #2: In the 1920s this was the Stanford Meat Market. Notice the chickens hanging behind the butcher to the right. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Hale Street (ca. 1920)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A postcard of a trolley headed down University Avenue as seen from Hale Street. Note the tree still standing in the middle of the road.

properties.name: Hamilton at Emerson (circa 1965)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking west on Hamilton at Emerson in the 1960s when every other car on the road seemed to be a VW Beetle. The Craig Hotel is at left and the Peninsula Creamery at right. Casa Olga was not yet built on the southern corner. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Hamilton at High (ca. 1930)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking east up Hamilton towards the Cardinal Hotel and Downing Block. Miller and Sanor Groceries is in the near building at the right. The decorations say "Seasons Greetings." (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Hanover Street (1956)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Two 1956 views looking down the hill where Hanover Street climbs. The new Lockheed plant parking lot is visible on the right. Hansen Way and the Varian buildings are visible in the distance. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Hansen Way
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Hansen Way is named for William W. Hansen, a graduate of Stanford and pioneer in microwave electronics. With the Varian Brothers he invented the klystron, a revolutionary high-frequency vacuum tube.

properties.name: Hansen Way (1967)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Hansen Way and El Camino Real where a Varian sign stands in the background. The photo is from 1967.

properties.name: Harker Street
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This street is named for Catherine Harker\'s "Miss Harker\'s School for Girls" which opened here in 1902. The school still exists as the Harker Academy in San Jose. Source: PAHA\'s Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Harriet Mundy Marsh
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Harriet Mundy Marsh was dedicated in 1982 to Ms. Mundy, a close friend of Lucy Evans who helped circulate a petition which resulted in the Cty Council stopping development until a Baylands Master Plan was prepared. Source: PAHA\'s Parks of Palo Alto

properties.name: Harvard Street in College Terrace
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A house on Harvard Street was used by an undercover female officer to attempt to trap the College Terrace Rapist in 1980 For the story go to: http://www.paloaltohistory.com/collegeterracerapist.html

properties.name: Hay Baker Jewelers
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Hay Baker Jewelers was here at 374 University in the 1940s.

properties.name: Henry M. Gunn High School (1964-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Henry M. Gunn Senior High School was constructed in 1964. One of the two public high schools in Palo Alto, it is a 4-year high school with an enrollment of just over 1900 students (454 seniors). Photo #1: School grounds in the 1960s. Photo #2: Henry Gunn himself in 1961. He served as the Palo Alto superintendent from 1950 to 1961 Photo #3: Robert McLean and Henry M. Gunn at Gunn High School graduation ceremony, 1981 Photo #4: Student leaders in the 1970s. Photo #5: School grounds in 2008. Photo #6: Students on campus.

properties.name: Henry W. Seale Park (1968-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Stockton Park was renamed for Henry W. Seale in 1968. Seale came to California from Ireland via New Orleans and, in 1865, was granted title to 1,400 acres of Rancho Rinconada del Arroyo de San Francisquito. In 1887 Seale sold 697 acres to Timothy Hopkins who wanted the property to develop a town which would become Palo Alto. The remainder of Seale’s property was farmed until his death in 1888." -City of Palo Alto Website

properties.name: Henry's (ca. 1941)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Harry\'s as seen behind paraders, ca. 1941. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Heritage Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Palo Alto’s newest park sits on the former site of the Palo Alto Medical Foundation. The Foundation moved in 1999, and negotiations between Summerhill Homes (new property owners), the city of Palo Alto, the Medical Foundation, and the neighbors led to several acres being set aside for a park. In 2003 the city approved an interim park; groundbreaking took place in 2004, and on March 12, 2006 Heritage Park had its grand opening." -City of Palo Alto Link to a 360 degree panorama of the corner of Homer and Waverley in 1996. Shows the parking lot that used to be where Heritage Park now is: http://www.virtualparks.org/scenes/ZmtjmSnyanZLwta8IpHCsRg.html

properties.name: Hewlett-Packard
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory it would take the influence of Stanford Professor Frederick Terman to make the Stanford Industrial Park a place to be. Calling the park “our secret weapon,” Terman begin to convince companies to come to Palo Alto and set up shop at what would be the first university-owned industrial park in the world. First aboard was Varian Associates which obtained a park lease in 1951. Terman then convinced Hewlett-Packard to head out to Page Mill Road, where they remain to this day. Soon, a flood of other corporations would make Stanford Industrial Park one of the most prestigious addresses on the West Coast --- and eventually give the Peninsula a collection of big name companies to rival any conglomeration back east. General Electric, Eastman Kodak, Lockheed Martin and hundreds of others joined Varian and HP, transforming the old “Garden of Heart’s Delight” into the ultra-modern Silicon Valley. Photos: Fred Terman with Hewlett and Packard, the HP headquarters yesterday and today. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Hill & Yard Photographs
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1 & 2: 220 University lost a Burger King in 2001 and gained a Pizza My Heart, the slice-heavy, thin crust pizza joint that started in 1981 in surfer hangout, Capitola Beach. With its decorated walls of surfer paraphernalia and photos, perhaps it looks a bit out of place in downtown Palo Alto, but it seems to have found a spot in the neighborhood. Its young, attractively hip staff always sporting those Pizza My Heart shirts, may have helped the resturant get voted "Coolest Palo Alto Hang-out" by the 2003 Paly class. It also has plenty of Best of Palo Altos up on its walls. Owned by pizza magnet Chuck Hammers (who also oddly owns the competition---Pizza A Go Go), Pizza My Heart continues to ride its own wave of popularity. Photo #3: In the 1890s this was the site of Hill & Yard Photographs. This photo is from 1894. Notice the photo display on the post. The Ledyard Building can be seen at far right. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Historian Guy Miller
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Guy Miller was Palo Alto\'s first historian. He worked out of the Carnegie Library on Hamilton Avenue. The Palo Alto Historical Archives are named for Guy Miller. Incidentally, he was also Palo Alto\'s first mail carrier. In November of 1954, Palo Alto Times columnist Elinor Cogswell rallied her readers to support the “adequate display --- and care --- of the valuable collection of Palo Alto historical material. This is now crowded into a corridor of the [library] basement, accessible only to those who venture down a dark flight of stairs and hunt out Historian Guy Miller among the stacks.” Today\'s Palo Alto historian is Steve Staiger, to whom this project owes a great debt of gratitude. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Hobee's Restaurant (1984-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This popular Palo Alto restaurant is part of the Hobee\'s chain founded by Paul Taber in 1974 in Mountain View. This Stanford location opened in 1984. The restaurant has won many local "best breakfast" awards from local papers. The older photograph is of the original Hobee\'s take-out location in Mountain View.

properties.name: Holly Oak Drive (ca. 1980)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The 700 block of Holly Oak Drive, circa 1980. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Homage to Silence
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Created by artist Jerome Kirk, “Homage To Silence” is located in the sculpture garden of the Palo Alto Art Center, 1313 Newell Road. The work was commissioned by the Public Art Commission and funded by the City of Palo Alto in 1981." -Public Art Commission In the third photo, Georganna and Leon Kaplan pose at the statue in 1987. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Home of J.F. Parkinson
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This was the location of the home of J.F. Parkinson, one of Palo Alto\'s preeminent early citizens. He was the first active mayor, the first postmaster, organizer of the Chamber of Commerce, master of ceremonies for the historical society and director of the first Bank of Palo Alto.

properties.name: Homer Avenue (1990)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Looking east down Homer Avenue in 1990. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Homer's Warehouse
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This warehouse was used for a time as a concert hall. Nick Gravenitis and Luther Tucker, Sons of Champlin and Charos Chorus, Quickfield, Stoneground, Rowan Bros. and Bob Banks and the Gas Tanks all played there.

properties.name: Hoover Elementary school
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Hoover School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Herbert Hoover Elementary School once stood here alongside Hoover Park. Today Hoover has moved to Charleston Road, the site of the former Ohlone School. The first Hoover School was closed due to declining enrollment. Today the old school grounds are the home to the Southwood Apartment complex. The new Hoover opened in 1974.

properties.name: Hope Technology School (2001-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Hope Technology School is a not -for -profit school, established in 2001, with the mission of providing an exceptional learning experience for typical and special needs children in a fully inclusive, technology rich environment. " -HTS Website

properties.name: Hopkins at Pine (ca. 1980s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This old house at Hopkins and Pine has since been torn down. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Hostess House (Community House)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Palo Alto\'s Community House Photo #2: Caretaker Charles Olaine poses in front of the newly landscaped Community House, the former World War I Hostess House. The building has also served as a community center and veterans memorial building. The base of the flagpole is visible along with the exterior view of the front of the building. The restaurant opened in 1981. Photo #3: Circa 1930 Photo #4: Circa 1941 Photo #5: As the Veterans Memorial Building Photo #6: Inside the Community House Photo #7:The Hostess House from above before the University Avenue overpass was built. Video of Historian Steve Staiger discussing the Hostess House: http://blip.tv/file/2520236

properties.name: Hostess House (Now MacArthur Park Restaurant)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Original Palo Alto Community Center and later veterans hall

properties.name: Hostess House Flagpole
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The flagpole near the Hostess House originally stood without a monument. When the University Avenue overpass was constructed, the war memorial flag pole that was formerly at the north end of The Circle was moved to this location. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Hotel Cabana (1962-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Opening in 1962, the Cabaña was originally awarded a 5-star rating and was described by Life Magazine as one of the best hotels on the West Coast. In the 1960s, it attracted such high-profile celebrities as Frank Sinatra, Sammy Davis, Jr., and the Beatles. But although The Cabaña managed to attract the celebrity crowd to Palo Alto, not all were so impressed by its design. Doris Day, unwitting part owner of the hotel, did not exactly sing its praises when she first saw it. Actually, she burst into tears. And that was just upon seeing the outside. “Impossible as it may seem, the inside was worse." Day said, recalling the Cabaña in her autobiography. "I got physically ill just walking through the lobby." And Day wasn’t convinced of the location either. She told her husband, "But it\'s Palo Alto, Marty! Who\'s going to stay at a hotel like that in Palo Alto --- and without gambling?" The Palo Alto History Project The Hotel Cabaña 4290 El Camino Real 2006 The Hotel Cabaña: Vegas Comes to Palo Alto Jay Sarno reinvented Las Vegas. In 1966, he gambled big-time with “Caesar’s Palace,” an outrageously conceptualized hotel that paved the way for the “New Las Vegas”--- an eclectic collection of quasi-theme park replica hotels that has made the desert city a kind fantastical ode to the rest of the world. Whether it’s San Marcos Square, the Eiffel Tower, the Manhattan Skyline or Rome --- you can get them all in Vegas, at a smaller scale, yes, but with quarter slots just one floor down. And it was Caesar’s Palace, a grandiose, almost garishly obscene monument to ancient Rome, done up Vegas- style, that started it all. Just in time, too. By the mid-60s, Vegas had become a tired collection of old Western- themed gambling hotels centered in the increasingly adults-only Downtown area. Strangely, before Sarno took his miniature model vision to the Sin City, however, he did a kind of test run --- and in Palo Alto of all places. The Palo Alto Cabaña Hotel maybe wasn’t as full-frontal in its exhibitionism as Caesar’s would be, but with statues of the Winged Victory and Michelangelo\'s David out front, it wasn’t too far off the pace, either. Palo Altans were a bit overcome by the El Camino Real hotel. With its Roman-themed Nero bar, 0,000 in cypress trees imported direct from Italy, and waitresses dressed in togas, the Cabaña was something else alright. Opening in 1962, the Cabaña was originally awarded a 5-star rating and was described by Life Magazine as one of the best hotels on the West Coast. In the 1960s, it attracted such high-profile celebrities as Frank Sinatra, Sammy Davis, Jr., and the Beatles. Perhaps the most unforgettable night in the hotel\'s history was August 31st, 1965, when the Beatles stayed at the Cabaña. Crowds of teenage girls held a two-night vigil outside the hotel, causing a traffic jam on El Camino. Hundreds of fans were disappointed when the band snuck out in a 1.5 ton truck the next day (The Cabaña’s present owners have dedicated Room 810 to the group, decorating it with Beatles paraphernalia, books, and newspaper clippings from the Fab Four\'s stay in Palo Alto). But although The Cabaña managed to attract the celebrity crowd to Palo Alto, not all were so impressed by its design. Doris Day, unwitting part owner of the hotel, did not exactly sing its praises when she first saw it. Actually, she burst into tears. And that was just upon seeing the outside. “Impossible as it may seem, the inside was worse." Day said, recalling the Cabaña in her autobiography. "I got physically ill just walking through the lobby." And Day wasn’t convinced of the location either. She told her husband, "But it\'s Palo Alto, Marty! Who\'s going to stay at a hotel like that in Palo Alto --- and without gambling?" Day proved to be correct. Over time, the Cabaña lost its stars---both celebrities and those in the ratings guides--- and by 1992 the hotel was washed-up. Four years later, just as the City Council was getting ready to hear final approval to build 93 homes in its place, hotelier B. B. Patel purchased the Cabaña and overhauled the design. Today it operates as the more run-of-the-mill Crowne Plaza Cabaña, a hotel on a strip of hotels. Still although few know it --- like a retired Vegas showgirl --- the Cabaña had a little glitz and glamour in its day. The postcards are circa 1965.

properties.name: Hotel California (1984-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Hotel California is located at Ash Street and California Avenue. Photo #1: 2008 Photo #2: Taken in 1984 soon after opening. Photo #3: Taken in 1983 as the hotel was under construction. The Oddfellows Building (hosting a Walderbooks) is across California Avenue, although barely recognizable from its original state.

properties.name: Hotel De Zink (1931-1934)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The inspiration of Mrs. Mary Belle Glover, the Hotel de Zink, nicknamed after PA\'s supportive police chief, became a treasured stop-over "hotel"for vagrants during the Great Depression. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Hyderabad House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: In 1985 this was the location of Tokyo Sushi Tempura. Photo #2: In 1970, the Varsity Barbershop could be found here. Photo #3: In 2009, this location houses the curry restaurant Hyderabad House.

properties.name: I Magnin
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This was originally the location of the I. Magnin Department Store when the Stanford Shopping Center opened in 1956. In 2009, it is the Macy\'s Men\'s Store.

properties.name: Indian Bowl (1940s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Indian Bowl was located in the heart of the automobile district in the 1940s. The purveyor of “the fastest boards in town,” Indian Bowl used the not-so-P.C. Stanford moniker as its namesake and logo. And its offer of 50 dollars to anyone who bowled a perfect 300 game perhaps does not seem so generous until considering that bowling a line (10 frames) cost two dimes until 6 PM and a quarter after that. The Indian Bowl advertisements from that era also recall the pre- mechanized days of bowling---“Pin boys are always available!” boast the fliers.

properties.name: International School of the Peninsula (1979-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "The International School of the Peninsula (previously known as the Peninsula French American School) was founded in 1979 by French teacher Charlotte de Géry, a remarkable woman with an unwavering dedication to bilingual immersion education. When Charlotte and her husband Xavier moved to the Bay Area, she immediately made plans to open a French-American school in the Peninsula area. In 1962, they were about to open the doors to "Ecole de Géry." Unfortunately, difficulty beset the de Géry family and halted Charlotte\'s plans. One of Charlotte\'s children became very ill, and Charlotte was forced to put the dream of opening her own bilingual school on hold. Thankfully, Charlotte\'s child recovered, and seventeen years later, with unwavering dedication, Charlotte was able to see her dream materialize." -ISP website This is the campus for 1st-8th grade. The nursery-kindergarten campus is at 3233 Cowper Street.

properties.name: International School of the Peninsula (1979-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The International School of the Peninsula (ISTP) was established in 1979 as the Peninsula French-American School. Founded by Charlotte de Géry with a small group of parents and friends, the school originally opened its doors to nine students. Today, we have grown to well over five hundred students. -ISTP Website

properties.name: Islamic Society of North America (1985-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The home of the local Islamic Society of North America.

properties.name: Island Drive
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A view of the island on Island Drive looking south from Edgewood, circa 1940. (PAHA)

properties.name: Izzy's Brooklyn Bagels (1996-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "On a crisp autumn morning in 1996, Izzy awoke at the crack of dawn to begin fulfilling his dream of recreating a family recipe and bringing to Palo Alto, California the authentic bagels he had loved in Brooklyn, where he had spent his most impressionable years." -Izzy\'s Brooklyn Bagels Website

properties.name: J, J & F Market (1948-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1948 Joe, John, and Frank Garcia decided to start a \'different kind of grocery store\' in Palo Alto. Today, their sons Dennis, Lloyd, and John still run the local market, which is a neighborhood favorite.

properties.name: J.C. Penney's (1924-1973)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In its early days, the 300 University building was home to the highly successful Palo Alto Furniture Company Palo Alto’s J.C. Penney’s opened in 1924 at 300 University and was run for two decades by Merrill Vanderpool, the kind of locally based store manager who was very much a part of the community --- he was elected to PaloAlto’s school board and Community Center commission, as well as serving as president of the Rotary Club and participated in the operation of the YMCA and American Legion. J.C. Penney’s on University had similar local connections. In 1973, 300 University had a third go-around as a Walgreens and later a Subway opened on its eastern side before a fire destroyed the building in 2008. Photo #1: J.C. Penney\'s Photo #2: The Palo Alto Furniture Company in its final days. Photo #3: After the fire during a street market day on University Avenue. Photo #4: Fire fighters battling the fire (PA Weekly). Photo #5: After the burned building was brought down. Photo #6: Two youngsters a patriot display. The banner says "Meet the freedom train in Palo Alto March 17th." Photo #7: The new building takes shape. Photo #8: Fighting the fire. (PA Weekly) Photo #9: When the building came down in 2008, it revealed on the wall of the building to the east an inscription for "Easterday Furniture." Photo #10: This same inscription can be seen in this photo from the very early part of the century. Photo #11: The Walgreen\'s the day after the fire. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: J.F. Parkinson Home
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The former home of mayor John F. Parkinson, known as the "father of Palo Alto." Parkinson also once lived at 616 Cowper.

properties.name: Jack in the Box
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A Jack in the Box is at the corner of Cambridge and El Camino.

properties.name: Jack in the Box (1950s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This shot of El Camino in Barron Park looking north shows an old-style Jack in the Box restaurant. A new Jack in the Box building is there as of 2009. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Jacobs Court
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Named after Irene Jacobs who managed the Palo Alto Cattery from the 1930s through 1976 until her death at age 90. Source: PAHA\'s Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Jacquie's Sew and Sew
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Formerly located at Alma Plaza. Jacquie has been in business in Palo Alto for more than 30 years.

properties.name: Jamba Juice
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This Jamba Juice was formerly Edy\'s Ice Cream.

properties.name: Jane Lathrop Stanford Middle School (1953-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Jane Lathrop Stanford Middle School was originally named Ray Lyman Wilbur Junior High School after Ray Lyman Wilbur. After the other two middle schools in the district closed due to lack of enrollment, students transferred to the school, which was renamed Jane Lathrop Stanford (abbreviated JLS) after Jane Stanford, who was the wife of Stanford University founder Leland Stanford. The land that Jane Lathrop Stanford Middle School and the adjoining Fairmeadow Elementary School now sit on were once owned by three farmers by the name of Diss.
