The farmers sold their land to the real-estate developer Joseph Eichler, who later donated the land to the district." -Wikipedia Photo #1: Members of the Wilbur poetry club. (1950s) Photo #2: The Wilbur Middle School sign. Photo #3: The gym at JLS (2008). Photo #4: JLS circa 1985 Photo #5: A middle-schooler poses by the school sign to promote a read-a-thon.

properties.name: Japanese Association of Palo Alto (1941)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Immediately following Pearl Harbor, many Palo Alto Japanese-Americans feared the worst and some even pleaded their innocence. Arthur Okado’s family had been in America since 1909. But two days after Pearl Harbor, the President of the Palo Alto Japanese-American Association released a statement printed in the Palo Alto Times, saying “We the members of the Japanese-American community having lived in Palo Alto and Menlo Park throughout 40 years…wish to make our stand clear. Without reservation, we are loyal to this, our country, the United States of America.” The article went on to say that the members of the association had purchased some ,700 in defense bonds and that seven of their men were serving in the Army (including Paly graduate Fred Yamamoto who would posthumously win the Silver Star after dying in France). Still, 10 weeks later, Mr. Okado was arrested by FBI agents along with three other Palo Altans on suspicion of belonging to an “alien Japanese organization.” It wasn’t until February 1945 that he would return home to Palo Alto after being cleared of all suspected wrong-doing. On May 19th, 1942, all Japanese-Americans were ordered to leave Palo Alto and the West Coast by Lieutenant General John L. DeWitt upon the authority of President Franklin Roosevelt’s Executive Order 9066. Later, Dewitt defended his decision saying, “A Jap’s a Jap. We must worry about the Japanese all the time, until he is wiped off the map.” Palo Alto Japanese-Americans had less than a week to sell their homes, farms and businesses --- just a small portion of the 00 million nationwide (in 1942 dollars) that Japanese-Americans would lose because of the internment. On May 26th, 144 local Japanese-Americans boarded busses leaving for the former racetrack that had become the euphemistically-named Santa Anita Reception Center. Each person was only allowed to take as much as they could carry and an animal ban meant that most family pets were destroyed. Japanese-Americans and their Caucasian friends exchanged candy, oranges and other small mementos, while the Palo Alto Society of Friends and the Gray Ladies of the Red Cross brought refreshments, lunch and milk. Then the buses pulled away and they were all gone. Photos: The Japanese Association Palo Alto marching in 1941 down University Avenue in the Dedication Day parade.

properties.name: Jennifer Convertibles
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Jennifer Convertibles furniture store in 2007. Photo #2: The North Face was here in 1985. Photo #3: The Alfred E. Werry Electric shop was here at this location for 14 years. This is also the former home of Cottonworks.

properties.name: Jerry Bowden Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This park is named after Jerome Trimble Bowden, a former City Council member who lived on nearby Nevada Street. Former World War I pilot and Stanford graduate, Bowden was a lover of parks. Bowden Park was originally called California Avenue Park when it opened in 1952. The photo is from 1966. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Jim Loose Imports
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Jim Loose Imports in the early 1980s. The Prime Rib Inn can be seen to the North.

properties.name: John F. Dahl Plumbing
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory John F. Dahl Plumbing has been in business in Palo Alto since 1895. Their motto is "Don\'t cuss...call us." Formerly located at 329 Alma St Photo #1: The Dahl truck in a parade of old vehicles circa 1980.

properties.name: John Hanna House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The flooding of Attorney John Hanna\'s house in the 1998 floods led to Hanna, 26 other homeowners and 1 small business in Palo Alto and Menlo Park suing both cities for their failures in handling the flood. Eventually the cities agreed to a settlement to the tune of .5 million dollars.

properties.name: Johnson Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Johnson Park as seen today and back in 1996. It\'s most alluring feature for most children is its enormous slide. (PAHA Collection) A link to a 360 degree panorama of the park in 1996: http://www.virtualparks.org/scenes/Zr27qRicy5aNaV2rbSaZOrQ.html

properties.name: Johnson Park Gardens
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Jordan Middle School (1937-1985, 1991-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The David Starr Jordan Middle School has approximately 1000 students from grades 6 through 8. The school is named after David Starr Jordan, who was the first president of Stanford University. It was closed in 1985 due to lack of enrollment in the district. It was remodeled and reopened in 1991. A bond was approved by the city of Palo Alto in 1995 to allow for further technological upgrades to the school. Photo #1: 2008. Photo #2: Early 1980s. Photo #3: Welcoming families and students. Photo #4: The dolphin is now the co-mascot of Jordan Middle School. Photo #5: After a cafeteria fire in 1973. Photo #6: Early 1980s. Photo #7: David Starr Jordan.

properties.name: Jordan's Cash Store
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Jordan\'s is decorated for President McKinley\'s 1901 arrival. Unfortunately, the trip was cancelled at the last minute. In 2009, this is the home of the Hatami Rug Collection. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Jose's Caribbean Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Jose\'s Caribbean Restaurant was formerly at this location on El Camino Real and Cambridge Avenue. At one point in the 1980\'s Jose advertised his Cuban restaurant as having "the worst pizza in town." But by the \'90s he was boasting that "nobody cooks like I do." At least I think he was boasting. Photo #1: A car accident outside Jose\'s. Photo #2: Jose himself. Photo #3: Currently home of a new building and the First Republic Bank.

properties.name: Joseph Magnin
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Joseph Magnin was one of the prestigious San Francisco department stores that opened up at Stanford Shopping Center in 1956. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Joya Restaurant & Lounge
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Phone #1: Current home of Joya Restaurant & Lounge serving "modern Latin cuisine." Photo #2: This was also the former location of Bi-Rite Market and Pantages Homemade Candy as seen in this 1941 parade photo. In the 1920s, this was the home of Palo Alto Dairy Lunch. An ad in the phone book said, "Saving money and getting a square meal. When you want a nice place to eat, where the food is good and the price right, drop in at Palo Alto Dairy Lunch. Help yourself. No tips. No waits. Bring your friends."

properties.name: Juana Briones Park (1969-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Named after Juana Briones, who owned the 5,000 acre Rancho Purisima Conception, she was known as "Juana the Emancipated" after leaving her first husband who did not treat her well, and striking out on her own. She spent her later years in Mayfield, living in a house on Page Mill Road and Birch street. The park was dedicated in 1969.

properties.name: Jungle
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  In 2009, this building is occupied by Jungle Digital Imaging. The photograph shows the building circa 1980. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Jungle Jane (1990-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "In 1998, Santa Cruz, CA artist FRED HUNNICUTT installed "Jungle Jane" in the eastern median at the intersection of California Avenue and Birch Street. This aluminum sculpture stands 9\' tall and 6\' wide and is composed of metal rods. Hunnicutt\'s unique work takes the shape of a face pushed through a piece of paper and is, in that sense, both two- and three-dimensional. His work can be seen in many Bay Area cities. “Jungle Jane” was commissioned by the Public Art Commission and funded by the California Avenue Area Development Association (CAADA), the City of Palo Alto, and private contributions." -Palo Alto Public Art Commission

properties.name: Junior Museum & Zoo
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Junior Musuem was one of the country\'s first children\'s museums, and is still one of a variety of activities for kids in the Rinconada Park area of Palo Alto. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Kaikoo V
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  “Kaikoo V ” was a gift to the City of Palo Alto’s Art In Public Places Collection, in the early 1990’s, by BETTY GOLD, an internationally recognized artist. It is sited at the Palo Alto Municipal Golf Course, 1875 Embarcadero." -Palo Alto Art Commission

properties.name: Kathleen Norris Home (1948-1958)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Famed writer Kathleen Norris lived at 1650 Waverley for 10 years after she sold her more famous residence on Cowper Street.

properties.name: Keeble Art Supplies
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The store was run by David Keeble as seen here in the 1930s. Photo #2: Circa 1925 off to the right of the photo. Photo #3: The same building in 1985. Photo #4: During the war years. The small sign in the entryway says "Bonds Buy Mercy, Help Our Wounded Back to Health." In 2009 this is the home of the Medallion Rug Gallery.

properties.name: Keeble and Shuchat Photography (1965-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Keeble and Shuchat Photography in 1993 and 2008. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Kent Place (1938-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Kent place was located in the 1938 Mayfair Subdivision which featured names with an English theme. Mayfair was advertised as a subdivision for particular people and was "one of the few areas which prohibits live poultry." Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Kenyon's
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Former home of Morris Plan (1980s). Photo #2: In the 1940s, this was Kenyon\'s, "beauty shop...drugs." Photo #3: 2009: Fashion Passion

properties.name: Kidizens!
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Kidizens! after-school program involves 3rd-5th graders building model cities and engaging in civics lessons. The kids govern the city, author a newspaper, open businesses, elect a mayor and council and debate the issues that arise in the city.

properties.name: Kiki's Candy Bar (2005-2008)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The building has since been demolished and in 2010 is being replaced by a new structure. It is also the former home of Palo Alto Joe\'s and Stoa restaurant.

properties.name: King Plaza (1971-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1, #5: City Hall Plaza has often been the site of protests, concerts and other gatherings. It was dedicated King Plaza in January 2008 to honor Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Coretta Scott King. The black and white photo is of a 1980s concert, the color photo from a 2007 anti-war protest. (PAHA Collection) Photo #2, #3, #4: The center of Plaza has changed over time. In 1970 it was a simple fountain. By 1981, we see that it is the sculpture "Filaree" by Gene Flores. By 2007, The plaza now features artist Samuel Yates “portable solar garage," office and headquarters during his twelve-month search for “The Color of Palo Alto.” In the project, Yates photographed every parcel of land in Palo Alto and then derived a common color to represent the city. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Kings Lane (1951-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Kings Lane was originally known as Pluns Court for William Pluns, an early and well-known building contractor. The name was changed in 1951 at the request of some of the residents of Pluns Court who stated that the name was often misspelled. The Pluns family has requested many times that the name be restored, but it never has. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Kingsley at Embarcadero (ca. 1925)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A view of Embarcadero Road at the intersection of Kingsley Avenue looking towards Alma Street. Palo Alto High School is visible down Kingsley Avenue. The undated photograph was taken sometime between 1918 and 1936 when the Embarcadero Underpass was built. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Kirk's Steakburgers (1948-2002)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This is the former location of Kirk\'s Steakburgers which is now located at Town & Country Village. Starbucks now resides at this location.

properties.name: Kirk's Steakburgers (2002-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Kirk\'s is a Palo Alto institution. They were formerly located at 361 S. California Avenue from 1948-2002.

properties.name: Know Knew Books (1988-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Bill Burruss, co-owns the shop with Paul Willitts on California Avenue. In recent years, there has been speculation that they may have to close due to a drop in sales.

properties.name: Ku Klux Klan Emblem (1946)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Local residents awoke on May 31st, 1946 to find a three foot high red-lettered KKK insignia painted in the street at the intersection of Homer and Ramona. Situated in what was then a small black section of town surrounding the AME Zion Church, Police Chief Howard Zink believed that the work was “done by an organization, not pranksters.” The symbol’s unfortunate appearance seemed a possible harbinger of some of the troubles that swirled in the Midpeninsula region in the mid-forties. The height of area Klan activity came later that year, when the Klan burned down the house of John Walker, a black man who had moved into an all-white Dumbarton Oaks neighborhood of Redwood City. But condemnation of the Klan in Palo Alto was swift and strong. Local op-eds asked the police to “arrest and prosecute the Klansmen” and urged local citizens “not to rest until we have found the Klan members living here and taken appropriate action.” A third Times writer warned that “by shutting our eyes to the first ventures of these un-American cowards at whatever level they operate, we leave the way open for activities that undermine our democracy and stain the fine community reputation we are so smug about.”

properties.name: L. Marks General Merchandise
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory L. Marks General Merchandise Store in Mayfield, pre 1900. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: La Morenita Mexican Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This is one of the former locations of St. Michael\'s Alley, which later moved next door and has since moved up the block. St. Mike\'s moved into this location in 1973.

properties.name: La Para Avenue
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This avenue was once an area of strawberry fields. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: LaFosse Music House (1970s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory LaFosse Music House on El Camino in the 1970s.

properties.name: Laning Chateau (1927-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Built by William Staller in 1927 in the Spanish Colonial Revival style. Photo #1: Circa 1927. Photo #2: In 1985, lost in the trees. Photo #3: The Laning Chateau looking over Palo Alto in the 1930s. Photo #4: Soon after opening. Photo #5: In 2008, covered with colorful ivy. Photo #6: Outdoor fountain. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Larry Page House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Property owned by Google co-founder Larry Page.

properties.name: Lawrence Lane (1948-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Lawrence Lane honored black educator, Dr. Paul Lawrence. At the time the street was named he was a graduate student at Stanford. The Friends Service Committee had purchased six acres of land in South Palo Alto with plans for setting up a tract that would serve as a "Laboratory of Interracial Living." This would allows non-Caucasian families the opportunity to find housing in Palo Alto to "develop attitudes of friendliness and understanding among dissimilar groups within our population." In 1948 Lawrence helped the group work out the problems of platting the tract.

properties.name: Layne Court (1957)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  In 1957 Layne Subdivision was the property of Roy and Doris Lane. When the City staff official asked the name of the street on his subdivision map, Roy Layne said he thought the city named the streets. The staff person said, "We do. Would you like it to be named Layne Court?" Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Lee DeForest House (Formerly)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Residence at 913 Emerson Street where Lee deForest and others conducted research in 1912. Palo Alto Historical Association metal sign stands in front of the house. The building was demolished in December 1978. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Leland Manor
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: An aerial shot of Rinconada Park and regions south circa 1941. The neighborhood now known as Leland Manor was just fields. Photo #2: This shot in December, 1959 shows that much had changed in the neighborhoods east of the Community Center in the 1950s. Leland Manor (to the right of the photograph) is a fully developed neighborhood here.

properties.name: Leland Stanford Meets Mayfielders (1886)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1886, Senator Leland Stanford met with local Mayfielders on the corner of California and El Camino (then known as Lincoln and Main) to inform the locals about his big plans for a university in their town. He wanted the entrance gates to the university to be situated on Stanford Avenue near Hanover Street. One catch though --- Stanford wanted the town to go “dry” --- no more alcohol (obviously universities did not have the same reputations as they do today). Mayfield, with its 13 saloons, voted no thanks. Rejected, Stanford turned his eyes north and convinced his friend, Timothy Hopkins of the Southern Pacific Railroad, to buy 700 acres of private property and sell lots. The collection of homes that grew up around the university (originally called University Park) eventually became Palo Alto. It was also the beginning of the end for old Mayfield.

properties.name: Lirio Hall
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A community meeting place for churches, schools, socials, etc. The building collapsed in the 1906 earthquake. (PAHA Collection) The sign in one photograph says "Elementary and Preparatory School."

properties.name: Livingstone Store
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Livingstone store at the Stanford Shopping Center during some reconstruction. Livingstone was one of the original stores at the shopping center, just to the north of Roos Brothers.

properties.name: Location of Herbert Kay Murder (1997)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Perhaps the most jarring of all Palo Alto crimes was the 1997 murder of 38 year old Bert Kay on quiet Gilman Street, just a block and a half from the downtown police station. Since that night, Palo Alto’s sense of security has never really been the same. On the night of June 12th, 1997 all that would come to an end. After putting their two-year old twins to bed, Meg dozed off and Bert set out from his apartment for his nightly “thinking walk.” Meanwhile over in East Palo Alto, six members of a Samoan gang called the True Blue Crips were drinking Mad Dog 20/20, a type of potent wine, and making plans to “jack someone.” They piled into the blue Isuzu Rodeo owned by 20 year old Christian Valdes and headed across the 101. Circling downtown around 10:30pm, they spotted Kay walking down Gilman Street, a typically serene setting that serves as the Saturday morning home for the Palo Alto Farmer’s Market. While Valdes remained in his car around the corner, his five friends snuck up on the unsuspecting scientist. One of the attackers brutally struck Kay in the head, knocking him to the ground. Searching Kay’s pockets, they only found a little girl’s ponytail holder (Kay had actually left his wallet at home). Two of the other gang members then savagely beat Kay while he lay writhing in pain on the pavement. Eventually they dragged Kay behind the bench that stands behind the Laning Chateau Apartments and fled the scene. The injuries to Kay’s face, head and neck were so severe that by the time police arrived just minutes later, Bert Kay was dead.

properties.name: Location of Tree Planted to Honor Policeman Ted Brassinga
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Palo Alto reserve officer Ted Brassinga was shot and killed by a Mountain View police officer during a 1994 training exercise. The incident took place in Gilroy as cops were preparing for World Cup crowds expected later that summer at Stanford Stadium. As 33 year old Brassinga played the "bad guy" in the SWAT-team exercise, he was shot in the chest by a Mountain View officer who accidentally had a bullet in his gun.

properties.name: Lockheed Martin
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Lockheed Martin became one of Stanford Industrial Park\'s (later Stanford Research Park) most important companies. In the photo, the Lockheed Martin plant is in the distance to the left. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Loma Prieta Earthquake at Safeway (1989)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A look down the aisle of the Middlefield Road Safeway in 1989 after it (and customers) are shaken by the earthquake. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Loma Verde Avenue (1940-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Loma Verde means green hill in Spanish. The street was once named College Avenue. A 1907 news article told of a Methodist College Board planning to build a college there. The name was changed to Loma Verde in 1940. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: London House English Tea Room (1969-1973)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Blue Chalk Café across from City Hall helped usher in the after-dark Palo Alto downtown that has thrived since the early 1990s. Pretty much dead after nightfall in the 1970s and \'80s (Baskin-Robbins and Round Table were about the hottest spots around), the downtown area now draws the singles crowds to Blue Chalk, Gordon Biersch, O\'Connell\'s, Fanny & Alexander\'s and the Empire Tap Room. Indeed this historically tee-totaling town which served its first legal cocktail in 1971, is now perhaps the most popular nightlife mecca between San Jose and San Francisco. At the Birge Clark-designed split level (and historically landmarked) building at 630 Ramona, the college-aged crowd shoots pool on blue-felted tables, revel by the gas fireplace, and play darts and shuffleboard. Not that long ago this hot spot for nightlife was the London House English Tea Room (1969-1993), full of women drinking tea. Now the building is loud, extremely crowded and overcome by hip-hop music. In the 1940s, this building was home to the Stanford Upholstering and Furniture Company. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Looking East Down California Ave.
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The view east down California Avenue (then known as Lincoln) circa 1890. This was then the main district in Mayfield --- a city later annexed by Palo Alto. Photo #2: Same view looking down California Avenue, circa 1935. The Mayfield Theatre can be seen to the right.

properties.name: Looking East Down University
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: View looking east down University Avenue in 1906 after the earthquake. Photo #2: Circa 1940. Photo #3: Same view in 1914 with the new electric sign. Photo #4: In 1901 with horse approaching.

properties.name: Looking South at Palo Alto from Above (1960s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A look from above at Palo Alto in the 1960s, with El Palo Alto near the bottom of the photo and the vast parking lots of Stanford Shopping Center to the right. El Camino Real runs along at the center. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Looking South on El Camino Real (1920s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking south down El Camino Real in the 1920s. The Mayfield Bank is on the near corner of California Avenue near the center of the photo. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Los Trancos Woods Road
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Los Trancos is an American misspelling of the Spanish las trancas, meaning cattle bars.

properties.name: Lou Henry Hoover Girl Scout House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory 1120 Hopkins, Palo Alto, CA"In 1922, Service Unit 1 was established as the first Girl Scout Council on the West Coast. Lou Henry Hoover, the wife of President Herbert Hoover, had been active in Girl Scouts on the East Coast and was the president of the National Council of Girl Scouts. She grew up in California, went to San Jose State University (then known as the San Jose Normal School) and then studied geology at Stanford University, where she met her husband. She met Juliette Gordon Low, who founded the Girl Scouts of America, at the end of World War I. When her husband moved the family to Washington D.C., Hoover started her own troop of scouts, which included both white and African American girls — a rare occurence at that time. The City of Palo Alto granted a piece of land for a Girl Scout House to be built within a corner of Rinconada Park adjacent to what is now the Junior Museum and Lucie Stern Center. Lou Henry Hoover and two other members of the Palo Alto Girl Scout Board each donated 00 to build the meetinghouse. Stonemasons built the fireplace from the sandstone of the fallen arch over Stanford’s Palm Drive that had been destroyed in the great 1906 San Francisco earthquake. Building the house became a community affair where local builders, architects, painters, and many others gave their time and their money to complete the project. June of 1926 saw the house dedicated to the Girl Scouts of Palo Alto by Lou Henry Hoover. A display case in the entry hall contains memorabilia of Lou Henry Hoover, including some of her field notebooks and early photographs. It was researched and donated as a Silver Award project by a Palo Alto troop." -Palo Alto Girl Scouts

properties.name: Louis Road
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The name Louis Road is actually a sign maker\'s mistake. The street was actually supposed to be "Lewis Road," named after Charles Lewis Smith, one of the founders of the Palo Alto National Bank. Source: PAHA\'s Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Love Spoken Here (1999-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "In 1999, the Bishop Corporation purchased “Love Spoken Here,” a work by San Francisco sculptor WILLIAM WAREHAM, as a gift to the City of Palo Alto. The bronze ensemble located at 408 S California Avenue, consists of a bench, two chairs, and a table. The work is dedicated to Stanley and Elizabeth “Cordy” Bishop, founders of the California Avenue Pharmacy, a Palo Alto landmark that no longer exists. Many people who enjoy this remarkable installation compare the sculpture to the furniture one sees in a cartoon. William Wareham has many works of public art throughout Northern California. His temporary installation "To Market" was exhibited in Palo Alto’s City Hall Plaza in 2000. The Bishop Corporation commissioned and funded “Love Spoken Here” as a gift to the City of Palo Alto’s Art In Public Places Collection." -Palo Alto Public Art Community

properties.name: Lucie Stern Community Center
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The community center was a gift of Palo Alto\'s "fairy godmother" Lucie Stern. Photo #1: The Community Center in 2008. Photo #2: The Community Center, circa 1940. Photo #3: An outdoor corridor in May of 1939. Photo #4: The Ballroom at the Community Center. Photo #5: The Community Center from above before the construction of the Children\'s Library. Photo #6: Shortly after opening. Photo #7: The same angle again in the 1950s. Photo #8: The Lucie Stern Theatre at the Community Center.

properties.name: Lucie Stern Community Theatre
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "In 2008 the Lucie Stern Community Theatre will celebrate its 75th Anniversary. The Lucie Stern Community Theatre programs are provided by Palo Alto Players, TheatreWorks, and West Bay Opera. Palo Alto Players has been performing in the theatre since it was built in 1933 and recently celebrated their 75th anniversary. West Bay Opera has been performing in the theatre since 1955 and recently celebrated its 50th anniverary. TheatreWorks originated at the theatre in 1970 and is in its 37th season. The group now known as the Palo Alto Players was established in June 1931 as the Palo Alto Community Players. They first performed in the Community House, now Macarthur Park Restaurant, on University Avenue near the train station. Mrs. Lucie Stern was a frequent first-nighter, sitting front row center. The Community House was not an ideal location, however, with its 100 seat limit and the proximity of the train station and tracks. The southbound "Lark" stopped nightly and the fast overnight freight trains ran through town evenings." -Palo Alto City Website Photo #1: Celebrating 20 years of community theater. Photo #2: "A Little Night Music" in 1990. Photo #3: The Lucie Stern Theatre in the late 50s or early 60s. Photo #4: The Palo Alto Players celebrate 25 years. Photo #5: The Palo Alto Players perform "The Madness of George III" in 1995.

properties.name: Lucky's

properties.name: Lucy Evans Baylands Nature Interpretive Cente
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "The Lucy Evans Baylands Nature Interpretive Center is built on pilings at the edge of the salt marsh. A plank walk leads a quarter-mile across the marsh to open water and a panoramic view of San Francisco Bay. The Center offers various programs and activities such as nature walks, animal and fossil workshops for children, an ecology laboratory, and displays of tidelands flora and fauna. Lucy Evans, born in Wyoming in 1903, came to California with her family at the age of two. She graduated from Stanford in 1929, having been elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She taught at Mayfield School for 23 years. Class field trips led to her joining the Audubon Society and exploring the Baylands extensively. A friend has said that "she knew every inch" of them. She fought for the preservation of the Baylands, and her determination earned her the appellation "Baylands Lucy." She died suddenly in 1978. The Baylands Nature Interpretive Center was rededicated to her memory in December 1978." -Palo Alto City Website Photo is of Lucy Evans with schoolchildren in the 1950s. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Lytton Elementary School (1905-1964)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Lytton Elementary School opened in 1905 along Middlefield Road between Lytton and University. It was built for 1,648 and opened with 10 classrooms and an assembly hall. Elizabeth Van Auken began her teaching career at Lytton in 1912, became principal in 1917 and served 36 years in all. The school closed in 1964 and was torn down to build Lytton Gardens senior residence units. Source: Palo Alto: A Centennial History Photo #1: Mrs. Weldegrave and her students in 1924. Photo #2: A sad photograph. Photo #3: Mrs. Bondurant and her students in 1951. Photo #4: The "Milk Squad" with their milk, naturally. Photo #5: Today Lytton Gardens Senior Communities stands on the old school grounds. Photo #6: Kids at the lunch tables. Photo #7: Lytton School front entrance. Photo #8: The massive old school in early days. Photo #9: Mrs. Olive Kaufman and her seven special education students in 1960. Photo #10: A postcard of the "Lytton Avenue School." (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Lytton Plaza
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The legacy of Downtown Palo Alto’s Lytton Plaza is more of the rowdy troublemaker than the educated dissenter. Not to say that Palo Alto has not had its share of both peaceful and enlightened protests. But especially between 1968 and 1972, Lytton Plaza became famous for a series of chaotic riots that symbolized the worst of the youth movement, not the best. The former location of the monumental American Trust Building, the 8,500 square foot plaza was constructed in 1964 by Bart Lytton across the street from his Lytton Savings Bank at Emerson and University. With its brick and cement foundation and modernist rounded concrete bench/plant holders, the plaza always had a somewhat severe appearance. Still, at its inception in 1964, it was clean, well-groomed and a needed pedestrian oasis in an increasingly automobile-centered downtown. But while Lytton intended the plaza for the “use and enjoyment of the people of Palo Alto,” some people’s idea of “enjoyment” was not exactly what Lytton had in mind. Within five years, the plaza had become the favored spot in Palo Alto for both protest and late-night rock concerts. Because it was privately owned, it was not subject to city park regulations, and because it was not fenced, anti-trespass laws did not apply. As a sort of legal “no man’s land,” Lytton Plaza soon became the place to challenge the system in Palo Alto. Note: To be renamed in 2009 and re-landscaped. The older photos are circa 1965 and 1971. (PAHA Collection) Photo #1: Lytton Plaza in 2008 Photo #2: Lytton Plaza circa 1965 Photo #3: The Marten Building stands at the future site of Lytton Plaza in the late 1890s at center, Ledyard Building is to the right. Photo #4: In the very early part of the 20th Century the line of buildings that ran down the corner of Emerson included the AM Trust building and the Ruckert Building. Photo #5: Lytton Plaza in the 1980s looking toward Burger King behind it. Photo #6: A Venceremos rally in the early 1970s. Photo #7: The Bank of Palo Alto in the 1930s. A hotel is next door on Emerson Street. Photo #8: The Bank of Palo Alto soon after opening. Photo #9: The rather imposing American Trust Company Building stood here before Lytton Plaza. Down the street, Home Foundation Savings offers a 4.6% rate. (circa 1960) Photo #10: The new Lytton Plaza opened with water fountain in December, 2009.

properties.name: Manning House (1909-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "The house at 604 Tennyson was originally built by early Stanford math professor Dr. William A. Manning. He and his wife Esther lived here until 1925 when they moved to 649 Alvarado Row on the Stanford campus. They had five children and clearly needed more room than a two-bedroom house, like 604 was at that time, could provide. Dr. Manning (1876-1972) lived to be 95. The house was sold to Vern James, a student of Dr. Manning\'s, who earned his doctorate in 1927. Dr. James taught mathematics for many years at San Jose State. (When they were young, the children of both professors Manning and James slept in an open sleeping porch located where the kitchen is today.) The second story was added in the early 1930s by Dr. James, as was the gabled section to the left. The facade was changed from redwood shingle to clapboard at that time. The shape of the right hand gable, however, is the same. Note the chimney and the position of the front door. Dr. James did most of the work himself, including the digging of a full basement by hand! (See pictures again.) Vern and Edna Chapman James lived here from 1925 until Dr. James\'s death in 1967. There were four children. (Edna James died in 1965). The historic photo shows Edna James and her children at the front door. The James children sold the house to its third owners, John and Ann Palmer. Dr. Palmer was a Stanford urologist, and he put the house on the market after only two years, because he received an offer in 1969 from UC Davis." -PAST Heritage There were some bright children who grew up in this house. Dr. Manning\'s son (still living) is a retired professor of electrical engineering at Stanford, and two of Manning\'s daughters became professional mathematicians in their own right. One of the James daughters was a professor of psychology at the University of Washington for many years. The current owner\'s son holds a Ph.D. in ecology and now works for NOAA. The current owner, who holds a Ph.D. degree himself, finds it interesting that, although realtors call this part of town "Old Palo Alto," this house, along with 299 Tennyson Avenue, is practically the first home south of Embarcadero Road to reach 100 years of age, other than the Gamble House (1902). Almost all the other older homes are either on the Stanford campus or north of Embarcadero Road. It would be more accurate and historically correct to call this area the Seale Addition.

properties.name: Maritime and VOA Station, KFS/KROJ (1921-1999)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "KFS was taken over by the U.S. Navy during World War I to allow communication with U.S. battleships. The station was moved in 1921 to the marsh just east of Palo Alto (the current "antenna farm"), and the San Francisco station was closed in 1927. Around this time the station was also sold to Mackay Cable & Wireless. In July, 1943, a new 50KW transmitter was activated at KFS under the callsign KROJ and provided a relay service for the Voice of America. This service was terminated in 1945 at the end of World War II. "The exact corporate history of the site after WWII is impossible to ascertain, but during the next 30 years it was owned by ITT World Communications (which eventually called the site Palo Alto Radio) and then KFS World Communications. The site still contains an old, unused mailbox with the ITT name on it at the front gate. "ITT had transferred much of the Palo Alto site to the city in 1977 and held an easement for their continued operation. In January 1994, Palo Alto bought the easement from KFS for 70,000, thus securing one of the last remaining large pieces of the baylands not under the city\'s control. There are currently no plans to renovate or demolish the site, although in 1994 there were some rumors about turning the large radio building into a youth hostel. Obviously this hasn\'t happened yet. "In 1995, the U.S. Coast Guard officially stopped listening for Morse Code distress calls. KFS sold the Half Moon Bay facility to Globe Wireless, a company specializing in maritime communications (including email and telefax) using satellite and HF communications. With the newly available communications technology, they decommissioned all Morse Code transmissions. The last commercial radiotelegraph transmission in North America was made from the Palo Alto site at 2359 UTC on July 12, 1999. The final words transmitted by KFS? "What hath God wrought"."

The building was later bought by Safeway before Maximart moved in and ran it under the name Sutter Packing. Hence the distinctive architecture.

properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Bank building on the corner of Main Street and Lincoln Street (now El Camino and California) in 1930. A building housing the post office is located behind the bank. Photo #2: Circa 1915 Photo #3: 2007 Photo #4: Mr. Charles Ellet was town treasurer and cashier of the Mayfield Bank (which later became the Stanford Bank of Palo Alto and Mayfield) Photo #5: The same corner, circa 1980. Three U.S. flags (one higher than the other two) stand on the center island. Photo #6: Inside the Mayfield Bank. Photo #7: At the teller window. The sign says "Paying and Receiving." Photo #8: By the late 1920s it was a Bank of America. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Mayfield Brewery (1868-1918)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "The Mayfield Brewery stood at the corner of what is now California Avenue and Birch Street in Palo Alto. The brewery operated from 1868 to sometime just before prohibition (1920). They brewed steam beer, a very common style in California at the time, and delivered the beer in kegs to local saloons. The brewery operated even when Mayfield became a dry town in 1905 and closed all its saloons. Prohibition finally shut down the brewery sometime just before 1920." -Thomas Skibo Christopher Ducker, proprieter of the Mayfield Brewery was the only member of the town\'s new board of trustees to vote against Mayfield going dry in 1904. By a thin margin and with much debate, the board later voted to grant The Mayfield Brewery a special wholesale license to continue operating. Photo #1: A beautiful painting of the Brewery. Photo #2: The building that now stands at the corner of Birch and California. Photo #3: The Mayfield Brewery

properties.name: Mayfield Mural

properties.name: Mayfield Snowstorm (1887)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory On the night of February 4th, 1887, Mayfield was hit by 6 inches of snow. This photo was taken about 4:30 pm on the 5th, by which much of it had melted. San Francisco got over a foot of snow that day.

properties.name: Mayview Avenue (1931-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The 1931 Mayview Homesites subdivsion, from which the street derived its name, originally had small homes and large lots to allow the dwellers to farm and raise chickens. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Middlefield Road (1878-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Middlefield Road was originally called el Camino de en Medio, or the middle road, by the early Spanish colonists. In late 1851, a fence, known as "Steinberger\'s Fence" had been built along the northeast side of the road in present-day Menlo Park and Atherton, marking the new border of marshland. By 1853, the fence was referred to as the Middle Field fence. Thereafter, the name was often transferred to the old road. It became the official designation by an act of the State Legislature in 1878. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Military Way was once the entryway leading to the California Military Academy which for several years occupied the old Barron mansion. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The street is called Military Way because it once led to the California Military Academy which formerly occupied the Barron Mansion. Source: PAHA\'s Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Miller Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The north side of University Avenue in the 1920s. The Stanford Theatre is at right and the Miller Building to the left. The Sun-Kist Market and Deli occupies the bottom floor of the Miller Building. Photo #2: Quite a bit of foot traffic along University Avenue on this day in the 1920s. The Sun-Kist Market and Deli is downstairs and the University Creamery is next door. Photo #3: Sushi Tomo is on this corner in 2009.

properties.name: Mills the Florist
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Mills the Florist has been family-owned and operated since 1903. In late 2006, Mills the Florist had to share its space with a modern trend with an ancient past --- the hookah bar. While the florist still occupies a small University Avenue alcove, the new Sehbali Café has taken over most of the 1902-built structure. In the back, hookahs are ready to smoke along with interesting and original coffees and chais straight from India. Photo #1: 2008 Photo #2: 1980s Photo #3: Circa, 1985. Photo #4: 1974. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Mills the Florist (1903)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Frank R. Mills was an English immigrant who purchased properties along San Francisquito Creek. Mills built greenhouses in his backyard and started selling flowers, shrubbery and trees. Besides local demand, over the years Mills the Florist has also received orders from celebrities like President Herbert Hoover, Senator Edward Kennedy and comedian Jerry Lewis." -Palo Alto Weekly 2/16/01

properties.name: Ming Toy's
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Stores from 1985 include a travel agency and a reading center. Photo #2: Ming Toy\'s was just west of the Hotel President along with a fur store, "shoe rebuilding" and a beauty salon. Circa 1925.

properties.name: Ming's Chinese Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Ming\'s was located on El Camino Real at Vista Road until 1967. Ming\'s opened in Palo Alto in 1956. Originally on El Camino Real across from Stanford University, it was a subsidiary of Johnny Kan\'s famed Chinatown eatery. Many of the original recipes, such as Ming\'s beef, Chinese chicken salad and Peking duck, survive to this day. Source: Ming\'s

properties.name: Miramonte Avenue (1981)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A look down Miramonte Avenue in 1981. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Mitchell Lane
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The name of this street honors Lydia Mitchell, longtime director of the Palo Alto chapter of the American Red Cross next door. It was so named in 1947. Source: PAHA\'s Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Mitchell Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Mitchell Park was seen as showcase of innovative recreational concepts when it first opened --- a park of "things to do." The middle photo is of former Stanford professor and PA Mayor Dr. J.P. Mitchell at the opening of Mitchell Park, April 1957. He was known as "Mr. Palo Alto" to many. After a great deal of vandalism to the park in the 1970s, Mitchell Park has had a resurgence, although it has acquired a more modest number of activities within.

properties.name: Mitchell Park Public Library
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Mitchell Park Library on Middlefield Road in South Palo Alto is a small but extremely busy branch of the Palo Alto library system. It opened on July 19, 1958 two years after the bond issue of 00,000 was passed for its construction and the construction of the Main Library. The new Mitchell Park Library and Community Center -- by far the most ambitious element of Palo Alto\'s 6 million effort to rebuild its libraries -- is slated to be completed in the spring or summer of 2012. Source: Palo Alto Weekly

properties.name: Mockingbird Lane (1972-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A property owner on this hill bestowed the name "Mockingbird Hill" on his residence in the 1950s when that species of bird was first noted in the area. In 1972 the area was subdivided and called by the same name. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Mollie Stone's
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This location of Mollie Stone\'s was formerly part of the Palo Alto Co-op chain. The first Co-Op was founded in 1935 and the last store closed in 2001. This store on California Avenue has been credited as being one of the state\'s first modern grocery stores. Photo #1: The Co-Op in the 1960s. Photo #2: In the 1980s. Photo #3: Inside the store. Photo #4: Mollie Stone\'s singing farm. Photo #5: Outside Photo #6: High above California Avenue in 1948. The Co-Op is to the right. Notice how undeveloped the street is compared to University Avenue in those years. (PAHA Collection)
