properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory At far left is Morey\'s Smoke Shop, circa 1930. At center is Roos Brothers (temporarily displaced) and at far right is Wilson\'s. A sign indicates that Morey\'s sells Dunhill\'s Pipes. Until 2009 this was the home of Elbe Restaurant, which served German and European cuisine, but is being converted into a sports bar adjoining Rudy\'s Pub.

properties.name: Morgan Oyster Company
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1926 the Palo Alto tidal marshlands and water were the location of the Morgan Oyster Company.

properties.name: Morris Refrigeration Service
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Mullen's Hall
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Mullen\'s Hall burned down in 1927. This photo is from much earlier in the century and shows that Mullen\'s was selling stagecoaches and buggies. Photo #2: Mullen & Harms in 1899, a blacksmithing and horseshoeing business in those days. Photo #3: Theatre curtain, Mullen\'s Hall, 1909.

properties.name: Municipal Water and Light Plant
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Exterior view of the municipal power plant on Newell Road with plowed field in foreground. Image was taken before 1914. Photo #2: City water pumping plant with supply of firewood in front and twin elevated water tanks in the rear. (1899)

properties.name: Museum of American Heritage (1990-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory 351 Homer Ave, Palo Alto, CAThe Museum of American Heritage (known locally as MOAH), it collects, preserve and display historic objects and inventions that illustrate the effects and influence of innovation. It began with the extensive collection of Frank Livermore and was founded in 1990. Permanent exhibits include a kitchen of the 1920s - 30s, an early 20th Century general store and a print shop of the 1920s - 30s. Photos are from 1991 and 1990. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Near Lincoln at Bryant (Ca. 1941)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Shot from lane just down the street.

properties.name: Newell House (1866-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Part of the old Newell House, still located at 1456 Edgewood Drive, dates back to 1866. The updated carriage house and "cow barn" once part of the estate, remain next door at 1450.

properties.name: Newell Road (1864-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Newell Place and Newell Road were named for Dr. William A. Newell, a prominent physician in San Francisco, who bought 47 acres from Henry Seale in 1864 for a country estate.

properties.name: Newell at Embarcadero (ca. 1970)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Kids crossing Embarcadero Road on their bikes, circa 1970. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Newsrack Rows (1996)
properties.description: Posted by PaloaltohistoryNewsracks took a beating in 1996 in Palo Alto---quite literally. Indeed, there had been so many old beat-up newsracks in front of the Downtown Post Office that some council members said it was safety hazard---it was hard to get up onto the sidewalk in an emergency. 33 newsracks had lined up in a row and there were no city ordinances to say that they couldn\'t. But what really had folks hot and bothered was the content of some of those newsracks. Adult weeklies with such...er..offbeat titles as Yank, often displayed partially naked women on the covers---in full view of children or anyone else on their way to mail a letter. In 1996, the Council unanimously approved shields for the racks that covered the bottom two-thirds of the magazine. But they would only go so far down that constitutionally protected road---the Council voted down an amendment to also require shields for lewd material in store windows that could be viewed from the outside. Many council members believed that such an ordinance could be dragged into court on first amendment grounds. In 1997, the council did some further housekeeping---regulating newsrack proliferation across the city. The city instituted new, modular racks to be located in specific spots throughout downtown. They also cut the total number of newspaper racks, thereby killing newsrack row.

properties.name: Nixon Elementary School (1970-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Lucile Nixon Elementary School opened in 1970 and was named after Lucille (“Luchi”) Nixon, who served as consultant for curriculum and instruction for the elementary grades of the Palo Alto Unified School District. She died in 1963. The modernist grounds are the largest of any PAUSD elementary school. The staff photo is from the 1971-72 school year. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Nola's Restaurant and Bar (1996-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: Nola\'s is a New Orleans style restaurant that opened at this location in 1996. Photo #2: The building in 1985 when it was Pearl\'s. It was built in 1938. Photo #3:: Pearl\'s Oyster Bar in the Ramona Architectural District.

properties.name: Nora's Cafe (2003-2008)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Just five days before Christmas, a Santa Clara County deputy sheriff had to walk customers, some in the midst of their meals, out of Nora\'s Cafe at 201 South California Ave. to lock the doors and legally evict the café\'s owners, Nora and Patrick Joulain, who had been unable to pay their rent for several months. The French bistro and crepes restaurant opened in October 2003." -Palo Alto Weekly 1/31/07 Former home to In 2009, it is Bistro Basia. Also home to California Crepes, Cafe Maremonti, The Flying Baguette and Chez Sophie.

properties.name: Nordstrom (1984-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Nordstrum is located across Arboretum Road. It opened in 1984. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: North County Courthouse (1962-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The North County Courthouse was completed in 1962. Photo #1: 2008 Photo #2: The courthouse as seen from above, circa mid 1960s. California Avenue runs along the right side of the photo and the Oregon Expressway is the wide road in the bottom left continuing out to its intersection with El Camino Real as Page Mill Road. The developing Stanford Industrial Park can be seen beyond. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: North Palm Service Station (1940)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The North Palm Service Station in 1940 at the corner of Forest and Emerson. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Nortree Hall
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This location originally housed a rather historic building---Nortree Hall. This was Palo Alto\'s first meeting hall and community center and many of the early debates concerning the shaping and vision of the city took place here. In 1921 came Liddicoat\'s---a grocery store (with requisite soda fountain) that lasted until 1977. That year Liddicoat\'s was converted into a kind of mini restaurant mall featuring such international flavors as the Bon Appetit Mediterranean food counter, Dimples & Company Barbecue and the brainchild of a 20 year old entrepreneur named Debbi Fields---Mrs. Fields Chocolate Chippery, which has since become a must in seemingly every mall food court in America. But time marches on. In 1990, the county health department cracked down on the abundance of rats, cockroaches, and electrical problems at Liddicoat\'s. The owners cleaned things up and spent 50,000 on improvements but, too little, too late---by then the property owners were already on the lookout for a new tenant. Photo #1: The Liddicoat\'s food court in the 1980s. Photo #2: Z Gallerie closed its doors in 2009. Photo #3: Old Nortree Hall Photo #4: The Liddicoat\'s food court from outside in 1983. Photo #5: Mrs. Field\'s Chocolate Chippery in 1977, the first store leading to a nationwide company. Photo #6: Debbi Fields was a young mother with no business experience when she launched Mrs. Field\'s Cookies in 1977. Photo #7: Nortree Hall, unbounded on either side. This was the site of the first ever Board of Trustees meeting in 1894, the precursor to the city council.

properties.name: Nouveau Trattoria Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory French-Italian cuisine. (ca. 1993)

properties.name: Nude in Steel
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Nude In Steel" by artist HANS WEHRLI is located at the Main Library on 1213 Newell Road. Commissioned by the Public Art Commission and funded by the City of Palo, the piece was purchased in commemoration of the 1976 Bicentennial celebration. -Palo Alto City Website

properties.name: Oak Creek Apartments (1980)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A view of the Oak Creek Apartments in 1980 and in 2008. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Oak Tree at Sherman & Park (1890)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A photo from May 21st, 1890 of the oak tree at Sherman and Third Street (now known as Park).

properties.name: Oddfellow's Building (1890-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The oldest building still standing from the old town of Mayfield. It dates back to the year 1890, although it has been remodeled several times. Video Link: Steve Staiger discusses the early history of Mayfield: http://blip.tv/file/2399604

properties.name: Ohlone Elementary School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Formerly named Elizabeth Van Auken Elementary School and for one brief year, went by the name Los Ninos. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Old Flagpole at The Circle
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: Before the overpass was built the flagpole stood just to the north of University Avenue. It was later moved to the front of the Community Center down the street. Photo #2: Before the University Avenue Overpass was built, the northside of the Circle had an island with trees and bushes. Photo #3: The flagpole dedication ceremony in 1908. Photo #4: Putting up the old flagpole in 1908. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Old Judge Buck Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Building housed Dr. Orwitz Dentists. On the right is American Trust Company. To the left is Lentos Shoe Repair shop and the Walk- Over Shoe Store. Automobiles are parked diagonally at the curb. Photo from 1937. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Oregon Avenue (until 1962)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Tiny Oregon Avenue was overwhelmed in the late 1950s and early \'60s by commuters headed to Stanford Industrial Park and points beyond. The road was widened and became the Oregon Expressway, but not before controversy interceded.

properties.name: Oregon Expressway
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The expansion of the Oregon Expressway in 1962 was one of the first major political issues to pit the Establishment forces of the city against the up and coming "Residentialists." While the expressway was eventually built, the objections of residents resulted in a less intrusive road upon local neighborhoods.

properties.name: Oregon Expressway Underpass (1957-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The underpass opened in 1957 in an attempt by the city to deal with increasing traffic problems caused by growth of residential areas and industry . In the Flood of 1998, one driver nearly drowned as this spot filled up with water. Another photo from the 1980s shows how the roadway fills up during flooding here.

properties.name: Oregon Expressway near West Bayshore (ca. 1965)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A look west on the Oregon Expressway in the 1960s. A sign welcomes drivers into the city to the right. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Oregon and Middlefield (1935)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking north from just south of Oregon Avenue on Middlefield Road in 1935.

properties.name: Original City Hall (1907-1953)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: A truck is parked at the curb next to the City Hall on Ramona Street in 1922. Photo #2: Palo Alto\'s first City Hall, built in 1907. Photo #3: The Fire Department occupied the right quarter of the building. A fire engine is parked in the doorway. The windows of the building have awnings. Photo #4: Exterior view of City Hall with flagpole and fire bell tower on the roof. This photograph was taken before the second story was added in 1922. Photo #5: Moving out of the old City Hall in 1953 and heading for Newell Road.

properties.name: Original First Methodist Church (1896)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The original First Methodist Church of Palo Alto as seen in 1896. This church as known to many as "The Redwood Church."

properties.name: Original Mrs. Field's Chocolate Chippery
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The now world-famous Mrs. Fields got her start in Palo Alto\'s Liddicoat\'s Food Court in 1977.

properties.name: Original PA High School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Early PA resident Anna Zschokke actually mortgaged her house, bought a lot herself, hired a contractor and built a three room schoolhouse to serve as a working, if only temporary, high school.

properties.name: Original Palo Alto Co-Op Location
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The original location of the Palo Alto Co-Op was here on Bryant Street where a parking garage now stands. The Palo Alto Co-op Market was founded in 1935, at a time when buying food staples in bulk wasn’t just a way to save a few bucks, it was a way to survive. At the height of the depression, 15 original co-opters joined together and bought a case of corn --- a group that would makeup the early foundation of what would become the Palo Alto Co-op Market.

properties.name: Original St. Michael's Alley (1959-1966)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Opening at 436 University Avenue on April 1st, 1959, owner and former political pollster Vernon Gates was looking to capture the spirit of the European cafes that he had known during his studies at the University of Innsbruck in Austria (St. Michael’s Alley is actually the London street where many of the first English cafes opened in the 17th Century). Palo Alto’s Alley was a modest establishment, about 90 x 30 feet with a high ceiling and service bar in the back. It had a dark, woodsy atmosphere, a piano painted speckled green against a side wall, and no bandstand. The atmosphere was cozy and informal. As jazz musician Dick Fregulia remembers, “A piano player could literally play with one hand on the keys and the other hand reaching for a coffee cup on one of the adjacent tables.” There were performances of all types --- folk singers, jazz bands, staged plays, poetry readings. And while it wasn’t obvious at the time, the place was becoming a proving grounds for many rising stars. Paly high schooler Joan Baez, members of Jefferson Airplane and Jerry Garcia and the members of the early incarnations of the Grateful Dead all played there. Bob Hunter even washed dishes in the kitchen for a while. It was a credit to Gates that such a creative atmosphere could thrive at St. Mike’s --- especially in a town as mainstream as Palo Alto in those days. From the beginning, the amateur watercolor artist and poetry writer pushed his employees to dance, paint and play music. He saw St. Mike’s as a “bohemian establishment in a sea of Republicans.” And as such, it soon began attracting counterculture types from all over the Peninsula. Photo #1: Greg Brown\'s painting of a nun flying a paper airplane which is on the second floor outside. Photo #2: 2009, Peet\'s Coffee & Tea Photo #3, #5: Folklorico Importer, 1980s...going out of business. Photo #4: Vernon Gates.

properties.name: Original Varsity Theatre
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Across the street from Starbucks is the ambient-rich University Café. Bearing multiple personalities, this location is juice and coffee bar by morning, caters to the lunch crowd at midday and becomes a romantic sit-down restaurant at night --- no laptops allowed. Open since 1994, the cafe\'s popularity seems to assure its remaining a part of University Avenue\'s scenery for some time. Photo #2: Bryant\'s in the 1940s. Photo #3: The original Varsity Theatre, circa 1917, is on the right of the photo. Photo #4: The final show at the original Varsity Theatre was "Grounds for Divorce" on July 6th, 1927.

properties.name: Original location of Wesley Church (1873-1903)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory At the time it was known as Mayfield Methodist Episcopal Church. For the story go here: www.paloaltohistory.com/wesley.html

properties.name: Ortega School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This housing development is the former location of the Ortega Elementary School. After the school\'s closing, it was the location of the Jewish Community Center from 1976-1983. Photo #1: The Ortega School in its final year.

properties.name: Oshman Family Jewish Community Center (2009-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This is the new home for the Jewish Community Center, which was located at the former site of Terman Middle School until 2001 when the school re-opened.

properties.name: Osteria Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Tiny Osteria Restaurant is in this corner location on the bottom floor of the Cardinal Hotel. This was once the recruiting office for the U.S. Army.

properties.name: Outdoor Christmas decoration (1984)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Nativity scene at 280 El Dorado Street in 1984. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: PA Downtown Post Office
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Presenting his blueprints for Palo Alto’s post office to the nation’s postmaster general in Washington, Palo Alto architect Birge Clark was ridiculed. As long-time employee and associate Joseph Ehrlich tells the story, “The postmaster pushed them away and said, ‘Don’t you know what a U.S. post office looks like? We expect a stately building with neo-Romanesque columns showing the power of the federal government. I cannot approve this design.’…Birge responded, ‘Ok, but I don’t think the President and First Lady are going to be pleased with the design change.’” After revealing that the Hoovers had already approved the plans while Clark was breakfasting with his old friends that morning, the postmaster had a sudden change of heart and approved every blueprint in front of him." Video of Gail Woolley discussing the Post Office\'s history: http://blip.tv/file/2525923 Photo #1: The Post Office in 1985. Not the Times-Tribune box. Photo #2: Birge Clark, the post office\'s architect. Photo #3: Numerous mailmen are assembled on their specially fitted bicycles with attached boxes on front in the rear parking lot. Photo #4: Construction in 1932-33 Photo #5: The Post Office circa 1941. Photo #6: Waiting in line. Photo #7: Circa 1950. Photo #8:The Post Office in 2008. Photo #9: The future site of the Palo Alto Downtown Post Office in 1930. Photo #10: A mail drop inside the downtown post office. Slots are labeled Redwood City, Menlo Park, San Jose. Another sign points to income tax forms and information in the basement, entrance on Waverley Street. Photo #11: The R-2 mailbox on Hamilton with Greg Brown\'s mural behind. Photo #12: The future home of the post office in 1932. A link to a 360 degree panorama of the post office corner in 1996: http://www.virtualparks.org/scenes/ZgdAiohtXg6NAtk1J3thyIQ.html

properties.name: Pacific Art League (1921-1965)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Pacific Art League (1965-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Built in 1926, this building was originally Winsor\'s Cabinet Shop. The exterior design combines elements of Spanish Colonial Revival, Mission Revival and Craftsman styles. The Pacific Art League bought the building in 1965. "The Pacific Art League of Palo Alto was founded in 1921 as the Palo Alto Art Club by a widely talented group of people who recognized a need to meet other artists, to work together, and to discuss and critique each other\'s works." Source: The Pacific Art League Photo #1: 2008 Photo #2: Circa 1927 Photo #3: Circa 1990 Photo #4: Circa 1960...you can see the building in all its castle-like glory. Photo #5: Winsor\'s Cabinet Shop circa 1960. Note the parking meters and weeds, no longer seen much in downtown Palo Alto. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palm Drive at Stanford Gates (1931)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Stanford Gates at Palm Drive as seen from the top of the Palo Alto flagpole in 1931. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Airport
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In the early \'30s, city officials decided to locate the new airport out at the Baylands (the old one had been at College Terrace). While the airport closed during World War II, it opened again in 1946 with two all-weather strips. One strip was eventually moved to make way for the golf course and later the county line was adjusted to put the entire airport within Santa Clara County --- they now runs the airport. Federal air controllers have operated its tower since 1967. While the airport remains quite busy, noise problems have led to city officials opposition to a second runway. Source: Palo Alto: A Centennial History

properties.name: Palo Alto Airport (1928-1935)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Palo Alto School of Aviation opened in 1928 near the corner of Stanford Avenue and El Camino, complete with two hangars, a ground school and a strip of grass for a runway. College Terrace residents complained about the noise and the air enthusiasts soon headed for a new airport in the Baylands.

properties.name: Palo Alto Airport Control Tower
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Palo Alto Airport Runway
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Palo Alto Bicycles (1973-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: The old Palo Alto Bicycle Shop, circa 1985. Notice the diagonal parking on one side of University and not the other. The store was founded in 1930 and moved to this location in 1973. Photo #2: The Palo Alto Bicycle Shop Catalog in 1976. Photo #3: Palo Alto Bicycles is still there, but in a new building with a more modern looking logo. Photo #4: Three-time Tour de France winner Greg LeMond was a member of the Palo Alto Bicycles/Avocet racing team when he won the Junior World Championship in 1979. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Bowl (1954-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Fiesta Lanes was built in 1954. Later renamed Palo Alto Bowl, the lanes have been owned by former ‘50s bowling star Rex Golobic and his family for the past two decades. Over the years, the Golobics have ridden the sport’s waves of popularity as bowling nearly went bust and then made a comeback in recent years. The plethora of entertainment choices lured away bowlers in the lean years, but lately in these parts, dot-commers have taken to the lanes looking for an activity to get away from the monotony of their computer screens. And Palo Alto Bowl managed to find new life with casual bowlers as they perfected such promotions as “Thirsty Thursday,” “College Night” and the decidedly manic “Karaoke Glow” bowling---a combination of singing and laser lights that appeals to teens and college kids, if not to the bowling purist. Photos #1, #5: 2007 Photo #2, 3, 4: Ca. 1970 (with the Rythem Room next door) Photo #5: Open for business. Photo #6: Going for a strike (1980s).

properties.name: Palo Alto Boy Scouts
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photos of the Palo Alto Boy Scouts through the years. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Bread Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Built in 1925. "Bakery delivery trucks would back into the building through the garage doors in the front of this commercial bakery and load bread from the racks that still exist at the rear of 212 Homer Avenue." Source: Walking Homer Avenue Photo #1: Janitorial Supplies was located here in 1985.

properties.name: Palo Alto Buddhist Temple (1914-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Palo Alto Buddhist Temple is at 2751 Louis Road. It has a congregation of 300 families.

properties.name: Palo Alto Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Palo Alto Central Condominiums (1984-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The condos were completed in 1984. Previously, this was the site of the old Mayfield Water Tower. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Chamber of Commerce
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: 122-136 Hamilton Avenue in 1985 when it was the home of the Stevens Printing Company. Photo #2: The Palo Alto Chamber of Commerce formerly had offices at 325 Forest in the Laning Chateau. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Church of Christ (1961-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Church was founded in 1961 and their initial building was hand-built by members. According to their website the "congregation was born from a desire to meet the needs of Stanford students and others living in what is now called the Silicon Valley." The first photo is of Doug Qualls addressing the membership in 1986.

properties.name: Palo Alto City Hall
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory City Hall is a decidedly modernist structure that was built in 1969-1971. The outer overhang and modernist statue have since been removed. A 360 degree panorama of City Hall and surroundings in 1996: http://www.virtualparks.org/scenes/ZtOHmz8Rzwy84ATEs59NK1Q.html (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Co-Op Market
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In the 1940s, this second Co-op storefront followed the original at 443 Bryant Street.

properties.name: Palo Alto Commons
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  An assisted living complex on El Camino Way.

properties.name: Palo Alto Drive-In (1947-1973)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  the Peninsula Drive-In Theatre opened off old Bayshore Highway in 1947. An ad running in the Palo Alto Times beckoned viewers to “see the stars --- under the stars” in promoting the grand opening week’s double feature --- teenage Shirley Temple’s “Kiss and Tell” and a feature length Disney cartoon, “Make Mine Music.” The Peninsula Drive-In (it later became the “Palo Alto Drive-In”) consisted of a 70 foot screen --- said to be the largest in the western states at the time --- a snack bar, central projection house, and semi-circular ramp with the capacity to hold 750 cars. And the requisite small speakers could be hung inside the car (a PA announcement after the show urgently reminded viewers to put the speakers back in the receptacle box before driving off). Indeed, at a cost of just 60 cents per adult, 14 cents per child and “no charge for your car,” the drive-in was one of Palo Alto’s most economical nights out.

properties.name: Palo Alto Duck Pond
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This duck pond was originally built as a swimming pool for kids, but due to siltation problems it was converted to a bird refuge. Photo #1 from 2008 Photo #2: Before it became the Duck Pond Photo #3 Ca. 1965 Photo #4 circa 1936 Photo #5: From 1943 from above Photo #6: Before the ducks arrived Photo #7: A boy and his mother feed the ducks. The Sea Scout building is in the background. (1960s) Photo #8: Boys sail boats in the pond in its very early days. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Elks
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks has been donating to charities, providing college scholarships and giving back to the community for more than 80 years in Palo Alto --- but sadly the state of the fraternal organization these days may best be symbolized by an empty parking lot. Standing at 4249 El Camino Real in South Palo Alto, the lonely and somewhat somber wood-paneled headquarters of the Palo Alto Elks is set back from the main street behind a two acre swath of empty asphalt parking lot. There was a time when such a plethora of space was needed --- the Elks grew by leaps and bounds to a peak of about 3,700 members in the 1970s. But in the last three decades, the Elks, like other fraternal organizations around the nation, have seen their membership shrink rapidly. Now comprised of less than 800 members, the average Elk is said to be over 70 years old. Facing possible extinction, the Elks are now proposing a bold plan to try to regain their stride. The photos of the Elks lodge are from 1973 and 2007. Included are also an artist\'s rendering of the new Elks Lodge and a photo of some Elk Club members in 1942. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Fire Department (1903-1907)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Palo Alto Fire Station 3
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This fire station was nearly the home of the Foreign Friends statue when protectors were looking for a home for the doomed gift. Photo #1: In 2008, a fire truck on display. Photo #2: From across Newell Road. Photo #3: With two trucks circa 1935.

properties.name: Palo Alto Golf Course (1956-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Palo Alto Golf Course opened in 1956 and is located east of Highway 101 at 1875 Embarcadero Road in Palo Alto.

properties.name: Palo Alto High School  (1909-1918)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1 Palo Alto High School in 1909. Photo #2: Channing Avenue, the center of education in Palo Alto in the early 20th Century. The elementary school is on the left and the high school on the right. Photo #3: The high school during winter time. Video Link of Historian Steve Staiger discussing early Palo Alto schools: http://blip.tv/file/2591527

properties.name: Palo Alto High School (1918-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Palo Alto High School (sometimes known as Paly) opened in 1918 at the corner of Embarcadero and El Camino Real. Photo #1: The school tower in the 1920s. Photo #2: A gathered crowd of students in the 1980s. Photo #3: The school tower on a postcard. Photo #4: Graduation ceremony. Photo #5: The class of 1923. Photo #6: Paly from above. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Hospital (1932-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: A postcard of the hospital in the 1950s. Photo #2: The new Palo Alto Hospital shortly after it opened in 1932. Photo #3: In the 1980s.

properties.name: Palo Alto Host Lions Club (1927-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "The Palo Alto Host Lions Club is a proactive civic organization that has helped the people of Palo Alto and nearby communities since 1927. In 1967, they organized and sponsored the first Palo Alto Concours D\'Elegance, a classic car show which they use to raise money to help their community." -Palo Alto Lions Website The third photo is from the Concours D\'Elegance in 1985. Meetings are held at the University Club on Miranda. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Hotel
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The old Palo Alto Hotel on the corner of Lytton and Alma. It was torn down in 1942 just after the new train station was built across the street. Photo #1:Ca. 1910s or 20s Photo #2: The same corner in 1985. Photo #3: Ca. 1941 just before its demise. It appears to be abandoned. Photo #4: Circa 1905. Photo #5: S.G. Voorhees has his name on the sign. Photo #6: The old hotel, no longer. (1942) Photo #7: Inside the Greyhound Bus Terminal. There are reduced fares to Portland and Seattle. Photo #8: Passengers getting onto a Greyhound Bus when this location was a bus terminal. Photo #9: A9.com, the occupant in 2009. Photo #10: The hotel to the right of the photo behind the newly opened train station (ca. 1940s). Photo #11: The old Greyhound bus terminal. Photo #12: A woman waits for a greyhound bus at the Palo Alto terminal. Note the enclosed-style phone booth to the right. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Hotel on High Street
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Palo Alto Hotel was for many years a favored place for low income residents. Rent was less than 000 monthly. It is being remodeled in 2008 as a fancier boutique hotel. Perhaps a sign of changing times downtown. The black and white photo is from 1965. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Humane Society (1937-1972)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Palo Alto Humane Society’s long history dates back to old Mrs. B.C. Merriman, which as legend has it, once rode the Palo Alto streets whip in hand, ready to teach a lesson to any driver she saw mistreating his horse. The Society’s early membership roles included Stanford’s first president, David Starr Jordan and Mrs. Jane Stanford herself, both of who helped push for the city’s first horse watering trough in the days before automobiles. But it wasn’t really until 1924 that the PAHS found its voice. That year Police Chief C.F. Noble issued a crackdown on dogs roaming the streets without licenses. Playing the villain to a tee, Noble hired a man named “Dick the Dogcatcher” to enforce justice. Soon the papers were full of letters from readers complaining about maimed dogs that had been swiped from their home yards and porches. One man wrote in to the Palo Alto Times complaining that his dog had never been the same after it was impounded and that it had become a “wild-eyed creature with deep bites about the head and body.” There was also some history of the local police operating with a “shoot on site” policy for strays. Clearly, there was a need for the Humane Society to help safeguard the city’s pets and strays from this rather overzealous police force. But the PAHS had little money and no land on which to construct a shelter. Enter, Mrs. Frank Thomas (as she was always referred to in the papers of the day), a Middlefield Road resident who was known for taking in as many stray pets as her home and husband would allow. Before long, the PAHS had set up kennels in her yard and acquired her services to take care of the animals being rounded up all over the city. And although it was supposed to be just a temporary arrangement, Mrs. Thomas wound up donating her home and time for more than two years before the city spent 000 to build a makeshift pound. This location is now home to the Sheraton Hotel and was formerly home to a Holiday Inn. Photo #1:Former PAHS president Gerald Damadge inquires after a cat. Photo #2: The cages inside. Photo #3: Circa 1945 Photo #4: Feeding the dogs in their cages. Photo #5: The Hyatt Palo Alto built in the same location, circa 1990. Photo #6: The Palo Alto Sheraton in 2007. Photo #7:The Humane Society building shortly before closing. Photo #8: The animal shelter with Alma Street behind it.

properties.name: Palo Alto Jazz Festival
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Palo Alto Jazz Festival was an annual event in the 1980s, beginning with the first festival in 1986. It was held at the Baylands Athletic Center. While the Palo Alto Jazz Festival is no more, local jazz enthusiasts have the Stanford Jazz Festival each year. Photo #1: A band plays at the 4th annual Jazz Festival in 1989. Photo #2: The second Jazz Festival, sponsored by Michelob. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Landfill and Composting Facility
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photos of the Palo Alto Dump in the 1980s, 1990s and 2000s. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Lawn Bowls Club (1935-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Lawn Bowls Club: Ginny Arnott had loved to bowl when she lived in San Francisco and played on the green that her friend John McLaren had built when constructing Golden Gate Park. With an OK from the city, Arnott convinced McLaren to build a Palo Alto version, which was constructed by Depression-era Civil Works Administration laborers in 1934. The Club opened on March 10th, 1935 with welcoming speeches by Arnott (who was elected the first Club President), McLaren and Mayor Earl C. Thomas. This is also the former site of the Peninsula Hospital from 1910-1934.

properties.name: Palo Alto Little League
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Palo Alto Little League began in 1951 at El Camino Park. In its second year, 1952, the current Little League stadium was built. It\'s still in use fifty-five years later. Palo Alto\'s Little League Stadium was patterned after neighboring Stanford University\'s legendary Sunken Diamond baseball field, and it has endured almost as long as its model. Not surprisingly, when I stand on the pitcher\'s mound today and look toward the outfield, the view is decidedly different from those first days. Back then, beyond the outfield fence were orchards and fields filled with carrots and apricots, and other farm crops that boys would pull from the ground or pick from the tree, wipe off on their pants, and munch-on before the ballgame. Source: Don McPhail

properties.name: Palo Alto Main Community Garden
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Palo Alto\'s Main Community Garden alongside the main branch of the library. The older photographs are from 1984 and 1981. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Main Library
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The main library opened in 1958 alongside what was then Palo Alto City Hall. The previous main library sat on the current site of the new city hall. Photo #1: Inside the library, note the card catalogs. Photo #2: The early days of computers. Photo #3:Librarians ready to help at the newly opened library on Newell Road. Photo #4: 2006 Photo #5: The library under construction. Photo #6: Looking at where the internet terminals stand now. Photo #7: Outside the main library in the 1960s. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Medical Foundation (1930-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Russel V.A. Lee joined up in 1930 with five other doctors to form one of the first group practices in the country --- the Palo Alto Medical Clinic. Later, Lee would oversee the Clinic’s growth into an arm of the Palo Alto Medical Foundation, today one of the country’s largest multi-specialty practices.

properties.name: Palo Alto Military Academy (1919-1972)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "The union of two schools, the Palo Alto Military Academy and the Harker Day School, formed what is today The Harker School in San Josel. Although these schools began independently, David Starr Jordan, the first president of Stanford University, inspired both. In 1893 President Jordan, concerned for the University’s need for superior incoming students, encouraged Frank Cramer, a pioneer educator and civic leader, to begin Manzanita Hall, a college preparatory school for boys. The program was dedicated to the premise that the successful future citizen and student of higher education is one who has a broad foundation not only in his classroom pursuits, but also in nonacademic areas. The development of high moral character and leadership qualities was emphasized. Catherine Harker, a Vassar graduate and a professor of Greek and Latin at Mills College, recognized the need for a girls’ preparatory school near Stanford and founded Miss Harker’s School in 1902, which also emphasized superior scholarship, character, and leadership. In 1919 Cramer’s original school, Manzanita Hall, became Palo Alto Military Academy, a school for boys of elementary age under the direction of Richard P. Kelly. Donald L. Nichols assumed leadership of the Academy in 1950 and the Harker Day School in 1956, merged the two schools under the name Harker Academy and moved to the present location in 1972." Source: Harker School Website Photo #1: Members of the Military Academy. Photo #2: Palo Alto Military Academy being demolished in 1972. Photo #3: The PA Military Academy before the development of Rinconada Park. Photo #4: Manzanita Hall Photo #5: PAMA students. Photo #6: The demolition of the school grounds in 1972. Photo #7: Students with bikes. Photo #8: A major with a dog. Photo #9: During 1972 demolition, a Harker\'s Day School for Boys and Girls sign has fallen upside down. Photo #10: Manzanita Hall being taken apart in 1972, (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Office Center Courtyard (1965-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The courtyard of 525 University Avenue is rarely used. A promotional pamphlet for the Office Center in 1965 optimistically gushes that “the total effect of the plaza…is not unlike that of plazas of beautiful old European cities. The plazas are places of rest, to sit, to see and enjoy.” In truth, for much of the plaza’s four decades, it has sat empty --- a concrete canyon in which a harsh wind tunnel effect can make it a rather cold place to try to enjoy a sack lunch. And while the structure’s backers boasted that the building’s design “gives every consideration to human requirements,” the massive three story bush-hammered, concrete columns that were supposed to “add enjoyment to work,” make for a rather forbidding exterior.

properties.name: Palo Alto Police Headquarters
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The police moved from their former Bryant Street home to the back of the City Hall building in 1971. Here we see photos of Palo Alto\'s Police Department at work in the 1970s, 80s and 90s. Included is guitar lover and former police chief Jim Zurcher.

properties.name: Palo Alto Radio Association (1940)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "The Palo Alto Amateur Radio Association was first formed in 1937, and then incorporated as a California non-profit orginization in March of 1956, and for many years has had the club callsign W6OTX, formerly held by club member and Palo Alto resident (Ramona St.) Wilbur C. Lauridsen, who died while serving in the Navy during WWII. The club first applied to the FCC for a callsign on December 12 of 1940, and listed its club station as being located at 549 Channing Avenue in Palo Alto (application signed by Mr. Lauridsen). Club meetings have been held at various locations over the years, but since we had to vacate the Naval Communications Reserve Building on the Stanford campus several decades ago, we have been meeting at the Menlo Park Rec Center, in Burgess Park. Previous meeting locations include the Palo Alto Community Center, Palo Alto’s Mayfield School, and the Redwood City Council Chamers, all during The War. During WWII, PAARA members participated in WERS (the Wartime Emergency Radio Service), a civil-defense group manned almost entirely by ham radio operators. The club participated in Field Day during June of 1941, operating the Palo Alto Portable Station as W6M." -Palo Alto Radio Association

properties.name: Palo Alto Recycling Center
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Palo Alto Red Cross
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Home of the Palo Alto Red Cross. The picture dates from 1951 as Mrs. James Quinby and Mrs. Louis Love of the Palo Alto Red Cross chapter pose with four unidentified persons including a uniformed military man. (PAHA collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Senior Center
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  After its first life as Police Court, this building has since served Palo Alto seniors. Today it is Avendas, a retirement home. Photo #1: The Palo Alto Senior Center celebrates its 10th anniversary in 1988. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Snow Day (1962)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory On Sunday, January 21st, 1962, the children of Palo Alto awoke to a dazzling site. It had snowed --- and not just a few ice crystals on the grass --- it had really snowed. While there had been dustings here and there over the years, this was Palo Alto’s version of a blizzard --- an inch and a half was reported at Rinconada Park and close to 9 inches up in the mountains on Skyline Drive. After an extremely warm and dry winter that year, the storm was part of a cold spell caused by wayward Canadian winds that settled over the Western United States. In Palo Alto that early Sunday morning, the temperature dropped to 26 degrees and by 4AM, the falling rain began to turn to snow. As it turned out, it would keep on falling for the next three and a half hours and by the time breakfast was on the table, most youngsters were already outside having a once-in-a-childhood experience. Soon, the whole city was a giant white playground. Snowmen were being built all over town, snowball fights broke out everywhere, the 10th hole fairway at Los Altos Country Club became a makeshift ski resort and Palo Alto stores ran out of film. So many families took rides north to the mountains that Page Mill Road became bogged down in traffic. Other cars never started at all. One Palo Alto gas station owner reported that he sold 150 gallons of antifreeze by noon, three times the usual amount for an entire year. And so many locals were on the telephone giving amateur weather reports that the lines were completely jammed by 6:30 in the morning. One thing no one seemed to be doing was going to church. Local ministers reported that between 35-40% of their usual congregations were conspicuously absent --- evidentially out admiring God’s work personally.

properties.name: Palo Alto Sport Shop
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  One of the longest-running businesses in town. Photo #1: 2008 Photo #2 Ca. 1950s Photo #3: 1985

properties.name: Palo Alto Square (1972-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1968, developers William Alhouse and Thomas Ford announced their plan to build "a one-stop financial shopping center" on Stanford lands at Page Mill and El Camino, then a horse pasture. In 1970, 800 opponents of the plan petitioned Stanford University development officials to no avail. In 1972, two 10-story towers were completed and named Palo Alto Square. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Square Cinema (1971-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Today, only 2 Palo Alto movie houses showing first-run features have survived. The Aquarius Theatre downtown and Palo Alto Square tucked away since 1971 among office buildings on El Camino Real near Page Mill Road. Actually, the odd location might be part of the secret to their success---the theatre uses office parking at night for the films, making it easy to get in and out on a Saturday night. Palo Alto Square has narrowly avoided a couple of near-misses at extinction. In 1997, there were plans to turn the theatre (at that time run by Landmark who had all kinds of financial problems in those years) into more offices. Moving trucks were parked outside and seats had already begun to be ripped out, when Council Member Gary Fazzino and city staff persuaded landowner Equity Office Properties in Chicago to keep the theatre on a month to month lease. In 2001, Landmark did lose its lease, but the support the community showed (both in terms of protest letters and ticket receipts) allowed Cinearts, the artsy arm of Century Cinemas, to move in to the twin-screen miniplex. After some screen and seat renovations and additions at the snack bar that perhaps better match the films inside (frenchpastries and gourmet coffees, for instance), the theatre re-opened in 2002.

properties.name: Palo Alto Times Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Palo Alto Times was Palo Alto\'s paper of record for most of the 20th Century. This building has served many uses since the Times left and it was remodeled. It has served as the home home for the Title Insurance Company, Radio Shack and Lotus Custom Decor. Also included are photos of Elinor Cogswell, longtime editor and columnist as well as Eugene C. Bishop, publisher of the Palo Alto Times, sitting at the new Intertype with W.P. Carlile and Ben Black standing behind him. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Transfer and Storage Company
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Palo Alto Transfer and Storage Company was incorporated in 1912 with offices that were located at 111 The Circle. They also had three warehouses including one here on Homer Street. Their motto on the storage warehouse building reads "Excellence in every detail." One of their trucks was unfortunately used in the Chowchilla Kidnapping Case of 1976. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Trolley (1906-1925)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Palo Alto Streetcar Line ran down University Avenue between 1906-1925. It was operated by the Southern Pacific Railroad. Video Link: Historian Steve Staiger discusses the history of the Palo Alto Trolley. http://blip.tv/file/2538341

properties.name: Palo Alto Unified School District Offices (1955-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The school district\'s main offices are headquartered here next to Palo Alto Senior High School. The older photos are from 1955. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Wastewater Treatment Plant
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The plant in the background as boats are stuck at lowtide in 1987. Photo #2: From above in 1990. Photo #3: 1948.

properties.name: Palo Alto Weekly (1979-2009)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory 703 High St, Palo Alto, CAThe weekly newspaper was founded in 1979 and has become the most distributed paper in the region. In 2009, they moved their headquarters to Cambridge Avenue. Photo #1: 1985 on High Street side with the Reach Gym to the right of the photo. Photo #2: On Forest Avenue side. Photo #3: The building on fire in 1960 when it was a Ford dealership.

properties.name: Palo Alto Weekly (2009-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory New home of Palo Alto Weekly, the city\'s once-a-week newspaper. The paper\'s editor is long-time newspaper man Jay Thorwaldson. The first edition was put out on October 11th, 1979.

properties.name: Palo Alto YMCA
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Palo Alto YMCA is located on Ross Road as seen in 2009 and 1992. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Palo Alto Yacht Harbor (1928-1986)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory There have been numerous controversial political battles in the history of Palo Alto, but perhaps none has resulted in as much bitter feeling and long-lasting resentment as the 1980 decision to close the Palo Alto Yacht Harbor. In some ways, it was a classic culture clash. It featured two groups, the yachters and the environmentalists, each possessing vastly different worldviews, with little in common in how they saw the destiny of Palo Alto Harbor. What resulted was perhaps the most compelling political campaign in the city’s history. Not only was it exciting, always in doubt and full of rhetorical sparks, but in the end, the campaign itself really mattered. Because despite the close divide in public opinion, the environmentalists’ campaign was so utterly victorious and the boaters’ campaign so profoundly defeated, that by 1985, the public had twice backed what was once almost unthinkable --- the complete demolition of the Palo Alto Yacht Harbor. Photos: Photo #1 from 2008, #2 iis circa 1980. Photo #3: from Yacht Club campaign.

properties.name: Palo Alto's Beatlemania (1965)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory While playing a 1965 show in San Francisco, the Beatles stayed at the Cabana Hotel in Palo Alto. On August 31st, 1965, some 3,000, mostly female fans, crowded into the Cabana parking lot (some overnight) along with the screaming, crying and emotional breakdowns that seemed to follow the foursome everywhere in those days. Out of control fans crowds passed the Cabana’s outlandish replicas of the David and the Venus De Milo, swarmed across El Camino Real (backing up traffic) and into the Rickey’s lot across the street. A few girls even slipped past the guards and actually began to climb up the outer grating of the hotel (presumably with the goal of reaching the Beatles on the 8th floor), before being coaxed down again. Police were everywhere. In fact, it cost the San Mateo County sheriff’s office some 1,000 to provide 80 men and 30 patrol cars for the Beatles 25 hour stay. Palo Alto itself shelled out some 00 in overtime in order to station officers at the Cabana and the hotel’s own security bill was ,000 after hiring some 200 temporary security guards, including many players from the University of Santa Clara football team. But most of the action came as the Beatles came and went. Upon arrival, the scene of pandemonium outside the Cabana resembled one of the frantic free-for-alls displayed the year before in “A Hard Day’s Night.” Fans climbed onto the Beatles limousine, rocking the car and denting the roof. Years later, one Beatle fan recalled that upon getting out, this most famous rock group in music history simply looked like “four scared kids.” The next morning, however, the Beatles made a slick getaway. Plans were announced that the Beatles were to be whisked out of their Room 810 Suite, down the Northside elevator, past the Cabana kitchen and out through the service entrance. Sure enough, two decoy limos and a truck were stationed out front, prompting many fans to wave goodbye to Beatles that they mistakenly thought were inside. Instead, the boys were sent by police out the southside entrance. “Where’s the car?” asked Paul, upon arriving --- only to be directed into a white and blue 1.5 ton delivery truck along with John and George. But as the truck frantically made its way for the Cabana exit, the driver realized he had left Ringo behind --- not the last time the Beatle drummer would feel forgotten --- and had to slam on the brakes to let in the fourth band member. A photograph of two of Palo Alto female fans --- 14 year-old Rocky Keith and 13 year-old Sue Moore --- was printed in the Palo Alto Times the next day “sobbing with joy” because they happened to see the Beatles’ exit. But most of the girls on the other side of the hotel were not so lucky --- and were forced to console themselves by later purchasing pieces of Beatle bedsheets sold in the Cabana parking lot.

properties.name: Palo Alto-Menlo Park Connecting Bridge
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The connecting bridge between Menlo Park and Palo Alto in El Palo Alto Park.

properties.name: Palo Verde Elementary (1953-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Palo Verde Elementary School on Louis Road. It was called Sequoyah Elementary from 1976 to 1983.

properties.name: Parents Nursery School Co-Op (1943-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "In 1942, Mrs. Cecil George proposed the idea of forming a cooperative nursery school through an advertisement she placed in the Co-op newspaper. The Mothers\' Cooperative Nursery School began on the Stanford campus the following January. Monthly tuition was .00, and each mother worked two mornings a week at the school. After six months, the school moved to Sunday school rooms at the First Methodist Church. The inconvenience of having to disassemble the classrooms every Friday and then reassemble them on Monday led parents to explore the idea of finding a building of their own. Dr. Esther Clarke, who saw this sort of nursery school as a model for the early education of children, encouraged parents in finding a school site. She appeared before the Palo Alto City Council to advocate for the idea of placing the school in a residential environment. In 1948, after several fund raising efforts, a group of parents was able to purchase a permanent site for the school: a turnip patch at the edge of the city. It was parents who raised the money for the school, and it is parents of currently enrolled children who have remained its co-owners." -PNS website

properties.name: Paris Theatre (1961-1977)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Paris Theatre University Avenue has changed a great deal over the past 30 years and perhaps nothing illustrates that transformation as much as the one-time existence of the Paris Theatre. The X-rated movie house operated during the 1970s at 124 University Avenue near Alma Street, giving Palo Alto a rather unseemly entry point to the Downtown area. During its time as the city’s only adult theatre, the Paris would become engaged on a local basis in the national debate over obscenity. While the nation’s high court grappled with what constituted “obscene” and what was protected under the First Amendment, Palo Altans struggled with what was permissible according to their own community’s standards. Photo #1: Being remodeled in the 1980s. Photo #2:Carolyn Kelsey in the 1940s. Photo #3: W.D. Wasson Real Estate next to Fraternal Hall at left. Photo #4: In 2009, the location at 124 University Avenue is used by E-Trade Financial

properties.name: Park at California (1985)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A photo from 1985 shows the north side of California Avenue as viewed from Park Boulevard. The Palo Alto Central Condominiums have recently opened. A sign seems to indicate that an apartment went for 74,000.

properties.name: Park at Cambridge (1984)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Road closing in 1984 at Park and Cambridge. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Parkinson Block (ca. 1910)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Parkinson Block built in 1900. Today this is the home of Juut Salon.

properties.name: Paul's European Cobblery (1942-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  It is now known by the name, The ClogMarket.

properties.name: Pearson-Arastradero Preserve‎
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Hike on gently sloping trails through meadows leading to Arastradero Lake, approximately 20 minutes from the parking lot. Fishing is allowed in this city-owned preserve which includes 6.26 miles of hiking in savanna grassland and broad leaf evergreen forest. Horses and bikes allowed. Dogs allowed on weekdays only. No barbecues, fires or camping. Cross under Interstate 280 on Page Mill Road, turn right onto Arastradero Road and park in the lot a half-mile up on the right." -Palo Alto Online

properties.name: Pedestrian Footbridge
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This 35 year old pedestrian/bicycle footbridge that crosses near Oregon Expressway. The other way for bikers to get across is through the tunnel at Adobe Creek, which is open only half the year due to frequent flooding. In 2006, two pro-bike city council members proposed building one or two new bike and pedestrian bridges over the 101. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Pedro De Lemos House (1920s-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "When Palo Alto architect Monty Anderson began restoring the landmark Hacienda de Lemos in Old Palo Alto, he understood the importance of the job he was undertaking. He just wasn\'t sure if the end result would be praised or vilified by preservationists. Seven years and about .5 million later, the verdict is in, and Anderson passed with flying colors. As proof of his success, the California Preservation Foundation presented Anderson and the home\'s owners, Harry and Shirley Hagey, with a 1999 Preservation Design award in the category of rehabilitation/adaptive reuse. The award recognizes efforts to restore structures to their original forms without altering the historical character. Hacienda de Lemos--also known as Waverley Oaks, the name of the cul-de-sac where it sits--was built over a span of 10 years in the 1920s and 1930s by Pedro de Lemos, a former curator of the Stanford Art Museum and founder of the Carmel Art Institute. De Lemos, who was an artist in his own right, designed the house himself. He also handcrafted many of the colorful and whimsical tiles that decorate the inside and outside of the house. The architecture is classified as "Spanish eclectic." -PA Weekly 2/5/99

properties.name: Peer's Corner (1887)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory On a snow day in February of 1887. 2 adults and a child are standing at the corner. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Peers Park (1899-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Peers Park was founded in 1899 and named after Alexander Peers, resident of Mayfield for 59 years. He helped establish the Page and Peers Lumber Company in Mayfield in 1866, for which Page Mill Road was named --- the road that brought the logs from the mill to Mayfield. Photo #1: Alexander Peers Photo #2: Cub Scouts in Peers Park on Arbor Day, 1987. Video Link about Peers Park with Historian Steve Staiger: http://blip.tv/file/2622412

properties.name: Peet's Coffee & Tea (2005-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This is the currently the location of one of the city\'s many Peet\'s. It was formerly Cafe Sophia. Sophia Omar\'s business has since moved to Midtown.

properties.name: Peninsula Creamery
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A second location of the long-time downtown establishment, known informally as the Peninsula Creamery, but officially now known as the Palo Alto Creamery due to new management.

properties.name: Peninsula Creamery Bottling Plant
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Peninsula Creamery Bottling Plant shortly after its closing in 1985. Today it is Palo Alto Hardware under the banner of the ACE Hardware Corporation. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Peninsula Creamery Dairy Store
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory 900 High Street, Palo Alto, CAThe Dairy Store was once the local over the counter outlet for the Peninsula Creamery Ice Cream Plant at 800 High Street that shut down in 1994. The Dairy Store is still there, however, and is well regarded by the community. Photo #1: Lit up at night Photo #2: 1985 Photo #3: 2008, looking much spiffier.

properties.name: Peninsula Creamery Ice Cream Plant
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The 800 High Street condos occupy the land formerly owned by the Peninsula Creamery Ice Cream Plant. Photo #2: The front entrance at 800 High Street. Photo #3: The Ice Cream Plant in 1985. The plant was closed in 1994 and demolished in 2004. Photo #4: In its early days as Family Service Laundry...they only used "soft water." Link to a 360 degree panorama of the corner in 1996: http://www.virtualparks.org/scenes/Z5n3pe3veH6ApOgVa40aAzA.html

properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Pete McCloskey
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Paul Norton "Pete" McCloskey Jr. (born September 29, 1927) is a former Republican politician from the U.S. state of California who served in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1967 to 1983. He ran on an anti-war platform for the Republican nomination for President in 1972 but was defeated by incumbent President Richard Nixon. In April 2007, McCloskey switched his affiliation to the Democratic Party. He is a decorated United States Marine Corps veteran of combat during the Korean War, being awarded the Navy Cross, the Silver Star, and two awards of the Purple Heart. He published a book called Truth and Untruth: Political Deceit in America in 1972. One of McCloskey\'s enduring legacies is his co-authorship of the 1973 Endangered Species Act." Source: Wikipedia "McCloskey supported his fledgling law practice in the 1950s by representing citizens groups, he said. He was the attorney for the Greenmeadow Association in Palo Alto, when 242 residents who bought homes from Joseph Eichler felt he had reneged on a promise to keep the swimming pool, park and community center only for the buyers. "They paid me each, and I got him to cede the center to the community," McCloskey told the Palo Alto Weekly." Source: Palo Alto Weekly

properties.name: Piazza's Fine Foods
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This is a Piazza\'s Fine Foods in 2009. It is the former home of Brentwood Market and the Mayfair Market.

properties.name: Piers Dairy (1937-1984)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This is the former location of Piers Dairy. Today it is the office of Chabad Palo Alto. "Few other institutions other than Stanford University itself have left as enduring a mark on the Palo Alto area as Piers Dairy and Piers Ranch The Piers family operation that shaped or marked much of the 20th century in Palo Alto began with the immigration of Manuel Ignatius Piers -- known as "M.I." -- from his native town of Pico, Azores, to the Palo Alto area in 1912. In 1914 Piers bought a small dairy, the Home Dairy, and 20 acres along Willow Road in "north Palo Alto," now Menlo Park. He began selling milk from a roadside stand, along with ice cream and butter -- expanding his business to horse-and-buggy deliveries to nearby homes. For many years, Piers and later his growing family lived in a home on the property. By World War I Piers was delivering milk in bulk -- reportedly initially by horse and buggy -- to Stanford University\'s student union and dormitories, while the U.S. government built the Veterans Hospital across Willow Road. By the 1920s, the Home Dairy was garnering statewide prizes for its rich, "certified" milk, which it delivered to Palo Alto schools -- one of the first certified dairies in the state based on stringent inspections and health tests of the cows. Piers developed a reputation as a leader in breeding techniques to improve his dairy herd, located on an 8-acre milking farm on Louis Road in what is now south Palo Alto. He and his wife, Eleanor, raised three sons and a daughter in their home on the Willow Road property and later on Center Avenue in Palo Alto: Byron, Roger, Edson and Elinor -- all of whom, plus years later Edson\'s son, Gregory, were involved in the dairy operation at some point. Somewhere between World War I and the early 1920s, Piers leased a reported 1,750 acres of Stanford University foothill lands for grazing and breeding of his dairy herds -- a leasehold that reportedly grew to a maximum of about 2,500 acres for the "Piers Ranch" before Interstate 280 and other encroachments trimmed it back to less than half that...In 1937, Piers enlarged the dairy herd at the milking barn at 3070 Louis Road and founded Piers Dairy, drawing in virtually all his immediate family members. The new dairy opened an office and creamery, including fountain service, at 338 University Ave. on Sept. 1. At some point, the family moved from Willow Road to a new family home at 560 Center Ave., Palo Alto. -Palo Alto Weekly 8/10/2005

properties.name: Pioneer Blacksmith Shop (1890)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Pioneer Blacksmith Shop (owned by Joseph Ponce) was located at Grant Avenue and El Camino Real (Main Street). (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Pitman Avenue (1983)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking along Pitman Avenue in 1983. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Pizza Chicago
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  In 2009 this is Pizza Chicago. It is formerly the location of Shakey\'s Pizza.

properties.name: Plane Crash (1949)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Palo Alto Airport, located out on the Baylands has had its share of crashes, but none more spectacular than on December 21st, 1949. On that day, 56 year-old investment company president Raymond McWard was pursuing a rich man’s hobby --- flying his Fairchild 24 four-seater private plane. A novice flier who had recently undertaken his first solo flight, McWard was practicing landings when he became distracted for a moment by a radio antenna network. Upon approaching the runway, he didn’t see a set of utility power lines until it was too late. Swerving violently upward, the undercarriage of the plane struck the top two lines of the 110,000 volt main feeder line for PG&E. The lines parted and McWard’s plane crashed to the ground, flipped over and skidded 100 feet, stopping just yards away from where Embarcadero Road ends. Gasoline spilled out of the wing tanks and covered the ground around the plane. The 110,000 volt wires fell to the wet ground and began to inflame a number of small fires.

properties.name: Playtown Amusement Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Site of the 1960 freak accident in which Harvard Professor Frank Freidel\'s three year old son Phillip died.

properties.name: Pole Field (at Byxbee Park)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "The Pole Field consists of telephone poles of varying height with their tops at a uniform plane. They do not serve some practical purpose but are supposed to be reminiscent of ruined pier pilings in the Bay, and represent \'the contrast between man\'s control and nature\'s self regulation. \'" Source: American Grand Tours Photos: A variety of photos of Pole Field, mostly taken from the 1990s. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Police Court (1927-1971)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The former police and fire headquarters on Bryant Street. The building opened in 1927. It is of a stucco Spanish Colonial Revival style and contains an arcade along the ground floor, balconies on the second floor and fine decorative iron work. Built by Birge Clark. The police moved to the Civic Center in 1971. The site is now used as the Avenidas Senior Center. (PAHA Archives)

properties.name: Police Protest
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Police protest in 1976 against Prop 13...a measure which when passed made it more difficult to raise taxes for public services.

properties.name: Polly & Jakes (formerly)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Formerly the location of the much beloved antique store, Polly & Jakes. This later became the location for an outlet of Cingular Wireless and then AT&T Wireless. It was torn down in 2008 and a bigger building opened next door to house AT&T.

properties.name: Pool Used During Mansion Fire (1936)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Former Location of pool that was used by firefighters fighting the Barron Mansion fire on 11/29/36.

properties.name: Pop Harris House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Seaman "Pop" Harris arrived in Palo Alto in 1892, saved money for nine years, bought a newly built house on Fulton Street and sent for his wife and 13 children in North Carolina. He operated a shoeshine stand at the trolley station on Stanford campus. His descendants would create the A.M.E. Zion Church in Palo Alto, the first black church between San Francisco and San Jose. The exact address of his house is unknown. Sources: PA Weekly 4/20/94 Palo Alto: A Centennial History

properties.name: Popular Circus Grounds (1940s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The circus was virtually a town of its own. Usually taking up two or three dozen railroad cars, the circus would arrive at the University Avenue Station. Then a frantic move would take place as hundreds of employees would transport the enormous production to one of the circus locations --- usually an open field. Actually, both of the main Palo Alto circus locations would become future shopping centers--- the John Greer property where Town & Country Village now stands and the empty lot where one now finds Edgewood Plaza. Here workers would drive huge spikes into the ground, raise the big top and set up a small city dedicated to laughs and thrills.

properties.name: Post Office Letter Drop
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The on-the-go letter drop on Hamilton Avenue.

properties.name: Pre-1941 Grade Crossing
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Before the University Avenue overpass was built, there was a grade crossing here where the Southern Pacific trains would cross at the west end of The Circle.

properties.name: President Hotel Apartments (1968-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The old Hotel President has been the President Hotel Apartments since 1968.

properties.name: Prime Rib Inn (ca. 1985)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A contender on El Camino\'s Restaurant Row.

properties.name: Printer's Inc. Cafe (1978-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  320 S California Ave, Palo Alto, CAThe Printer\'s Inc. Cafe remains on California Avenue, despite the closing of the old Printers Inc. Bookstore in 2001. The bookstore operated from 1978-2001.

properties.name: Proposed Auto Row
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  In 2005, one issue during the city council elections was whether an "auto row" should be encouraged by the Palo Alto city government in this area.

properties.name: Proposed City of Leland (1905)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This was the center of an expansive 1905 real estate dream that never materialized, the City of Leland. The projected town included approximately the area from Colorado to El Verano and from Alma Street to the Bay. The promotion maps envisioned a university, hotel, opera house, fish cannery and docks for ocean-going steamers. The real estate venture was shattered during the 1907 depression, leaving atangle of debts and disappointed land owners.

properties.name: Proposed Location for Original PAMF Hospital
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Palo Alto residentialists, whose political philosophy is summarized in the quote above, picked their battles carefully in the early 1970s. After failing to stop the construction of the Oregon Expressway and having had their power reduced during the 1967 recall election, the residentialists were now clinging to just two remaining Council seats and were in need of a political victory. They would stake their comeback on the rejection of two major development projects in 1970 and 1971: the so-called Superblock project --- twin 11 story towers that were proposed on a downtown site along University Avenue --- and the 18 story Patient Care Health Center to be erected on a two block square in quiet Professorville. Dreaming of a city hospital to remedy the crowded conditions at Stanford University Hospital, The Palo Alto Medical Research Foundation (PAMRF), a non-profit corporation founded in 1930 by Dr. Russel V. Lee, proposed a “jet-age” hospital to open across from the Palo Alto medical clinic. The hospital project was massive in scope: The original proposal called for a 1 million, 18 story hospital of 600,000 square feet, 300 beds, and between 800 to 1,000 employees. But the problem was not just the size, but the location. Professorville is Palo Alto’s most historic neighborhood having acquired its name for the many Stanford professors who built their homes there in the 1890s. The PAMRF claimed (perhaps a bit cynically) that the location bordered by Waverley and Bryant Streets, Addison and Channing Avenues was the best of the many sites they considered for the hospital. But hospital opponents noted that it "is incredible that the PAMRF should conclude from their alleged site studies that the best location for the new hospital just happens to be across the street from their present medical clinic." Pointing to the small scale nature of the neighborhood and the old homes that would have to go, residentialists argued that “The site’s not right.” Photo #1: The tower would have risen in this photograph had the opposition forces won the battle. Photo #2: A sketch of the proposed hospital. Photo #3: A biker makes her opinion known. (1970) Photo #4: A map that never fully came to be. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Proposed Location for Shopper's World
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Originally, Alma Plaza was going to be far more than a neighborhood center. "Shoppers World," an 11-acre destination center on Alma with a department store, 60 to 80 smaller retailers and a gas station, would have been "the most convenient, attractive, successful shopping center on the Peninsula," predicted Palo Alto architect Morgan Stedman in a May 23, 1952 Palo Alto Times article. Dreams of "Shoppers World" became a reality of a grocery store-anchored neighborhood center, with about 45,000 square feet of retail and shops like a dry cleaner, a hair salon, shoe repair and a donut shop." -Palo Alto Weekly 6/16/06

properties.name: Proposed Superblock Complex (1970)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Palo Alto reached a turning point in 1970 and 1971. No longer the quiet small town of years gone by, developers began to pitch projects that sought to attract big-name businesses to further economic development in Downtown Palo Alto. But such projects also threatened the small-scale downtown environment that many cherished. The debate over what type of city Palo Alto was to become reached its zenith in the late 1960s with the debate over a sizable downtown office complex nicknamed the Superblock. Three years of political battle would ensue before the Superblock was finally rejected by the city’s voters in a 1971 referendum. And when the dust had finally settled, a new political course was set that would lead Palo Alto to become the city that it is to this day.

properties.name: Protest at Police Station (1968)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Students protest at the Palo Alto Police Station in 1968. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Protests at Town & Country
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The busy corner of El Camino and Embarcadero has long been a good place to stage a protest. Photo #1: This remarkable photo is of the Peninsula Youth for Peace protesting H-bomb testing. Paly student Joan Baez stands at far left. Photo #2: Protesters against U.S actions in El Salvador in the mid-1980s.

properties.name: Public Restroom
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Homeless advocates and parents of small children had been pushing for public restrooms downtown and in public parks since at least the 1980s. But neighbors and council members often worried it would attract the "wrong sort of people" NIMBYism seemed to arise with every potential location. In 1994, the debate heated up again when neighbors of Johnson Park complained that basketball players were using their stairwells for their baser needs. But when other neighbors protested the idea of park facilities, the city came up with a different plan---take out the basketball hoop. So what is a small-bladdered Palo Altan to do? Ah, have no fear, the French to the rescue. Decaux public restrooms, which are operated by coin, self-clean for 55 seconds after each use, and are visited by maintenance workers twice a day have been installed in cities all over Europe. Perhaps that\'s why the French are considered so refined? But while the new toilets solved much of the problem, the bad news was that you get what you pay for.
