With a yearly tab of 1,500 per toilet, the city purchased just two restrooms and installed them at Lytton Plaza (later moved to the Caltrans station) and at the corner of Hamilton and Waverly. The restrooms cost 50 cents to use, but tokens are distributed for free to the homeless. What a relief!

properties.name: Purity Market
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory It is a little hard to believe these days but Stanford Shopping Center once had a Purity supermarket. These photos are circa 1955. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Purity Market
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: In the early 1940s. Photo #2: The sign for the Hotel President can be seen in the background. Photo #3: In the 1940s as cars pull into the parking lot.

properties.name: Purity Market (1948)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This aerial photo shows the Purity Market under construction to the left. The year is 1948. Later the space was used as a nightclub called the Keystone. The photo is of the Water Brothers playing at the Keystone. Jefferson Starship, Bruce Springsteen, Huey Lewis, the Tubes and Cheap Trick all played there. The Keystone later became The Vortex, one of the first places in the Bay Area to offer New Wave-DJ dance music. The old market then had a third life as the dance club, The Edge. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Push
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Created by Santa Cruz, CA artist, Fred Hunnicutt and located in Mitchell Park, 600 East Meadow Avenue, “Push” was purchased in 1983 in response to a community vote as part of a sculpture invitational exhibition. “Push” was commissioned by the Public Art Commission and funded by the City of Palo Alto." -City of Palo Alto

properties.name: Quarry Road
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This street is named Quarry Road because it is the 1954 extension of a road from a quarry that was located near the present day 18th hole of the Stanford Golf Course.

properties.name: Quarry Road (1934)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Quarry Road on the Stanford Campus where the Stanford Shopping Center is presently located. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Radio Shack
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This location is home to a Radio Shack in 2009. It is the former site of The Winery restaurant.

properties.name: Ramona Hotel
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Located at the corner of University Avenue and Ramona Street once stood the rather grand Ramona Hotel. Photo #1: Ramona Plaza under construction Photo #2: Perhaps a fire on the first floor of the Ramona Hotel. Photo #3: Ramona Plaza under construction. Photo #4: 1937 Photo #5: The Ramona Hotel from above. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Ramona Nails
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A photo of the building in 1985. In 2009 it is home to Ramona Nails. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Ramona Plaza Courtyard
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Ramona Plaza Courtyard is a tucked away spot behind the stores on Ramona Avenue.

properties.name: Ramona Street
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Ramona Street derives its name from the heroine of the popular novel "Ramona," about early life in California. It was written by Helen Hunt Jackson (pictured).

properties.name: Ramona's Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Ramona\'s Restaurant is a pizza place that used to be located on Ramona where the Old Pro now stands.

properties.name: Ramos Park (1958-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Don Jesus Ramos Park opened in 1958 next to the Ortega School. It was originally known as Meadow Park after it was purchased in 1955 for 5,000 from the Brown-Kaufman tract. The park is named for Mexican native Don Jesus Ramos who lived at 727 Page Mill Road and acted as a guide to visitors interested in the gold finds at Stevens Creek, 10 miles southeast of Mayfield. He also worked as foreman to Don Secundino Robles for many years. Source: The Parks of Palo Alto

properties.name: Ray Field
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: The Palo Alto High School Vikings in 2004. Photo #2: During a football game in what appears to be the 1950s. The band is playing at intermission. Photo #3: The Paly football team in the year 1922. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Red Mango & Neighbors
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Stores on this block today include Shady Lane and Red Mango, a yogurt shop whose franchisee is Survivor winner Yul Kwon. The older photo is from 1985.

properties.name: Rendtorff House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Historic Buildings Inventory as revised in 1981: "A good example of an important Craftsman variant design, rare in Palo Alto. Professor Karl J . Rendtorff (1865-1945), the first occupant, came to the United Status from Kiel, Germany, in 1893 for graduate study at Stanford. After receiving his Ph.D. degree he remained with the University in the German Department until retirement in 1929." Photos are from 1978 and 2004.

properties.name: Rick's Swiss Chalet (1961-1985)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Rick’s Swiss Chalet was geared specifically to the food and tastes of Switzerland and provided European ambiance courtesy of Southern Bavaria’s Edelweiss Trio. The Chalet even held the first meeting for the still existent Peninsula Swiss Club and from 1961-1985, the restaurant served some three million meals on El Camino Way where the Goodwill Store now stands.

properties.name: Rickey's Hotel (formerly)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This Palo Alto institution had a rich and truly historic sixty year run as one of the foremost hotels in the region. As the area’s major venue for weddings, class reunions, Rotary Club meetings and all gatherings local, the percentage of Palo Altans who spent at least one important day of their life at Rickey’s is probably pretty high.

properties.name: Rinconada Adult Pool
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The rectangular pool at Rinconada Park was added in 1940 and now serves as the adult pool.

properties.name: Rinconada Children's Pool
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The children\'s pool at the east side of Rinconada Park. It was renovated in 1998 in a creative and playful way. These photos show the pool since renovation and a range of photos of swimmers at play dating as far back as the 1930s.

properties.name: Rinconada Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory 799 Embarcadero Rd, Palo Alto, CARinconada Park is the second-oldest of Palo Alto\'s parks, having been acquired from the University Realty Company in 1922. The park was originally known as "Waterworks" for the reservoir and well located on the site near the corner of Newell Road, but after Mrs. M.S. Alterton won a 5 naming prize in 1924, it has since been known as Rinconada Park (little corner in Spanish). Over the years, the park has been developed through the construction of a community center (1932), children\'s theatre (1936), swimming pool (1940) and children\'s museum (1941). Source: Parks of Palo Alto Photo #1: Rinconada Park Photo #2: Picnic grounds Photo #3: From above in the 1940s (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Rinconada Tennis Courts
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: A man prepares to serve on the Rinconada Park tennis courts. Photo #2: Women playing doubles in perhaps the 1960s. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Robaii, Falafel & Persian Bites (1998-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Iranian Restaurant is at the corner of Hamilton and Cowper is named after a technique in Persian poetry. The eatery offers falafel in pita, hummus, lamb dishes, Persian-style burgers and their popular iced tea. This is the former home of the Penny Farthing.

properties.name: Robert Krohn Shoes
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This rhombus-shaped building is the former location of Robert Krohn Shoes. It later changed its name to the somewhat more cosmopolitan, Eurowalk Shuz. Photo #1: Robert Krohn in his shoe store in 1988. Photo #2: Barbara Baer at Robert Krohn Shoes in 1992. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Roos Brothers
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: 121-131 University Avenue in 1985, including the ice cream parlor known as One Scoop or Two. This building opened in 1925 and was the location of Roos Brothers, which later moved to the Stanford Shopping Center in 1955. It was designed by Birge Clark. Photo #2, #6: Roos Brothers circa 1924, just before the building was demolished. The sign tells of the store\'s temporary location "just around the corner." Sticky Wilson\'s is next door to the right. Photo #3: Veteran firefighters walk past Roos Brothers and Sticky Wilson\'s at the 1941 Dedication Day Parade. Photo #4: Regent, J. Nielsen "expert jeweler" and the Eagle Drug store in this photograph of the north side of University Avenue during a celebration. Photo #5: In 1905 John F. Byxbee and B.F. Hall\'s Realty Office was here alongside Hemlick\'s, which has a sign advertising "ice cream sodas" inside. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Roos Brothers
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Roos Brothers was the first store to locate at the Stanford Shopping Center in 1954. This postcard shows the clothing store facing El Camino Real alongside Emporium. Photo #2: Stanford Shopping Center booster Alf Brandin, the vice president for business affairs at Stanford, posing in front of Roos Brothers. Photo #3: At night with a Christmas Tree in between The Emporium and Roos Brothers.

properties.name: Rope Pole (1997-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Po Shu Wang, a Hong Kong-born artist now living in Berkeley, installed his untitled sculpture, “Ropepole” in 1997 California Avenue at Birch Street. The 25\' cedar trunk has been carved to look like the strands of a rope. Some people say that the rope seems to ascend into infinity on one of Palo Alto\'s cloudy, low sky days. Po Shu Wang is represented by major works of public art in many Bay Area cities. He was a recipient of the Eureka Fellowship award in 1998. The work was commissioned by the Public Art Commission and funded by the City of Palo Alto." -Palo Public Art Commission

properties.name: Rose & Crown English Food (1991-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Formerly Lavenshire Tavern. The older photo is circa 1981. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Rose Garden at the Gamble Gardens
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Roth Building (1932-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The historic Roth Building was the long-time home of the Palo Alto Medical Clinic, opening in 1932. Currently unused, it is the future home of the Palo Alto History Museum. Video clip of Historian Steve Staiger discussing the life of Russel V. Lee: http://blip.tv/file/2566152

properties.name: Rrrun (2004-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 2004, former Public Arts Commission Member Marta Thoma’s “Rrrun” statue was purchased by the City of Palo Alto for 0,000. There were allegations made at the time that the artist was too cozy with commissioners and that there was a potential conflict-of-interest at hand. “Rrrun” was eventually approved by the city council and now the leggy roadster baffles drivers passing by its perch along side Alma Street.

properties.name: Rudolpho's
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1956, brothers Harry, Rudy, George and Art Alfinito opened the beloved Rudolpho’s at the corner of Los Robles Avenue and El Camino. The brothers would spend more than three decades serving cannelloni to Jimmy Durante and other not-so-famous clientele at their distinctive red checkered tables. Controversially, the restaurant was closed and later bulldozed in 1993 to make way for apartments when the City Council changed the zoning status of the block --- an action that brought angry protests from spaghetti fans all over Barron Park. Photo #1: El Camino Real and El Camino Way in the 1960s. The Rudolpho\'s building is the top right hand corner. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Rue du Chat Qui Peche
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The hiring of Rosemary McAndrews in the early 1970s signaled a move toward a more high-end shopping experience. In 1976, the Palo Alto City Council approved an enormous expansion of the center that allowed McAndrews to go to town. Policy was changed to force many stores into smaller quarters and some larger leases were bought out. McAndrews then took to fashioning the old mall into a sort of European street fair. Using photos of markets and shopping plazas she took while on trips to the Old World, McAndrews made what was once a good place to buy a new lawnmower or ladder into the place to purchase a trendy Italian sports coat or rare oriental fragrance. The appearance changed dramatically, as well, with the addition of lush gardens, fanciful sculptures and a grand mural of a European market rather self-consciously referred to as the “Rue du chat qui peche." By 1985, the Euro strategy had paid off, quite literally, as its 150 stores led the Peninsula with annual earnings of 50 million. Photo #1: 1980s Photo #2: 2008

properties.name: Russian Orthodox Church Hall (1952-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: The inside of the Russian Orthodox Church Hall on Ross Road as seen in the 1966. Photo #2: Outside in 1968. Photo #3: Polina Zapreyeva lights candles inside the Russian Orthodox Church on Ross Road in south Palo Alto just before the start of the Christmas Eve celebration. (PA Weekly) Photo #4: In 2006. (PA Weekly)

properties.name: SRI Protest (May 16th, 1969)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory On May 16th, 1969 and a Stanford student militant group called the April 3rd Movement was protesting war tactics and chemical weapons being researched at the Stanford Research Institute (SRI). Early that Friday morning, 150 demonstrators arrived at the SRI building on Hanover Street in the Stanford Industrial park off Page Mill Road. Linking arms, they formed a 100-man picket line while others carried placards saying “SRI Kills” and “Pax not Pox” (as in peace, not smallpox weapons that were being developed). The Palo Alto police sent a bus with 55 officers and other security personal to oppose them. By mid-morning there were nearly 400 demonstrators on hand and the police force opposing them had grown to 130. Things began to spiral out of control. Some protesters began to throw rocks and break windows in the SRI building. Then in 2 places, the students set fire to the bus and the makeshift barricade. As the chaos grew, the police gave the crowd a warning to disperse or face arrest. When they did not, all hell broke loose. Police released eye-irritating choking tear gas and smoke bombs and began moving en masse down Hanover Street. Many protesters were forced to flee into an empty field, while others caught the full effect of the teargas. Some of the police, ducking rocks, chased protesters as far as 3/4 of a mile. In all 15 arrests were made, 60 protesters were injured and someone threw a rock through the window of the Stanford president’s office.

properties.name: San Antonio at Alma (1961)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  In 1961, before the construction of the overpass. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: San Antonio at the 101 (1960s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The rather sparse landscape of San Antonio Avenue as it crossed the Bayshore Freeway in the 1960s. This view is looking north towards the interchange.

properties.name: San Francisquito Bridge (1886)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory El Palo Alto is visible off to the left of the photograph. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: San Francisquito Creek at El Palo Alto
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A postcard of El Palo Alto and the San Francisquito Creek.

properties.name: Sand Hill Road (1977-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Sand Hill Road, first named Willow Road, had its name changed in 1977 to conform to San Mateo County\'s Sandhill Road so that the same designation could be applied to the entire road. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Sand Hill Road Controversy
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The 42 million Sand Hill Road Project and its seemingly endless political tangents occupied a place in the Palo Alto political spotlight for nearly 3 decades. And in the mid-90s when Stanford put on a full-court press to get the city’s go-ahead on the project once and for all --- concerns over traffic congestion, open space development, relations with Menlo Park, the fate of native creek species and even the hidden artifacts of the Ohlone Muwekma Indians created a hailstorm of criticism and controversy. In the end Stanford got its way, but only after a pricey public relations war and a feisty political campaign. (PAHA Collection) Photo #1: Sand Hill Road in 2007 Photo #2: Sand Hill Road, circa 1985. Photo #3: Sand Hill Road in the early 20th Century.

properties.name: Sanor Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The House of Foam in 1994. It is still there as of 2009. Photo #2: The House of Foam and Hamilton Press in 1985. Photo #3: Miller & Sanor Groceries storefront was located at the corner of Hamilton Avenue and High Street in the 1930s. An ad in the window for Chesterfield Cigarettes remind us that "they satisfy." (PAHA Collection).

properties.name: Santa Rita at Bryant Street (1930s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Schulse House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "This house was built in 1902 and is a Category 3 on the Historic Buildings Inventory. The companion house at 319 was probably built in 1900. James W. Wells built the 1900 house, while H.L. Upham built the 1902 house." -Historic Buildings Inventory Photo take i 1978

properties.name: Sea Scout Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Built in quintessential 1940s “streamline moderne” style by Birge Clark, the Sea Scout Building with its porthole windows, navigation bridge, flag hoist and smoke stacks was designed to resemble an actual ship. From its beginning,it was the home to the local Sea Scouts, an off-shoot of the Boy Scouts, that taught boys and girls aged 14-20 how to excel in water activities such as sailing, sea customs, riggings, compass reading and knot-tying. On the weekend of May 30th, 1941, Palo Alto’s “fairy godmother” and greatest benefactor Lucie Stern --- who had given 3,000 for the base’s construction --- christened the building by smashing a bottle of Atlantic Ocean seawater on the deck rail. The three day extravaganza of dedication activities included a bonfire, jiu-jitsu, magic show, barbeque and formal dance; all emceed by radio performer Hal Burdick. On Sunday, the event concluded with the formal inspection of over 150 Palo Alto and visiting Sea Scouts in their dress uniforms. The building was abandoned after the Yacht Harbor closed, although it will soon be the home to the Environmental Volunteers. Photo #1: In 2007 Photo #2: From the same angle in 1973. Photo #3: At the Sea Scout weekend of opening activities in May 1941. (PAHA) Photo #4: Palo Alto’s “fairy godmother” and greatest benefactor Lucie Stern --- who had given 3,000 for the base’s construction --- christened the building by smashing a bottle of Atlantic Ocean seawater on the deck rail in 1941. Photo #5: The Environmental Volunteers are restoring the old building. Photo #6: Architect Birge Clark\'s porthole windows help give the building its distinctive ship appearance. Photo #7: The newly constructed Sea Scout Building with several boats, including S.S.S. Alcor, visible in 1941. Photo #8 The Sea Scouts tried to rally the community to support the Yacht Harbor, but ultimately failed. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Seale Avenue
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Seale Avenue was named for Palo Alto pioneers Henry Seale, Thomas Seale and the Seale family. Henry Seale, like John Greer, came from Ireland and started a contracting business in San Francisco with his brother, Thomas. In 1853, the Seale brothers acquired a large party of Rancho Rinconada del Arroyo de San Francisquito from the Soto heirs. The Seales at one time owned most of the land on which early Palo Alto was located. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Second PA Train Station
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  In 1896, a second larger, yellow-tinged station was constructed around the original, built with archways and some of the spectacle of the nearby university. As the start of the local line to San Francisco, the new station served Stanford’s 400 students and Palo Alto’s 318 residents. It was replaced in 1941 by the current station. Photo from the 1930s (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Second Street
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Strangely, this is the only numbered street in Palo Alto. That\'s because in this part of old Mayfield, First Street became Wilkie Way and Third Street became Park Blvd. but Second remains. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Secundino Robles Adobe
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Secondino Robles Adobe was near the northeast corner of Alma and San Antonio. It was destroyed by the 1906 earthquake. Source: Mayfield 1850-1925

properties.name: Sequoia Book Shop
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This parking lot is the former location of the Sequoia Book Shop. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Seventh Day Adventist Church
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: 2008 Photo #2: Carolers sing on the church steps a few days before Christmas in 1976. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Shangri-La Motel
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  These postcards show the old Shangri-La Motel at 3981 El Camino Real. More recently it was the Mayflower Garden Motel. In 2009, the hotel was torn down and the middle campus of the private Keys School was constructed.

properties.name: Shell Gas Station
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Many local residents have worried that this gas station may be lost when Edgewood Plaza is renovated. It is currently highly-trafficked despite the abandoned mall.

properties.name: Shell Gas Station (ca. 1965)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory At the corner of Margarita Avenue is a Shell Gas Station in this photo. Kraft furniture is across the street. Notice the Mastercharge sign. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Sherman Street (1890)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Sherman Avenue with Mayfield (California Avenue) train station in the distance. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Shirley Cobb Books (1938-1985)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Ty Cobb\'s sister ran Shirley Cobb Books for many years next door to the Varsity Theatre, which would eventually become Borders Books and Music. The store was a fixture on University Avenue from 1938-1985. Shirley was stricken with a debilitating stroke in 1971, paralyzing the left side of her body. But she remained the manager at her shop from 1971 until its closing. Photo #1:La Boulangerie shortly after Shirley Cobb Books left Photo #2:Shirley Cobb Books circa 1983 Photo #3: Shirley Cobb Books Photo #4: In 1970 next door to the Varsity Theatre (showing "Love Story"). 2009: The Mint Leaf Cafe (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Siam Royal
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This was once the location of Piers. In 2009, it is the location of Siam Royal. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Simkins Court (1983-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Simkins Court was named in 1983 to honor Henry W. Simkins, pioneer businessman, once owner and editor of the Palo Alto Times and first elected town clerk when the city was incorporated.

properties.name: Site of 1927 Accident
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This was the site of the 1927 accident that killed seventeen year-olds Mary Collins Harris and Max Springer as they were on their way to attend the Palo Alto Junior College located on the high school campus. As it crossed the tracks, the automobile was struck full- force just behind the rear wheel by the oncoming train, sending the vehicle nearly 50 feet in the air. Both students were thrown out of the car and Mary Harris died instantly. Springer died later in a bed at Palo Alto Hospital.

properties.name: Site of Overpass Decoration
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The "Chapel in the Sky" was erected on the overpass at University Avenue at Christmas time in both 1941 and 1946. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Site of Vladimir Pokhilko Double Muder-Suicide (1998)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The horrible events at the house of Vladimir Pokhilko one night in 1998 were the end of a sad Silicon Valley tale. For more, click on the link...

properties.name: Site of the David Lui Murder (1994)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory David Lui was murdered outside this apartment complex in 1994.

properties.name: Site of the worst hit area in the 1998 Flood
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In the early hours of February 3rd, 1998, heavy El Nino rains prompted an event that residents had worried about for years --- San Francisquito Creek overflowed. A wave of water went rushing downhill at record speeds of 7,100 cubic feet per second into the neighborhood of Crescent Park, past University Ave, Hamilton, Channing, over Embarcadero, running southeasterly and pooling into the lowlands near Greer Park in this neighborhood.

properties.name: Sky Ranch Motel
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Sky Ranch Inn in a postcard, circa 1960 and in 2008. Today it is part of the chain known as America\'s Best Value Inn. They have some 900 locations across the country.

properties.name: Smith's Cyclery
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Fred Smith\'s Cyclery on The Circle began as a small bike shop and then evolved into an "automobile garage," enticing customers with "free air." Later it expanded west and became a sporting goods store as well. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Southgate Food Store (1949)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A small market located on the corner of Miramonte Avenue and El Camino Real, photographed in April of 1949. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Spaulding Furniture
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Stanford Savings & Loan (1985) Photo #2: A very early photo of University Avenue with the Spaulding Furniture Building on the corner of Bryant and University. In 1923 this was the meeting place for the Chamber of Commerce, Palo Alto Merchants\' Credit Association and Builders\' Association among others. In 2009 it is the site of a Wells Fargo Bank. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Spirals
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  In 2009, this space was empty. It had most recently been the Italian restaurant, Madison & Fifth. In the 1980s, it was Spirals, as run by former city council member Micki Schneider, seen in the picture. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Spot, A Pizza Place (2008-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Spot: A Pizza Place opened here in 2008 after a move from Town & Country Village. This is the former home of Espresso Bettola Coffee House.

properties.name: St. Albert the Great Church
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Completed in 1961, St. Albert the Great Church sits on a two-acre campus and includes St. Elizabeth Seton School, an extended day care center (managed by the school), a parish center and a parish hall. Source: http://www.paloaltocatholic.org/SAG.html

properties.name: St. Aloysius Church (1868-1939)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Approximate location of St. Aloysius Church, established in 1868 as the first Catholic church in Mayfield. Its steeple and bell tower were added in 1910. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: St. Ann's Chapel
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In the late 40\'s the Norris house was sold to serve as home to The Catholic Archdiocese of San Francisco. Catholic priests and students moved in and the house began to take on a church-like aura, complete with Madonnas and crucifixes in nearly every room. The chapel erected in the side yard was the gift of Congresswoman Clare Booth Luce. It is dedicated as St. Ann, for her daughter who was attending Stanford when she died in an automobile accident in 1944.

properties.name: St. Michael's Alley (1973-2009)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Perhaps no Palo Alto establishment runs the full gamut of the hippie to bourgeois progression like legendary St. Michael’s Alley. Opening as a kind of European-favored coffehouse in the late 1950s, it just caught the end of the Beats, helped launch Joan Baez when folk took over and became the happening spot in town. In the mid 60’s it garnered a bad reputation, making police watch lists and drawing the wrath of mainstream Palo Alto. After closing down in 1966, St. Michael’s Alley reopened 7 years later as a full-menu restaurant with a new location and new credo to serve an upscale audience. By the 1990s it had become a definitive bobo hangout --- featuring such specialties as “Prosciutto-Wrapped Halibut topped with white wine lemon cape-garlic sauce.”

properties.name: St. Thomas Aquinas Catholic Church
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This is the oldest existent church building in Palo Alto and incidentally the host to a scene from the 1971 movie Harold and Maude. Designed in 1901 by Shea and Shea of San Francisco, it features a distinctive Gothic style. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Stacey's Booksellers (1960-2000)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This address was home to Stacey\'s Booksellers for four decades. Today it is a Verizon Wireless store.

properties.name: Stanford Credit Union
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Stanford Credit Union was founded in 1959.

properties.name: Stanford Dyeing and Cleaning Works (1910)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Stanford Dyeing and Cleaning Works, circa 1910. A horse and buggy wait outside. A sign indicates that the establishment uses "scientific methods." This address is now a public parking lot next to the Aquarius Theater. Photo #2: Stanford Dyeing and Cleaning Works gutted from the dire to Deluxe Hall next door. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Stanford Electric Works
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Stanford Electric Works in the 1950s. Photo #2: Inside what was called Stanford Lighting in 1919. Photo #3:Stanford Electric Works in 2008. Photo #4: Chris Machala and Ed Cargill now own and operate Stanford Electric Works. Photo #5: Mr. A. B. Peterson established Stanford Electric Works back in 1914. This photo was taken in 1924.

properties.name: Stanford Financial Square
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The office building has been climbed by King Kong courtesy of Miller Lite. Circa 1990.

properties.name: Stanford Pet Clinic
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Stanford Pet Clinic is a full-service veterinary located on El Camino Real at El Camino Way.

properties.name: Stanford Research Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In the 1940s, Stanford Professor Frederick Terman began to consider how Stanford might further a kind of western intellectual center that could rival the eminence of eastern hotspots. He envisioned a meeting of academia and industry that would prove prophetic. Actually, Terman would make it prove prophetic. During the 1950s, Frederick Terman would play the pivotal role in establishing that entrepreneurial partnership with Stanford University that set off a now world-famous techie boom. The innovative center was called the Stanford Industrial Park and it would become the heartbeat of what came to be known as Silicon Valley.

properties.name: Stanford Research Park (1960s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Hanover Street south of Page Mill Road. A building housing Energy Systems is visible on the right. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Stanford Shopping Center (1954-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In many ways Palo Alto’s Stanford Shopping Center represents the story of the typical American mall. Built in the early days of American’s great suburban migration, the new shopping plaza north of Stanford and just west of El Camino Real immediately drew shoppers away from the traditional downtown Palo Alto commercial district. And yet Stanford Shopping Center has never been completely typical. Founded as a special source of income for Stanford University, its beginnings certainly were unique. Furthermore, as an outdoor center which has grown in stages and also undergone a dramatic upscale shift over the years, the Stanford Shopping Center has never been easily classified. These days it hardly resembles the typical multi-tiered, air conditioned “box with food court” that is the prototypical American mall. As Palo Alto has become the capital of Silicon Valley’s success, the Stanford Shopping Center has grown to accommodate the new wealth that has flooded the city. Long gone are Palo Alto’s days as a sleepy small town --- and long gone are the days of the Stanford Shopping Center as a sleepy small town mall. Photo #1: Tiffany\'s at the modern day Stanford Shopping Center. Photo #2: Looking at Bloomingdale\'s. Photo #3: Tractors begin their work on the Stanford Shopping Center in 1953. Photo #4: A map of the original shopping center. Photo #5: The Emporium was one of the big San Francisco stores which opened locations in the original center. Photo #6: The fields where the Stanford Shopping Center would be built. Palo Alto Hospital is in the distance. Photo #7: On a rainy day. Photo #8: The farmland in the top left is today\'s Stanford Shopping Center (circa 1942).

properties.name: Stanford Shopping Center Parking Lot (ca. 1990)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  In the Stanford Shopping Center parking lot, circa 1990. This view is looking southwest. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Stanford Theatre
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  For a time it seemed that the Stanford Theatre --- Palo Alto’s oldest and grandest movie house --- would suffer the unfortunate fate of most single-screen theatres of yesteryear. As cable and color television, VCRs and year-round TV sports lured people to stay home on Friday and Saturday nights --- and big screen multiplexes opened within a short freeway drive --- the Stanford began to sink ever further down the cinematic food chain, eventually showing second-run Hollywood action flicks while continuously poised on the verge of being eaten up by shops and restaurants. But thanks to the David and Lucile Packard Foundation and the zeal of the billionaire’s movie-buff son, David Woodley Packard, the story of the Stanford has a happy ending after all. It just goes to show what million can do. But no matter how high the price tag for the theatre’s restoration and operation, today the Stanford is one of Palo Alto’s treasures, sending lines of patrons around the block for “Casablanca,” “Citizen Kane” and the annual Christmas Eve showing of “It’s a Wonderful Life.” Indeed, it’s the Stanford that gives Palo Alto the same kind of small-town charm that inspired George Bailey to run down Main Street calling out hellos to Bedford Falls. Photo #1: 2008 Photo #2: 1925 on the night of the theatre\'s opening Photo #3: In 1985 showing Dance With Stranger Photo #4: The interior in 1925 Photo #5: In the theatre in 2007 Photo #6: Savior David Woodley Packard (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Stapleton Florist
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Tiny, pink Stapleton Flowers nestled in between bigger buildings on Waverley was cherished by locals. Today it is Michaela\'s Flower Shop. Photo #1: In 1985 Photo #3: In 2007 (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Starbucks
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory 2000 El Camino Real, Palo Alto, CAThis local Starbucks caters to the nearby Stanford student population. Previously it was a Mountain Mike\'s Pizza and in the 1960s, it was the Hasty House.

properties.name: Starbucks
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This Starbucks is in the former location of the Bungalow Market.

properties.name: Stark's Bakery (ca. 1941)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Stark\'s Bakery near the corner of University and Bryant at 412 University Avenue. In 2009 this is home of the Union Bank of California. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Stars Palo Alto (1995-1997)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Stars, partly owned by chef Jeremiah Tower, opened at the 265 Lytton Ave. in 1995, and business started off strong. Within months, Tower took a more limited role in the restaurant and business sagged, leaving Palo Alto developer Jim Baer and 60 other Silicon Valley investors to run the restaurant." -Palo Alto Weekly Spago\'s then took over at the location, but closed in 2007. The building itself dates back to 1927 when it was 1927 when it was built to house the Tinney & Sons Mortuary. In 1974, the building began a new life as a restaurant when it was remodeled to become The Gatehouse, which did business until 1994.

properties.name: Sterling Park (2009-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A collection of condominiums, townhomes and detached single-family homes.

properties.name: Steve Jobs House (1934-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory When he first bought his medieval-revival mansion, he had a minor complication with Palo Alto\'s rather strict historic preservation regulations. Jobs wished to tear down a arguably historic Craftsman style bungalow that he owned in the adjoining property to his 1930\'s-era house. His proposed new use for the site: apricot orchards. Most in Old Palo Alto agreed that a little piece of bucolic farmland in the neighborhood probably wasn\'t going to hurt anyone. Palo Alto let Jobs circumvent the rules and he planted his orchards. President Clinton visited the house in August of 1996 for a fundraising dinner.

properties.name: Stickney's (Formerly)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Scott\'s Seafood is the former location of well-remembered Stickney\'s Restaurant.

properties.name: Sticky Wilson's (1902-1951)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Sticky Wilson\'s is behind the paraders in this 1941 photo. Photos #2, #3: In the early days of Palo Alto this was the Hall\'s Drug Store and then the Eagle Drug Company. Photo #4: Sticky Wilson\'s with a Western Union further on down University Avenue. (1920s) Photo #5 The Stanford Bookstore was on this corner in 2006 Photo #6: Sticky Wilson\'s, circa 1924, next to Roos Brothers. This was also the location of a club called the Poppycock in the 1970s.

properties.name: Su Hong Eatery (1987-2007)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The first Su Hong\'s opened in 1977 in Menlo Park. In 2007, Su Hong moved to 4256 El Camino Real.

properties.name: Subway
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This Subway has also been the previous locations for Round Table Pizza and Bishop\'s Creamery.

properties.name: Sun Flowers (2003-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "In 2003, a work entitled, "Sun Flowers" was installed on at 440 S. California Avenue near Mimosa Lane. "Sun Flowers" consists of seven bronze "flowers" that also function as umbrellas. The slightest breeze makes the petals slowly revolve. Each contains embedded solar batteries that build up energy in the daytime, and then light up at night. In addition, they are elegantly crafted tables and chairs. In recognition of its excellence, "Sun Flowers" was awarded two prizes in 2003 by the prestigious Northern California Chapter of the American Institute of Architects. The first was for "Green Design" and the other for "Urban Design." The team of JENNIFER MADDEN & JEFFREY REED has sold is represented by many works throughout the San Francisco Bay Area. "Sun Flowers" was commissioned by the Public Art Commission and funded by the City of Palo Alto, the City of Palo Alto Utilities, and the California Avenue Area Development Association (CAADA)." -Palo Alto Public Art Community

properties.name: Sundance the Steakhouse (1974-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  1921 El Camino Real, Palo Alto, CASundance the Steakhouse in 2008. This was once the home of the Stanford View Barbecue.

properties.name: Sunrise of Palo Alto
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  An assisted-living center at the corner of El Camino and Page Mill.

properties.name: Sutter Avenue (1950-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Sutter Avenue is located in the 1950 Golden Gardens tract. John A. Sutter\'s mill was the site of the discovery of gold by James Marshall in 1848. Coincidentally, the cover sheet of the Golden Gardens tract map contained the name of Lewis Sutter, vice president of the bank which financed the tract. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Suzanne's Muffins (1986-2000)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory 376 University is the current address of Palo Alto\'s latest Starbucks. In the 1990s it was the home of Suzanne\'s Muffins, a company which began in the Bay Area in 1986 and grew to 10 stores before it was sold off in 2000 by founder Suzanne Epstein.

properties.name: Swain Way
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Swain Way is named for Robert Swain, Stanford professor of chemistry and city council member for 13 years, including mayor 1914-1916. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Swain's House of Music
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory What is the Apple Store in 2009 was for years Swain\'s House of Music, where Jerry Garcia of the Grateful Dead once worked. Photo #1: 2007 Photo #2: Circa 1960 Photo #3: 1985 Photo #4: Ca. 1960 Photo #5: In 1941, it was a store called "K&T," as seen in this photo. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Syntex Agribusiness (1962-1994)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "Syntex was founded more than 60 years in Mexico and relocated to Palo Alto in 1962, rising to success on the strength of its oral contraceptives. It also produced Naprosyn, a pain killer that was a tremendous success. Naprosyn and another arthritis drug, Anaprox, accounted for 48 percent of the company\'s sales in 1992. But the two drugs lost their patents at the end of that year, triggering large financial losses for the company. The company also lost the faith of Wall Street investors, as its stock price plummeted from 4 a share in January 1992 to 8 a share in mid-1993. Syntex stock stood at about 4 a share in October when Roche purchased the company for a reported .3 billion." -Palo Alto Weekly 1/18/95 Syntex was integrated into the Roche group in 1994. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Tab Products Co.
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Tab Products Co. on California Avenue in the Stanford Research Park. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Taijiquan Tutlage of Palo Alto (1973-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Taijiquan is the pinyin version of spelling T\'ai Chi Ch\'uan (which is also sometimes seen as tai chi chuan, taichichuan, tai chi, taichi, or taiji). Pinyin is the system adopted in 1979 for transliterating Chinese ideograms (characters) into the Roman alphabet (pinyin is the official system of romanization for China and became the United Nations Standard in 1977). -TTPA Website

properties.name: Tamarine Restaurant (2003-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  546 University Ave, Palo Alto, CA"Anne Le is the owner of Tamarine, a beautiful Vietnamese restaurant that took over the spot where Perry\'s previously resided. Le\'s family also owns two other, more casual family-style Vietnamese restaurants in San Jose and Milpitas. Le\'s an experienced restaurateur and manager." -Palo Alto Weekly 6/25/03

properties.name: Telephone Company Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Historic Buildings Inventory as revised in 1981: "On the site, the first elementary school of the town was built in 1893; in the \'teens and \'twenties small residences were occupied by some of the town\'s Japanese families. When it opened in 1929 the new Telephone Company Building provided customer services on the ground floor and housed its switchboards on the second floor. Two decades passed before the need for expansion led to construction of a major connecting building at the rear which, by 1955, extended to another large structure fronting Hamilton Avenue." Photo #1: 1985 Photo #2: Palo Alto\'s first school in 1893. It was constructed in 2 days time. Photo #3: 1932 Photo #4: Schoolchildren in front of the school on a windy day. Photo #5: Raising the flagpole in 1893. Photo #6: Telephone switchboard operators.

properties.name: Telephone Storefront (1908-1924)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This telephone storefront was on the northside of the First National Bank Building from 1908-1924. It then moved to a Hamilton Street location.

properties.name: Tennyson Avenue Architecture
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Tennyson Avenue in Old Palo Alto is known for its many distinctive styles of architecture closely spaced together.

properties.name: Terman Middle School (2001-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Terman Middle School is located at 655 Arastradero Road in Palo Alto. The school mascot is the tiger. The original name of the school located on the site was Terman Junior High School (named after Lewis Madison Terman), unrelated to the school currently at the site. The district placed a new middle school named Terman Middle School at the site in 1999 to deal with rising enrollment. The first school year was 2001-2002. It was named after both Terman and his son Frederick Terman. The relocation was met with great controversy by local residents as the district overtook the land by eminent domain from the residing Jewish Community Center." -Wikipedia Photo #1: The Terman Middle School mascot. Photo #2: The old Terman Junior High. Photo #3: Terman Junior High School grounds (1970s). Photo #4: Terman Junior High was named after Lewis Terman, inventor of the IQ test and Stanford professor. Photo #5: Terman Middle School is named after both Lewis Terman and his son Frederick Terman, often called the "father of Silicon Valley."

properties.name: Terman Park Library (1985-2002)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Terman Park Library in West Palo Alto opened in 1985. When the Terman Middle School re-opened in 2002, however, the library was closed. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Tesla Motors (2010-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This Stanford Research Park facility is soon to be home to Tesla Motors. "The electric car manufacturer plans to spend as much as million to retrofit the facility. About 350 employees will initially work at the site, gradually increasing to 650. Tesla plans to use 40,000 square feet for office space and eventually expand that to 100,000 square feet. The other 250,000 square feet will be used for research and development as well as manufacturing of the engine, transmission and drive shaft for the all-electric vehicles that can travel 300 miles on one charge." -Palo Alto Weekly 9/25/09

properties.name: Thai City
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  3691 El Camino Real, Palo Alto, CAThai City is a restaurant at Wilton and El Camino Real.

properties.name: The 101 Looking South (ca. 1980)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking south at the northbound lane of the 101, circa 1980. On the opposite side of the freeway, a sign indicates San Antonio Road is 1/2 mile ahead. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The 8,000 Traffic Circle (1995-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1995, when a traffic circle was proposed for the intersection at Addison and Bryant, no one was particularly bothered. But when the Historic Resources Board, Architectural Review Board and the neighborhood\'s more aesthetic-minded homeowners got involved, plans for a common traffic circle slowly began to take on the characteristics of high art. Surely the custom-designed, handmade brick & ivy circle would have been attractive, but when the price tag came in at a staggering 8,000, even the North Palo Alto-dominated council could read the writing on the wall.

properties.name: The A Street Gang
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A suspected "gang" was centered here in the summers of 1993 and 1994 that created quite a bit of local press. But many residents wondered if the term gang was really accurate.

properties.name: The Agnes House (1896-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This Victorian home at 1023 Forest was built in 1896 by M.P. Madison.

properties.name: The Aquarius
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Aquarius Theater opened in 1969 (in the Age of Aquarius, naturally) and has been operated by Landmark since 1985. Photo #1: A shot of the parking lot at Emerson and Lytton. At the right is the Buick dealership which formerly stood at the Aquarius location. Photo #2: In 2006 with the indie-hit "Once" leading the marquee. Photo #3: Shortly after opening, the Aquarius is showing two classics: Best Picture winner "Midnight Cowboy" and Best Picture nominee "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid." Photo #4: An ad for Community Motors at 430 Emerson. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Ashby House (1889-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This small Victorian cottage at 1145 Forest predates Palo Alto\'s founding. It was owned by Ella Ashby and her husband, Delmar. It was originally located at 1000 block of Forest near the "island" until about 1910.

properties.name: The Barbee House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This house was at the center of a 1994 controversy during which the homeowner wished to tear down a house considered historic by some.

properties.name: The Barbie Doll Hall of Fame
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Stores at Bryant Street and Hamilton Avenue in the 1960s include Rucker\'s Uniform Shop, Schwabacher and Company, and the Pacific Telephone building. Photos #2-#5: The original home of the Barbie Doll Hall of Fame was at 325 Hamilton. They also had locations on Waverley and Ramona before Evelyn Burkhalter was forced out due to higher rents. A Palo Alto Weekly story in 1999 tells of the Doll Studio, AKA Barbie Doll Hall of Fame: "Burkhalter has one of the most remarkable collections in the world: 20,000 pieces of molded plastic that, more vividly than most history books, tell the story of late-20th century America. Burkhalter collects Barbie dolls. Since 1984, she\'s had them on display at her Barbie Hall of Fame.Almost every trend, fashion, political view, lifestyle and technological advancement that Americans have witnessed since Barbie\'s debut can be found in the dolls. And Burkhalter has every model, from the Teenage Model Barbie of March 1959 to this year\'s X-Files Barbie. You can learn a lot about what this country has gone through by wandering through the narrow aisles of the Barbie Hall of Fame. It\'s all there. The Jackie Kennedy pillbox hats and bubble haircuts of the early 1960s, the hippie movement, the transition of women into the work force, the go-go 1980s, political correctness. In Barbie, you see glamorous designer clothes and dream houses, but you also see the mundane details of family life--Corningware, camping trips, Big Macs, baby-sitting." -Palo Alto Weekly (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Barker Hotel
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Built in 1928, the Barker Hotel was a seedy downtown hotel by the 1990s. But in 1995, the City of Palo Alto tried to help its low-income residents by purchasing the hotel at a cost of 3 million dollars. The money spent was criticized by some, lauded by others. Years earlier, the hotel had been under the threat of becoming office space, which would have curtailed the amount of affordable housing in the city. After a 10 month renovation, the hotel reopened to the delight of its residents---who didn\'t see their rent raised a penny. Photo #1: The Barker Hotel in 2007 with Greg Brown\'s mural on the side of the building. Photo #2: The Barker Hotel in 1993 with Gelato Classico downstairs. Photo #3: 1985. Photo #4: Gelato Classico in the 1980s.

properties.name: The Barney Property
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Barney Property circa 1915 before the construction of the Lytton School. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Bead shop (1982-2008)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Bead Shop closed in 2008 although it still exists as an online outlet. Janice Parsons is the founder of The Bead Shop. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Birge Clark House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "This house was designed by Birge Clarkin 1936 for his family residence and helived there until his death. It has been lovingly restored by owners,Megan McCaslin & Richard Yankwich." -PAST Heritage Photo #1: February of 1994. Photo #2: Birge and Lucile Clark in 1976.

properties.name: The Bol Park Donkeys
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Certainly no image of the Barron Park neighborhood could attest to Barron Park’s countrified flavor like the sight of a man jogging through Bol Park with a donkey on leash. That would be Pericles (Perry to close friends), one of two donkeys who live at Bol Park and serve as would-be neighborhood mascots. Donkeys have lived in the 13 acre Bol Park since its farmland days in the Great Depression. Originally full of apricot orchards and strawberry fields, the land also served as a donkey pasture. It was then the property of Cornelius Bol, the long-time Stanford professor and inventor of the mercury vapor light who moved to Palo Alto from his native Holland to escape the Nazis. Bol often allowed neighborhood kids to play with and even ride the seven donkeys that grazed the pasture in those early days. And if a group of donkeys would wander from the pasture and begin marching around the neighborhood in single file --- as they were apt to do --- local kids would round them up and lead them back to pasture. It seems the donkeys have always been seen as community pets. Photo #1: The donkeys are huge favorites with Barron Park children. Photo #2: Mickey who became a Barron Park favorite even though he was known as the "braying-est donkey this side of the Holy Land." Mickey died in 1998. Photo #3: Paul Wolff and Richard Placone posing with Negrita, the Gunn mascot in 1969. Photo #4: The map\'s author poses with Miner 49er.

properties.name: The Boy Scout Hall
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  In the early part of the 20th Century, the Boy Scouts met here at Boy Scout Hall at 424 High Street.

properties.name: The Boyce House (1883-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Although it has been modernized, this is one of Palo Alto\'s earliest houses. It belonged to Anna and Samuel Boyce and stands at 955 Channing.

properties.name: The Campbell House (1909-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Historic Buildings Inventory as revised in 1981: "This Colonial Revival design owes its feeling of solidity to manipulations of fenestration and proportion. The first occupants, Mrs. Helen Campbell and her daughters, were succeeded (1913) by Mrs. Harriet Buffurn, widow of George A. Buffum; Frank L. Brown (1915), a commissioner of the Panama-Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco; Burt L. Davis (1866-1941), a prominent San Francisco insurance business man, head of various industrial firms, and father of the prominent Palo Alto physician Burt L. Davis; and, for over 20 years (1920-1942) Dr. and Mrs. John C. Silliman (1878-1935). " The house was built in 1909 and the photograph is from 1978.

properties.name: The Cardinal Hotel
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The famed Cardinal Hotel has long been a Palo Alto landmark. Completed in 1924 with help from Palo Alto architect Birge Clark, the Cardinal was the in-place to go in Palo Alto\'s early days. In its prohibition days, it even had a speakeasy in the basement. Photo #1: In 2006. Photo #2: Shortly after opening. Photo #3: Looking down Ramona. Photo #4: Inside the lobby. Photo #5: Under construction. Photo #6: Looking down Hamilton with the Medico-Dental Building just beyond. Photo #7: From high above in the 1960s. Photo #8: The modern day Cardinal. Video of Tom Wyman discussing the history of the Cardinal Hotel: http://blip.tv/file/2566152

properties.name: The Cashel House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "This well preserved home was built by Mrs. Bridget Cashel, the mother of Edward and John Cashel who started the plumbing shop at 200 Homer Avenue across the street. Early Palo Alto pioneers, the Cashel family moved to Palo Alto in 1892, and still occupies the house. The house is ornamented with diamond shaped divided lights in the attic gables, dentils under the eaves, leaded glass windows, and ornate Corinthian capitals on the porch columns." -Walking Homer Avenue http://www.homeravenue.com/Walk_Tour.htm

properties.name: The Channing House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Built in 1962-1963 by Russel V. Lee and the Palo Alto Medical Clinic. Lee wished to create a non-profit that would work with the Clinic to provide a place “where older residents could continue to participate in the affairs of our city.” Photo #1: Channing House in 2008. Photo #2: Channing House, circa 1965 Photo #3: In 2007 from the same angle Photo #4: Russel V.A. Lee in front of Channing House.

properties.name: The Cheesecake Factory (2004-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Cheesecake Factory opened at 375 University in 2004. This is the former location of Copeland Sports. Before that it was Rapp\'s shoes.

properties.name: The Children's Library
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Lucie Stern herself had suffered great hardship as a mother. Louisa and Louis Jr. both died in infancy in 1900 and 1901 and her second daughter Dorothea succumbed to pneumonia at the age of five in 1908. Her third daughter Ruth was a bright and happy girl until she began suffering epileptic seizures at the age of 12. These retarded her mental development and left her as an invalid for the rest of her life. Perhaps seeing her own children suffer helped inspire her to donate a place where the city’s children could discover the magic of books. Of course, the city’s politicians very nearly blew it by looking the proverbial gift horse in the mouth. One city councilman said he liked Stern’s gift but that he expected her to also endow the Library for future staffing costs as well. Mrs. Stern was so taken aback, she withdrew the offer. Soon, she would receive an anxious letter from the rest of the City Council apologizing and attempting to smooth Aunt Lucie’s rather ruffled feathers. Lesson Learned: When someone wants to give you a brand-new library for free, you don’t go asking if you could have a little more to man the circulation booth. Eventually, amends were made and at a ceremony on September 14th, 1940, the library was officially bequeathed to the city on behalf of Mrs. Stern, by its designer --- famed local architect Birge Clark. Note: The library was renovated in 2007 and has recently opened in grand style.

properties.name: The Children's Theatre
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1932, during those heady days of liberalism, The Children’s Theatre’s first play “The Perfect Gift” was commissioned by the Mayor\'s Committee for Unemployment Relief. By 1937, they had won their own venue at 1305 Middlefield Road donated by generous Palo Alto benefactor Lucie Stern. A public theatre, funded by government, had come to Palo Alto. Even today, funding for the Palo Alto Children\'s Theatre comes from the city. The current budget is over a half a million dollars, plus use of the building, facilities and utilities. Ticket prices are set by the City Council, and the money collected goes back to the city. Prices have been kept low --- for adults and for children --- making the Children\'s Theatre an inexpensive entertainment option for families. n the 1940’s, the Children’s Theatre became the pride of Palo Alto as none other than The New York Times published two articles on the organization. The Palo Alto Children\'s Theatre was also featured in Life magazine that year --- it was supposed to be the cover story, but it was bumped by the bombing of Hiroshima and the end of World War II, an understandable editorial decision. The Children\'s Theatre also had a half-hour weekly local radio show --- "Under the Red Tile Roof" --- in the 1940s, which drew national sponsorship. In the 1950s, the youth theater group performed "Rumplestiltskin" on KRON television in San Francisco. They also produced seven short films --- such as "Pudge," which was about the group\'s mascot, a cute cocker spaniel with big, floppy ears. Photo #1: The Children\'s Theatre in the 1940s Photo #2: The same shot in 2007. Photo #3: "James and the Giant Peach" in 1985. Photo #4: Members of the Children\'s Theatre marching at the Centennial Parade in 1994. (PAHA)

properties.name: The Circle
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Circle at the base of University Avenue was a natural meeting spot and shopping area in Palo Alto\'s early days. The building of the University Avenue overpass ended the Circle\'s prominence in Palo Alto\'s downtown, although the area is still extremely busy as the entry point of traffic to downtown. Photo #1: In 1897, the Bank of Palo Alto is at right. Photo #2: On Alma Street looking north to where it crosses The Circle on January 1st, 1939. Photo #3: Looking east down University Avenue from The Circle in 1893. Photo #4: A wide shot of The Circle. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Circle (Northside)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: A postcard of the Circle\'s northside. Photo #2: The Patrick Building and the north end of the Circle in the early 1900s, perhaps on the day of the earthquake in 1906. Photo #3: Looking from the northside of the Circle across to University Avenue circa 1900. The Bank of Palo Alto is on the corner and the bottom of Fraternal Hall can be seen down the street through the trees. Photo #4: The University Hotel in the 1920s. An ice cream store appears to be on the first floor to the left. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Circle (Southside)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: An early 20th century postcard showing the south side of The Circle. There were two small islands just south of University with some benches, a water fountain and trees. Photo #2: Smith\'s cyclery and sporting goods remained at The Circle even after the construction of the overpass. Photo #3: By the 1930s, the south side of The Circle had changed. The island now had palm trees Smith\'s dominated the block. Photo #4: Circa 1915 with The Bank of Palo Alto at far right, the islands, palm trees, benches, the water fountain and a sign out front for "Kodak processing." Plenty of parking to go around. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Clothes Closet
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: In 1985. Photo #2: The interior of the clothing store after it moved to Ramona Street in 1937. Photo #3: In 2009, this location is the Tercera Gallery (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Cordoza House (1895-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Owned after 1900 by dairy farmer Thomas Cordoza, his nine children could walk on a path through the fields to his dairy ranch near the present-day 101 Freeway. The house stands at 760 Homer.

properties.name: The Country Inn Motel
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Country Inn Motel from a postcard circa 1960 and in 2009. It is still known by the name Country Inn Motel.

properties.name: The Coupa Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Coupa Café began in 2004 and had a "wildly successful" first year according to Palo Alto Weekly. Specializing in South American coffee, specifically from Venezuela, owner Jean Paul Coupal wished to "re educate Americans about coffee." Offering coffee as well as desserts and side dishes from his home country, Coupa provides customers with a South American themed café that includes artifacts on display such as a turn-of-the-century Venezuelan green bean coffee selector and Brazilian Indian hammocks. He also imports his coffee beans directly from the South American plantation that he owns and has hired has a full-time barista (coffee expert) from Venezuela to train his staff. Photo #1: Coupa Cafe in 2008. Photo #2: The location back in 1985 when it hosted the Gallery House. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Dayan Mansion (1895-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This square house in the Classical Colonial style originally fronted University Avenue and boasted a sweeping front lawn with palm trees much like the Squire House across the street. Mrs. Dayan took charge of the landscaping of University Avenue and Alma Street in the new town. The address is 449 Seneca. Source: Gone Tomorrow

properties.name: The Decker Oak Corner
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The famed Decker Oaks that stood until 1920 that gave the building and house near this corner their names. The final photo is of one of the trees being cut down in 1920. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Deckeroak
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Centennial Buildings Tour: "When William Peacock built this towered Queen Anne house for prominent dentist Dr. Charles W. Decker it was the only structure at the comer of Waverley and University. In 1920 the lot was subdivided, a commercial building placed on University, and the large oak tree which gave the house its name, "Deckeroak," was cut down. From 1928 onward, the house was used commercially as a rooming house, cafeteria, the well-known women\'s apparel shop established by Sallie M. Greene, The Corset Shop, and an antique shop." Photo #1: Circa 1990. Photo #2: 1985. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Deckeroak Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Deckeroak Building, named for the large oak tree that stood here until 1920 was built in the Classical Revival style. The University Realty company led by William Cranston, father of future senator Alan Cranston, was the realtor that was behind the building\'s construction. Photo #1: In 1985 this was the home of Il Fornaio, the Italian Restaurant that is now at 520 Cowper. Today this building is the home of Chico\'s and Letter Perfect. Photo #2: The Decker Oak Tree cut down in 1920. Photo #3:In this early 1940s photo, you can see "The Deckeroak Building" painted on the side. Photo #4:: Letter Perfect in 2008. Chico\'s has been at this location on the corner of the building since opening in 2000. This is the former location of Boudin Sourdough and the European Cobblery.

properties.name: The Downing Block (1909-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: In 1985 Photo #2: Looking down Emerson Street in the 1920s. Stores visible include California Shoe Rebuilding, Palo Alto Piano, and Hallom Tailoring all located on Emerson Street. Photo #3: Taken after 1924, the year the Cardinal Hotel was built (far right). This building was an early home of the Palo Alto Post Office.

properties.name: The Downing House (1894-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Centennial Buildings Tour, prepared by The City of Palo Alto Historic Resources Board for the Centennial Building Celebration, April 16, 1994: "The Downing House, built by W. Matlock Campbell for T.B. and Margaret Downing, is probably the most flamboyant Queen Anne still in Palo Alto. Restored as offices in the 1970\'s, it is on The National Register of Historic Places and abounds with gingerbread, decorative shingles, gables, and a "witch\'s hat" tower. A member of the original City Council, Downing erected the Downing Block at Hamilton and Emerson. Built in 1894." The city of Palo Alto ordered the demolition of the Downing House in 1976, but Gail Woolley and the late Dorothy Regnery--who was working with her at the time--successfully requested that the house be put on the National Registry. Photo #1: 2008. Photo #2: While in disrepair before renovation. Photo #3: In bad shape: notice the open top floor window to the right. Photo #4: In earlier times. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Dunker House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Many of the city’s best known and most prestigious homes were built by Birge Clark, including the Dunker House at 420 Maple Street.

properties.name: The Eichler Club (1958-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Eichler Swim & Tennis Club is a family-friendly place for the community in Midtown Palo Alto bringing together the families through competitive and leisurely-playing tennis and swimming. Each year, over 100 children compete as a part of the Eichler Gators Swim Team, a member of the Junipero Serra Swim League (JSSL). The members may also enjoy the swimming pool and the tennis courts all year as well as taking private lessons from very experienced staff members." -Eichler Club Website

properties.name: The Elizabeth Gamble Garden Center (1904-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Georgian revival Gamble House was built in 1902, by Edwin Gamble, son of Proctor & Gamble founder James Gamble. It was one of the first houses constructed south of Embarcadero Road --- at the time not even within the Palo Alto city limits. Although the property contained a worthy nine-room, three story house, the property was truly valued for its expansive gardens as cultivated by Edwin’s daughter Elizabeth Gamble, the long-time Palo Alto resident and benefactor. A great lover of irises, the gardens boasted a world-class collection of irises and roses as well as rare trees such as a Chinese Chestnut tree, an Empress tree and a Weeping Crabtree. There was even an old carriage house built for a horse and buggy and a small tea house where Miss Gamble entertained guests. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Elwell House (1908)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Cyril Elwell came from Australia in 1902 and later was granted a degree in electrical engineering at Stanford University. In 1908, at this address, he built the first radiotelephone station on the West Coast, The following year, he founded the Federal Telegraph Company located at 913 Emerson, employing a group of scientists who would later become world-famous.

properties.name: The Emporium 1956-1996
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory When Emporium closed its doors in 1996, The Stanford Shopping Center solidified its slow progression from neighborhood mall to swanky shopping center. This was the first Bloomingdale\'s to open west of the Rockies, and Bloomie\'s pulled out all the stops to create a buzz. "The Ultimate Premiere" (do store openings really have names?) in November 1996 featured a sold-out concert that included Liza Minnelli in the parking lot. Doling out between 50 and ,000 got you inside the tent party (don\'t worry --- it went to charity), which featured a cocktail buffet catered by Paula LeDuc. 100,000 shoppers showed up the first weekend and overwhelmed the parking lot, causing shouting matches --- and in one case, some actual fisticuffs. The Stanford Shopping Center solution offered the next week --- valet parking, of course. Photo #1: Across the parking lot from near P.F. Chang\'s in 2007. Photo #2: A postcard of the mall in the 1950s. Photo #3: A busy shopping day at the Emporium.

properties.name: The Epoch Times (2003-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "The English edition of The Epoch Times launched in September 2003 on the web, and in August 2004 as a newspaper in New York. It meets a growing need for news reported and published independently, uncovering stories that have depth and meaning to people. In English, as well as in other languages, it serves a broad, international readership. The Chinese-language Epoch Times started publishing in response to the growing need for uncensored coverage of events in China. The first newspaper was published in New York in May 2000, with the web launch in August 2000. Local editions published by regional bureaus soon followed, making it the largest of any Chinese-language newspaper outside of Mainland China and Taiwan." -Epoch Times

properties.name: The Fife House (formerly)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Former location of Dr. George Fife, who spent summers in Palo Alto in the house at this address. It was built in 1905. It burned down in 1939 and the neighboring street was named after Mr. Fife.

properties.name: The Fish Market
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory 3150 El Camino Real, Palo Alto, CAThe Fish Market at 3150 El Camino Real is a concept restaurant to be sure. The interior has the look and feel --- as well as hustle and bustle --- of a real fish market. Its walls are adorned with fishing boat models, old photographs of fishermen standing proudly by their catch, and nautical ornaments of all shapes and sizes. And with its open kitchen, oyster bar, cocktail bar and lounge area, a dinner at the Fish Market is as much of an experience as a way to fill an empty stomach. However, the Fish Market is not just a concept restaurant --- it’s also the real deal. Founded in 1976, by an actual sport fisherman and a boat captain/gourmet cook, the Fish Market has always prided itself on its authenticity. They own a federally-inspected seafood facility, Farallon Fisheries, an interest in an oyster farm in Puget Sound and even a couple of fishing boats, the Pilikia III and the Temptation. And there is a real “market” in the restaurant where you can purchase raw fish to bring home to try your own hand in the seafood business. This is the former location of Uncle John\'s Pancake House.

properties.name: The Flint House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  An early photograph of the Flint family home at 1001 Forest Avenue (originally Forest Court), with the carriage house (1009 Forest Avenue) visible at the left. A windmill is visible behind the carriage house. From 1922- 65 it was owned by the Smiths, who owned Smith\'s Sport Shop on the Circle starting in 1906. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Food Closet
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Food Closet is located on the Hamilton Street side of the All Saint\'s Episcopal Church. Local donations provide can goods and produce for the 85 or so individuals who stop by on a daily basis. Volunteers hand out more than 24,000 bags of groceries every year to people who earn less than 00 a month.

properties.name: The Former AME Zion Church (1925-1965)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The recently restored former AME Zion church on Ramona has a compelling history. During the Great Depression year of 1935, the church faced foreclosure, but white and Japanese neighbors help raise enough money to save it. Palo Alto’s first historian, Guy Miller, called it “one of the city\'s brightest brotherhood-in-action episodes.” The All Saint\'s Episcopal Church --- which was predominately White --- sponsored numerous fund raising dinners to help retire the mortgage on the church. The American Legion, Shriners, Kiwanis, and Rotary Club also provided financial support and the media backed the effort in the form of Dallas E. Wood\'s "The Prowler" column in the Times. Eventually, accounts were established at all local banks for the AME Zion so that contributions could be made. On July 8, 1939 the mortgage was "burned" and the AME Zion was saved. Of course, the church is also at the heart of two of Palo Alto’s less tolerant moments -- when the African- American and Japanese-American residents were expelled from downtown Palo Alto. During World War II, Japanese-Americans on Ramona Street lost their homes and were sent to internment camps. During the 1950s, African-Americans in the neighborhood were redlined into moving to East Palo Alto. Photo #1: Boarded up in 2006. Photo #2: 1980s. Photo #3: Up on stilts during renovation. Photo #4: Ruth Anne Gray who fought to save the old church. Photo #5: In the 1970s. Video link: http://www.youtube.com/paweekly#p/u/42/dBKUYr8DCnc

properties.name: The Free Reading Room  (1897-1904)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: At this location inside Simkins Stationary Store beginning in 1896, the first informal library began. It was called the Free Reading Room by 1897 and later became the Hyde Pioneer Book Store. Photo #2: Looking west on University toward the Simkins Bookstore. Photo #3: The HW Simpkins Bookstore gutted after the 1906 earthquake. A sign on the top of the building says "Established 1892." Photo #4: During the 1906 earthquake, machinery in the Palo Alto Times office fell through the floor during the shaking. Hollingsworth Groceries stands at 170-172 University. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Fuller Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Built in the 1920s it was torn down in the late 2000s.

properties.name: The Good Karma Offices
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Dixit\'s India Arts (1940s) Photo #2: Former location of Palo Alto Post Office. A large group of men and some women stand outside the Post Office and John F. Parkinson\'s store on University Avenue on Christmas Eve, 1905. Several bicycles are parked next to the sidewalk at 161 University Avenue. Photo #3: 1993 "This building has served as an incubator for several noted Silicon Valley companies, including Logitech, Google, PayPal, and Danger, Inc. YouTube also provides this location as the example address when setting the location of an uploaded video." -Wikipedia T Mobile and the Loving Hut (2009) (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Goodman House (1897-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The former house of Southern Pacific officer T.H. Goodman is at 509 Hale.

properties.name: The HP Garage
