properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Hewlett-Packard story is legendary in Valleyfolklore. Beginning with 38 in start-up capital, the boys set to work in that one-car shed with a used Sears Craftsman drill press that Packard had lugged out from Schenectady in his car. Packard and his newly-wedded wife Lucile lived on the first floor of the house on Addison originally built for Palo Alto’s first mayor. The landlady (the mayor’s widow who charged just 45 bucks a months for rent) lived on the second floor and Bill in a little shack behind the house just big enough for a cot and a sink. The garage lit by a single, overhanging bare lightbulb, served as the research lab, development workshop and manufacturing plant for HP\'s early products, including the Model 200A audio oscillator used to test sound quality in radio and TV. Hewlett and Packard’s naming process show what an unseasoned enterprise it was. The boys flipped a coin to decide the name of the company and because Bill won, it was H-P that would one day be listed as a Blue Chip stock on Wall Street, not P-H. For the name of the first oscillator, they chose the name Model 200A, rather than 100A, which might reveal the greenness of the company. And for the product’s original price, the boys chose 4.40, as in “54-40 or fight,” James Polk’s old presidential campaign slogan. These were truly the whims of business world newcomers. While some of their early clients were of the local variety---they helped invent a foot fault indicator for a San Mateo bowling alley---in 1939, HP gained a more prestigious client. They sold 8 of their audio oscillators to Walt Disney to test the state-of-the-art soundtrack for Fantasia. HP used those profits to move to a larger space, at Page Mill Road, and hire a few employees. They were on the road to eventually establishing a 90 billion dollar a year company with over 150,000 employees--- a company that is largely credited for laying the foundation for what would become Silicon Valley. Photo #1: The HP Garage in early days. Photo #2: The restored HP Garage. Photo #3: Inside the restored house. Photo #4: Packard with the oscillator. Photo #5: Packard and Hewlett at their garage before renovation. Photo #6: The boys in earlier days. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Hotel President (1929-1968)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Hotel President’s legacy dates back to 1929. Stanford’s Herbert Hoover was president and the brand new hotel put up on University Avenue reflected the city’s pride in their local hero. The Hotel President, designed by another local --- architect Birge Clark --- was six stories tall and contained 125 rooms. Built in that decade’s trendy Spanish Colonial Revival style, the Hotel President boasted a lush roof garden, a beautiful beamed ceiling lobby and a grand spiral staircase that climbed all the way to the top floor. A brochure from the era, advertising the hotel’s “gracious living,” pointed to its “large, comfortably furnished guestrooms,” each of which had “outside exposure and a private bath.” The hotel even featured in-room radio service, allowing guests to choose between channels as they showered, shaved, or relaxed in their suite. But after decades as Palo Alto’s fashionable place to stay, the President began to falter in the 1950s as more easily accessible competition began to sprout up along the edge of town. And as downtown began to lose shoppers in the 1960s, Palo Alto’s leaders feared that University Avenue could suffer an economic collapse. Some of the policy changes they experimented with had a negative impact on the Hotel President. For instance, the city’s brief experiment with making University Avenue a one way street hurt business at the hotel. New signing restrictions were also detrimental, according to the owners at the time. The Hotel President was forced to take down its enormous rooftop sign, making it more difficult for out-of-towners to find the hotel. Additionally, the modernist mini-skyscraper built caddy-corner to the Hotel President at 525 University, demoted the hotel’s prominence on Palo Alto’s skyline. It also suffered from the end of the Lark and the Daylight, Southern Pacific’s Los Angeles to San Francisco trains that once stopped the base of University Avenue --- and brought tourists to stay at the Hotel President. After the hotel converted to studio apartments and became the “President Hotel Apartments,” a predictable decline began. Over the course of the next few decades, the building became a sad version of its former self. As it aged, improvements were foregone and the rooms that were luxurious for 1930s guests, now seemed stiflingly confined and aged as modern-day apartments. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Huttman House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Centennial Buildings Tour: "Identical to 1022 Webster, this home was possibly first occupied by D.C. Burns. From 1904-1958, it was the home of Mr. & Mrs. Emil Huttman. Huttman was a gardener on Menlo Park\'s Bassett estate."

properties.name: The Hyde House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The house at 301 Addison St was the residence of the W.F. Hyde family in the early 20th Century. "This brown shingled residence exemplifies one of the principal stylistic modes, the shingle style, that characterized early Palo Alto residential construction." -Historic Buildings Inventory Photo: The 3rd photo is from 1978.

properties.name: The Inner Lives of Teenagers (2001-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Palo Alto artist ELIZABETH LADA competed her mural in 2001 on the wall of Long’s Drugs, in the Midtown District of Palo Alto, 2701 Middlefield Road. The work was commissioned by the Public Art Commission and funded by the City of Palo Alto." -Palo Alto Public Art Commission

properties.name: The Irish Cottage
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The former location of the Irish Cottage.

properties.name: The Iron Works
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: Compadres Mexican Bar and Grill closed in September of 2008. It opened in January of 1985 and was once rated in the Top 500 Mexican restaurants in the country by Restaurant Hospitality Magazine. Photo #2: The Iron Works in front of Jack in the Box (in the photo angle) was an actual wrought-iron shop that was converted to a restaurant also called the Iron Works, which later morphed into Compadres.

properties.name: The John Adams Squire House (1904-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Squire House was designed in 1904 by famed architect T. Paterson Ross for unofficial weatherman and official Stanford lecturer John Adams Squire, he a direct descendant of President John Adams. The seven bedroom mansion was built for 6,000 (a whopping sum in 1904) and would survive the 1906 earthquake, numerous termite invasions, and even the roller skating parties of the Squire girls. The effort to save “the grand old lady” of University Avenue would mark the dawning of the preservation movement in Palo Alto. 1969, Gail Woolley started her quest to save historic old homes in the city, authoring a booklet called “Gone Tomorrow,” which told the stories of endangered Palo Alto houses. Her involvement soon broadened and she became a key player in the Palo Alto Historical Association’s fight to save the Squire House from the wrecker’s ball. Eventually Woolley (a future Palo Alto mayor herself) and the Association convinced the city to purchase the house for 0,000. There was a catch, however: they would have to raise the money to pay the city back within a year’s time. Woolley’s “Save the Squire House” committee went into fundraising overdrive. A “Save the Squire House Art Show” was held in the lobby of the Palo Alto Times depicting old Palo Alto buildings and scenes. Contributions were also sought between and ,000 to “do something for tomorrow, today!” By 1973, the 0,000 had been raised and the Squire House became the first house in Palo Alto to be preserved. A movement had begun. Photo #1: The Squire House in 2007. Photo #2: From the same angle circa 1930. Photo #3: In disrepair in the 1970s. Photo #4: Saving the "Old Lady" of University Avenue. Photo #5: One of the Squire family daughters lies in a haystack behind her home on University Avenue with the Tobey House at 567 Hale Street visible in the background. Photo #6: Some teenagers and a snowman enjoy the company of the Squire House in perhaps 1976. Photo #7: Under construction in 1904. Photo #8: Surrounded by much shorter palm trees. Photo #9: With really short palm trees.

properties.name: The Juana Briones House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The following is from the Centennial Buildings Tour: "The Juana Brioncs House, State Historic Landmark #524, is Palo Alto\'s oldest home and has been occupied continuously for over 140 years [1979]. The original house is a three room section of the existing building (two wings and a central courtyard were added in 1908). Its walls, a wooden cribe filled with adobe soil, have been covered with cement to preserve and strengthen them. She was a farmer and rancher known for her hospitality and healing skills, and was a pre-eminent woman of Spanish and Mexican times." Photo #1: February or March 1901. West side from the southwest. Photo #2:1925, or shortly thereafter. Aerial photo taken in a southerly direction. The lane leads to the house in the center of photo. No road continues over the hill. Photo #3: Original is a blue and white print taken in the 1880s or early 1890s. East side. The attic entrance appears to have been more solidly enclosed--without windows Photo #4: Protesters rally to save the old house. Photo #5:In 2008. Photo #6:Taken April 5, 1963 by San Francisco News-Call Bulletin. Rock wall encloses fourth side of patio. Four chimneys are surfaced alike. Note original chimney now is on the east slope of roof." Photo #7:Taken Dec. 16, 1962 by San Jose Mercury-News. Interior of sourh wall and concrete fireplace. Source: PAST Heritage

properties.name: The Kathleen Norris House (1923-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory An old house can hold many stories and such is the case with the monumental Norris House at 1247 Cowper Street. It was built in a time of decadence, just before the crash when money seemed no object. The Norrises were writers and Kathleen was one of the highest paid women in America. She wrote dime-store novels, mostly about virtuous women dealing with moral issues (like having affairs with married men) and cashed in enough to build an unthinkable 1,000 home. The house included 12 bedrooms a four-car garage, a secretary\'s office, an outdoor "Spanish kitchen" the size of a cottage, a croquet lawn and several fireplaces. And of course, it was designed by Palo Alto\'s most treasured architect, Birge Clark---designer of the Cardinal Hotel, the post office and other historical bedrocks of Palo Alto. Also known as La Casa Abierta.

properties.name: The Kee House (1889-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Built in 1889, it is the oldest house in College Terrace.

properties.name: The Ledyard Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1 shows the building just before it was taken down. A sign on the outside says "New Building to be Erected November." Photo #3: The corner of Emerson and University where the Ledyard Building stood in the late 1890s. Photo #2, 5, 6: This was later the site of Frazer\'s Dry Goods that was badly damaged in the 1906 earthquake. Photo #4: In 1904 before the earthquake. Photo #7 The building was rebuilt and eventually was occupied by such businesses as Lytton Savings Bank, Cornish & Carey Realtors, Ross Dress for Less and Magnolia Wi-Fi. Photo #8: Under construction in July, 1914. Thoit\'s Shoe Store is to the right. Photo #9: As Montgomery Ward, circa 1940. Notice the rather aggressive driving at the Emerson & University intersection. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Lucie Stern House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Birge Clark built this house for Lucie Stern, Palo Alto\'s greatest benefactor, next to that of her daughter, Ruth Stern. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Magic Forest
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1971, the redwood grove on Hopkins Street behind Rinconada Pool was named The Magic Forest by unanimous City Council motion in memory of Edith Ellery Patton. Miss Patton was a devoted Walter Hays teacher who took generations of her students to the grove. Source: PAHA\'s Parks of Palo Alto Photo #1: The Rinconada Adult Pool with the Magic Forest behind it (2007). Photo #2: Looking up into the Magic Forest in 2007.

properties.name: The Mail-Dispatch (1946-1948)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "A small local weekly newspaper with a crusading editorial policy and free delivery to all Midpeninsula mailboxes springs up to challenge the dominant Palo Alto-based daily, holds its own and scores a few scoops. From December 1946 until August 1948, a six- to 12-page tabloid called the Mail-Dispatch took on the Palo Alto Times, the Redwood City Tribune and the San Mateo Times, delivering homespun journalism to nearly 30,000 homes in Palo Alto, Menlo Park, Atherton, Redwood City, Mountain View, Los Altos and eventually San Carlos and Belmont.The little paper churned out local news and columns from a small second-story office at 131 University Ave. in Palo Alto. A certain young journalist named Alan Cranston, Stanford class of \'36, wrote a column on "World Affairs." -Palo Alto Weekly 4/13/94

properties.name: The Marc
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Marc Palo Alto, an urban apartment building. It was formerly the Forest Towers. Photo #1: As Forest Towers. Photo #2: The Marc stands out prominently on Palo Alto\'s skyline. This photo was taken from City Hall. Photo #3: A dolphin stands out front marking The Marc\'s entrance. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Median Strip Panhandling Ban
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory in the median panhandling ban, council members argued that “Selling articles or soliciting donations in the medians of the city streets…creates a real hazard to both solicitors and drivers themselves.” Continually, supporters claimed that the cause of the ban had nothing to do with panhandling, but was about driver distractions. But according to a Palo Alto Police report, “Intersections where panhandlers and solicitors often stand have no higher rate of collisions” than any others. Furthermore, police found that of 88 accidents at these intersections, not one listed soliciting from medians as its cause. As opponent and councilmember Jim Burch argued, "We\'re singling out a dozen people in five locations and making a law against them. People who drive while talking on cell phones are a bigger hazard than the 12 to 14 people who stand on medians." Time and time again, those in support of the bans argued that public safety was the issue. But to those who feel that the city was simply trying to get rid of its less desirables, such arguments seemed artfully disingenuous at best.

properties.name: The Medico-Dental Building (1927-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The Medico-Dental Building designed by Birge Clark, circa 1960. Photo #2: 1985 (University Art on the bottom floor to the right). Photo #3: A colorized postcard circa 1928, soon after the building opened in 1927. Photo #4: Circa 1930. Notice the old standing clock on Ramona. Photo #5: Construction underway next door to Birge Clark\'s Medico-Dental Building. Photo #6: The same view in 2007 looking west down Hamilton toward the Medico-Dental Building. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Miller House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The following is from the Centennial Buildings Tour, prepared by The City of Palo Alto Historic Resources Board: "This fine Queen Anne house, richly embellished with Victorian ornamentation, has a rectangular corner tower set at an angle and surmounted by a pyramidal roof. Original owner, Walter Miller, Stanford\'s first Latin professor, required his children to memorize Latin conjugations before eating breakfast. A later owner, Michael Carney, was a Mayfield mayor." Photos from 1978 and 1992.

properties.name: The Nevada Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Former home to Starbucks and Noah\'s bagels. In 1995 Roxy Rapp was one of many downtown business owners who pushed for and eventaully won a 20 feet smoking ban outside his Palo Alto\'s Starbucks at 276 University Avenue. As in many cities which have attempted outdoor smoking bans, the issue was divisive. In this case, not only were smokers and non-smokers on opposite sides of the issue, but for many Palo Altans, homelessness was also at the heart of the matter. Photo #2: In 1996, councilwoman Micki Schneider was attacked by a homeless man outside Noah’s Bagels on University Avenue. The attack came while the police chief, Gary Fazzino, Schneider and other city officials were making a tour of a popular downtown homeless hang-out. The attacker, Anthony Feipel, was angry that the council members had thrown some trash away which he claimed were his possessions. Schneider was bruised but not seriously hurt. Photo #3: The building at the corner of University and Bryant in the mid 1950s undergoing renovation. Photo #4: Kids lined up outside the Palo Alto Hardware Company (circa 1930). Photo #5: The Nevada Building hosting the Palo Alto Hardware Company. Photo #6: From above in the early 1940s with Palo Alto Hardware Company featuring Sherwin-Williams paints. Photo #7: The Nevada Building in the 1920s. A bowling alley is open next door. Photo #8:: Circa 1915.

properties.name: The North Face
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This unlikely retail location is the home of the North Face in 2009. It was once home to Sierra Designs, as in the 1980s photo. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The O.S. Hoover House (1893-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This house and its twin next door were built in 1893 by Henry Hook and his son.

properties.name: The Oaxacan Kitchen (2008-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Oaxacan love story Palo Alto is the beneficiary, so to speak, of a powerful love story. It is the site of the first-ever Oaxacan restaurant in this area, which will be located on Birch Street in the California Avenue shopping district. The love story begins decades ago, when Palo Altan Ron Kent met Oaxacan-born Zaida. "I fell in love with her and then I fell in love with Oaxacan food," Kent said. The result has become a unique culinary experience. Ron\'s extensive background of French cuisine in five-star restaurants combined with Zaida\'s knowledge of her native dishes resulted in an authentic Oaxacan cuisine family business with a French influence." -Palo Alto Weekly 10/17/07

properties.name: The Old Pro
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Ramona\'s back in 1985. Photo #2 & 3: Today it is the Old Pro which moved a few years back from its former location on El Camino Real. A very popular sports bar downtown. Other restaurants that have occupied the same space on Ramona: Mackie\'s Supper Club, Moe\'s and Enrique\'s.

properties.name: The Old Pro (1964-2005)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The former location of the Old Pro. A new building now stands there hosting an AT&T outlet.

properties.name: The Opportunity Center (2006-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "The Opportunity Center opened in September 2006. It provides stable housing for more than 100 people who had been homeless (including more than 25 children). As a core part of the services at the center is the Opportunity Health Center, a nonprofit medical clinic that provides primary care and mental-health care to the clients of the center." -Palo Alto Weekly 12/12/07

properties.name: The Palo Alto (1960-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: Inside one of the condos in 1973. Photo #2: The Palo Alto Condominiums can be seen in this aerial photo at the right of the photo. Photo #3: 101 Alma dwarfs its surrounding neighbors. Photo #4: The demolition of the Hart-Parker residence at 101 Alma in 1958. Photo #5: The 101 Alma apartments. Photo #6: 101 Alma from across the pool.

properties.name: The Palo Alto Creamery
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Palo Alto\'s most famous spot to get a milkshake, the Creamery has a long tradition and old-time atmosphere that makes it a must for any tour. It is probably known best for its 18 flavors of milkshakes and bigger-than-your-hand hamburgers, but the mid-century ambiance is what vaults it ahead of other local greasy spoons. The walls feature posters for old-style cookies and drinks like Yoo-hoo (which is still around) and Green River? (maybe not so much). There is also a collection of items such as old style speakers, a working jukebox, early televisions and standing hat racks that recall another time. And the fifties style incorporates more than just the atmosphere. An authentic Woolworth’s-style soda-jerk behind the lunch counter will make you a Chocolate Coke, an Egg Float or one their famous milkshakes served in one of those stainless steel cups. Photo #1: 2008 Photo #2: Ca. 1940 Photo #3: 1985 (looking worn-out)

properties.name: The Palo Alto Drug Company (Ca. 1941)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Palo Alto Drug Company and Harry\'s are seen in here during the May Fete Parade in the early 1940s. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Palo Alto Office Center (525 University)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Completed in 1965, this 15 story “suburban skyscraper” recalls the dominance of the city’s once powerful commercial establishment, which had dreams of making Palo Alto into the region’s premiere business center. In fact, original plans called for twin 15 story structures with a much larger central plaza featuring fountains, promenades and additional upper walkways. But in the late 1960s and early ‘70s, anti-growth “residentialists” took control of the city and scuttled other proposed emblems of a growing downtown --- notably, an 18 story hospital project in 1970 and the twin-towered “Superblock” commercial project the following year. By 1974, a residentialist-dominated Council had put a 50 foot height limit on all Palo Alto buildings. Today the Palo Alto Office Center stands as a lonely, oversized monument to a path not taken, an alternate vision of what Palo Alto never became. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Pappas House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Historic Buildings Inventory as revised in 1985: "This structure is important as an attractive remnant of a neighborhood now largely changed. Its unusual form and decorative touches lend importance to this Craftsman house. It was originally owned by R.F. Mettman. Since 1926 it has been the family home of the Pappas family. At the time of World War I, three brothers, Gus, Jim, and Tom, emigrated from Greece. Upon arrival in Palo Alto in 1922, they bought the Orpheum Cafe on the Circle and renamed it the New Orpheum. It was a leading city restaurant until 1939, when business dropped away after completion of the University Avenue underpass. During the Depression, they served soup and sandwiches freely to the unemplbyed, and continued to do so for many years on holidays. Thomas Pappas, the last surviving brother, died in at age 97, the day after the death of his son, Danny." Photo taken in 1978. Source: PAST Heritage

properties.name: The Plantation Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The former home of the Plantation Cafe was on the first floor of the Palo Alto Central condominiums. It is apparent in this 1980s photo at left. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Point
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "The Point," by Richard F. Shirley and John M. Kennedy, was dedicated in 1980 "to the beauty and poetry of the Baylands." On it is a plaque with a poem on the Baylands by Tom Walker. The sculpture is a popular climbing structure for children and a shelter for ground squirrels. -Ronald Horii, Palo Alto Baylands Website

properties.name: The Prolific Oven
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Prolific Oven is notedfor its baked treats and goodies. Offering a small sandwich menu and assortment of coffees, the Prolific Oven has had catered to a small, but loyal group of customers since opening nearly ten years ago. It is part of a three store chain and owned by Henry Chan. It\'s a long-time "Best of" winner in the Palo Alto Weekly. This site is also the former home of Fred Eyerly\'s Hardware store. Eyerly was also a mayor of Palo Alto and is pictured above in 1983. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Roller House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Historic Buildings Inventory as revised in 1985: "According to Community Book 160, the block which contains 448 Addison was originally to be a park but, the 0,000 purchase was voted down in 1919. From the beginning to 1976, this was the home of Milton B. Roller, a member of one of Palo Alto\'s earliest families. By the time of his death, he had logged over seventy years of daily commuting to San Francisco via the SP railroad. He was a superlative lighting designer for the Phoenix Day Co. Among his best-known works were the Chinatown street lamps and the great chandelier of the War Memorial Opera House in San Francisco. His first wife, Janet, was a teacher at Addison Elementary School for many years." Photo was taken in 1978.

properties.name: The Rosebrook House (1893-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The following is from the Centennial Buildings Tour: "Rosebrook House, a Queen Anne cottage, has the style\'s typical bay window, turned columns and jigsaw ornament, and fragments of the 19th century landscaping. It was built by Sheldon and Mosher for Mrs. Rosebrook, a charter member of the Palo Alto Women\'s (sic) Club and active in the Unitarian Church, women\'s suffrage, and the Women\'s Christian Temperance Union."

properties.name: The Ruth Stern House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This house was designed by Birge Clark for Lucie Stern\'s daughter, Ruth.

properties.name: The Sailing Station
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "This is the Sailing Station dock. A 180-foot ramp leads out to the dock. The dock has been recently renovated, but it is the last reminder of the Palo Alto Yacht Harbor\'s nautical past. However, no more can large yachts and sailboats sail into the harbor. The dock is a launching point for small craft, such as canoes, kayaks, and wind surfers." -Ronald Horii

properties.name: The Schmidt Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The Schmidit Building was built in 1922 by Charles Baker. It was home to a market and Alan\'s Shoe Repair in 1985. In 2009 it hosts the Thaiphoon Restaurant. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Secret Garden
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A tucked away place behind the Children\'s Library where kids can read and relax.

properties.name: The Sit-Lie Ban
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The hyper-controversial “sit-lie ban” may have been the most divisive issue in the politics of 1990\'s Palo Alto. It signified a city at odds with itself over its attitude toward the homeless. Passed in March 1997 by a 7-2 vote after a long public debate in the media, opposition to the ban was heartfelt and angry. On the night Council finally took up the question, more than 50 people signed up to speak against the ban and only 20 had finished before the meeting was adjourned due to the late hour. Defenders of the poor said the law was designed as an end-run around anti-panhandling laws, which have yet to be ruled constitutional---and to keep the homeless from tarnishing Palo Alto\'s well-to-do image. The Police and Chamber of Commerce said it was an issue of public safety. They argued that University Avenue had become increasingly crowded, and teens and homeless sitting on the sidewalks were creating safety hazards, particularly for senior citizens. Homeless advocates countered frequently that the police could not cite a single documented incident of anyone tripping on another person downtown. For the record, the law bans sitting or lying on a seven block stretch on University Avenue sidewalks between High and Cowper Streets from 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. The sidewalk next to Lytton Plaza at University and Emerson Street was designated as an exception area to allow for any First Amendment speech activities involving sitting or lying.

properties.name: The Slonaker House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: The Sunbonnet House (1899-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "Preeminent bohemian architect Bernard Maybeck, who also created the Palace of Fine Arts in San Francisco, originally designed the cedar-shingled 1899 residence, located at 1061 Bryant St. The Sunbonnet House was one of Maybeck\'s earliest works, and is believed to be the oldest still standing intact." -Palo Alto Weekly 8/4/04 Photo #1: The Sunbonnet House, date unknown. Photo #2: Bernard Maybeck Photo #3: 2006

properties.name: The Thoits Building
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Thoits Building was one of Facebook\'s Palo Alto locations until recently. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Thoits House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Historic Buildings Inventory as revised in 1985: "The structure is a two-story wood frame building with hipped roofs and shiplap siding, in ar restrained and markedly consistent version of Colonial revival design. Edward K. and Elizabeth Thoits, for whom the house was built, came to Palo Alto in 1893. Thenceforth the Thoits family occupied a prominent place in the city\'s business and civic affairs. Thoits had been a seaman in his youth and then went into business before his death in 1897. His son, Edward C. Thoits, attended Stanford (A.B. l898) and continued and expanded his father\'s business (shoe merchandising, investment, real estate). He began his civic career as a member of the Library Board in 1909, served as mayor 1913-1914, and was a City Councilman for over 40 years (died 1951, age 74). This house was built in 1897." Photo was taken in 1978.

properties.name: The Tobey House (1904-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Behind one of John Squire\'s daughters is the house at 567 Hale Street in this early 20th Century photo. It cost 8,000 to build and even the barn had 4 rooms. Mr. Tobey had accumulated a fortune in the lumber business in Nevada. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: The Varsity Theatre
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Varsity Theatre opened in 1927 and inspired a half-century of memories as a one-screen first-run theatre and later revivial house. Buddy Rich, Van Morrison, jazz duo Tuck and Patti, and Count Basie all played there. The theatre operated until July of 1994. That year a "Save the Varsity Committee" was formed in an attempt to find a group willing to put up the -8 million dollars to save the theatre. At the first City Council meeting devoted to the subject, there were so many speakers ready to speak for saving the Varsity that the meeting was essentially fillibustered. Many speakers aimed to have the city purchase the building to become a Perfoming Arts center, but neither the city nor a benefactor (such as David Packard who stepped forward to save The Stanford down the street) appeared on The Varsity\'s behalf. While the committee lost the war, it was instrumental in winning the battle of saving the outward Mission Revival style courtyard and the Varsity marquee. Keenan did basically start anew inside the theatre, converting the theater into a 23,000-square-foot, two-story bookstore and espresso cafe. Photo #1: In 1985 featuring the Uptones and Zusu Pitts. Photo #2: The Varsity Theatre in 1970 with "Love Story" on the marquee. Photo #3: Circa 1930. Photo #4: In the 1970s featuring Timber Creek. Photo #5: In 2008 as Borders Books & Music. Photo #6: Late in its life, the Varsity Theatre was turned into a restaurant, bar and theatre and re-named the "New Varsity." Photo #7: The New Varsity\'s restaurant area was in the courtyard. Note the names of famous Hollywood stars on the back of the seats.

properties.name: The Vipham House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Historic Buildings Inventory as revised in 1985: "This house was built in 1925. It was the home for thirty-five years of Thomas and Margaret Vipham and their descendants, to 1962. It has been a rental unit since then. The Viphams were natives of England who came to Palo Alto in 1924. He was a plastering contractor and his sons John, Howard, and Edwin followed the same trade for a number of years before taking up other occupations." Photo taken in 1978.

properties.name: The Walla Walla Onion Bank
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory250 Lytton Street, Palo Alto, CaliforniaNow a Comerica, the University Bank had gained fame in the 90\'s for its charming marketing gimmicks such as giving away 10 pound bags of Walla Walla Sweet Onions once a year to customers. The bank also has a mural of a flying spaceship crashing into its side and its delivery truck had a prison convict painted on the door, peering out from behind bars.

properties.name: The Westin (2000-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This is the former location of The China First restaurant.

properties.name: The Williams House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1994, the city commenced an attempt to find a suitable resident for the former Williams House. A host of non-profits including a center for non-verbal therapy for childhood trauma victims, a historic clothing society and chocolate factory (an odd juxtaposition?), and a care center for deaf children were among the applicants. Eventually, the decision came down to the proposals from the Museum of American Heritage and the Pacific Art League. And even after the city awarded the site to the museum, the process almost reverted back to square one again when the museum submitted a sizable building alteration plan to the city. Fearing that the Williams House might never be filled, Council member Gary Fazzino joked at one meeting that “given the amount of time we\'ve spent on this issue in the last three years, we\'re probably discouraging Palo Altans from including the city in their wills.” Eventually, however the Museum of American Heritage went forward with their plans. Once established, both have become local favorites and wonderful ways for Palo Altans to take in a lazy weekend day..

properties.name: The Wine Room  (2007-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "The Wine Room is housed in an architectural gem at 520 Ramona St., designed by artist and craftsman Pedro de Lemos, according to the National Register of Historic Places. Developing buildings in the 500 block of Ramona Street, de Lemos incorporated Spanish and early-California styles with tile roofs of varying heights, wrought iron, graceful archways and courtyards. In 1985, the area was designated as a Historic District in the National Register." -Palo Alto Weekly 3/7/08 In 1925 this address was the Gotham Shop. From 2001-2006, this was home to the Bay Leaf Cafe. Before that it was Double Rainbow Gourmet Ice Cream and Dessert Cafe. Photo #1: In 1985.

properties.name: The Wing House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Centennial Buildings Tour: This was designed by A.B. Clark and built by George Mosher for Charles Benjamin Wing, professor of civil engineering at Stanford from 1892-1945. Wing helped restore Stanford after the 1906 quake, designed and built Stanford\'s Stadium, and was influential in the development of Big Basin State Park. He served as city councilman for 25 years and as mayor from 1901-09. This house was built in 1893. Renovated in 2009.

properties.name: The Winter Lodge
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory On February 15th, 1956, “The Winter Club” opened in a largely undeveloped area along Middlefield Road. It was an immediate hit. California ice was a skate down memory lane for the many non-native Palo Altans who spent their childhood winters twirling triple salchows or falling on their backsides at rinks back East. While for home-grown California kids, lacing up winter skates had a novelty appeal --- and a little taste, perhaps, of what they were missing in a single-climate region. Today it is known as the "Winter Lodge."

properties.name: The Woman's Club of Palo Alto
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "On June 20, 1894, 24 women gathered together to formally organize the Woman\'s Club of Palo Alto. Their goals were self-improvement, mutual help and community work, and they didn\'t waste any time fulfilling them. Within the first four years of the club\'s existence, they had founded the city\'s first reading room and library, as well as its first elementary school and high school. Their dream of having their own clubhouse, however, was not realized until 1916. After twelve years of continuous fundraising they managed to raise ,300, and their Tudor-Craftsman-style "home" was designed by Charles E. Hodges, a noted architect of the day. As so often happens, there were cost overruns and final cost of construction was 0,590. At the time, they worried that it was too far removed from the center of town, but its location in a quiet residential neighborhood has proved a felicitous one." Source: Palo Alto Woman\'s Club (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Theodore Roosevelt Speech
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Theodore Roosevelt is seen speaking to spectators at The Circle after arriving on the Southern Pacific. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Thiele Building (1906)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: This was the site of the Campus Garage in the 1930s and 40s. The signs indicate that they sold Chrysler and Plymouth used cars. Photo #2: Before it was the Campus Garage, this building was known as the Depot Garage and sold "Dodge Brothers Motor Cars." (ca. 1910) Photo #3: Palo Alto physician Dr.Clelia D. Mosher described the 1906 earthquake devistation to the Thiele Building: “Mr. Thiele had recently completed a 0,000 building of concrete blocks—the same material used in the Fuller Building,” Mosher noted. “Both of these buildings collapsed and were in plain view of the railway track. With the ruined [university] entrance gate to the Arboretum on the other [side], it is small wonder that people passing through on trains immediately after the earthquake should have reported Palo Alto as one of the towns very badly injured.” Source: Palo Alto, Stanford and the 1906 Earthquake Later that year a dispute took place between the city and F.C. Thiele, the owner of a fallen building that stood in ruins just across the tracks from the University Avenue Southern Depot train station. This disquieting visage led many out-of-town travelers to believe that Palo Alto had fared much worse than it had during the earthquake --- a perception problem that eventually prompted the city to take matters into their own hands. On June 4th, with the building still in shambles, the city ordered workers to clear the debris on the street and throw it back onto the Thiele property at “the owner’s expense.” The Palo Alto Promotion Committee was even planning to erect a large signboard blocking the unsightly building from the view of commuters when the wreckage was finally cleared up by the owner. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Thoits Shoe Store (1891-ca. 1948)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Thoits Shoe Store was a mainstay along Palo Alto\'s University Avenue. Here we see the outside of the store in the \'20s, \'30s and \'40s (at far right in the third photo) and the interior in 1940. In 2009, this store was empty. It was most recently a "Natural Traditions" outlet. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Thomas Seale House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This is the approximate location of the original Seale ranch house. The Seale family once owned most of the territory that makes up the part of town above present-day Oregon Expressway. After Thomas Seale died (1907) and Alfred moved elsewhere, this became the administration building of the Seale Military Academy

properties.name: Thompson's Oak Bakery
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: In 1985. Photo #2: Thompson\'s Oak Bakery, "Palo Alto\'s Best Bread," stands next to Cashel Brothers Plumbing circa 1925. Thompson\'s closed in 1937. All 3 of these buildings still stand. Photo#3: Is from 1907. The roads were not yet paved and a house stood aside Thompson\'s.

properties.name: Three Seasons (2002-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This is the former location of 42nd Street, which some credit as the bar that helped revitalize Palo Alto\'s late night scene. In 2009 it is the Three Seasons restaurant as it has been since 2002. In between it was O\'Connell\'s, an Irish pub.

properties.name: Thurlow's Smoke Shop
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Phillps-Terkel clothing store stood next door. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Tippawingo  Drive
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This street was named by Vera Young Colby, the property owner, in honor of her husband who was part Iroquois. The Indian name means "House of Happiness." Mrs. Colby also had "Tippawingo" carved on the lintel of her home. Source: PAHA\'s Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Tom Casey Field (Home of the Palo Alto Oaks)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Palo Alto Oaks semi-pro team plays here. One photo shows an older Palo Alto baseball team from 1911. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Top of the Tangent
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: The Top of the Tangent, a small folk club upstairs from a pizza parlor at 117 University Avenue featured local artists such as the Mother McCree’s Uptown Jug Champions, an early incarnation of the Grateful Dead. The Tangent downstairs was a pizza restaurant. Photo #2: A fire at Rudy\'s and Nataraja. Photo #3: Rudy\'s Pub, taking pride in itself. Photo #4: In this photo from the 1930s, the corner building is no longer, the University Avenue Hotel is to the left and Roos Bros. to the right. A sign advertises "stores to lease."

properties.name: Tower Well
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory While there was no doubt that the Tower Well off Alma Street near Menlo Park played an important role in Palo Alto\'s electrical development, the 1911 cement tower wasn\'t isn\'t an architectural marvel. During one city council debate, the city’s vice-mayor referred to it as “an 80-foot concrete bunker” He went on to say, “We\'re talking about a water tower for a city utility. It does not commemorate a major historical event." Over the years, the Palo Alto City Council rejected both attempts to turn the Water Tower into a historically protected site---as well as more creative attempts to turn it into public bathrooms, hotel rooms, condominiums, low-income housing, and even a house for restoration enthusiasts Tom and Katy Taylor. Finally, Tower Well survived as a kind of nod to utility history and remains standing today surrounded by a small park with a collection of informational plaques. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Town & Country Accident (1968)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1968, 64 year-old Audrey Haughey was attempting to park her friend\'s car in front of the S. Christian of Copenhagen glassware and home furnishings store, when her foot slipped off the brake and pushed the accelerator. The car lurched forward knocking 68 year-old Menlo Park resident Herman Ramhurst and his wife Marguerite through the store’s plate glass window and splintering a heavy wooden roof support beam. As the pillar crashed down, it pinned Mr. Ramhurst’s chest until he was able to be removed by Palo Alto police. He was pronounced DOA at Stanford Hospital due to major chest injuries. His wife escaped with only minor injuries.

properties.name: Town & Country Village (1953-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Throughout its long history, Town & Country Village ---the outdoor shopping center at Embarcadero and El Camino Real --- has gone from cutting edge to old-fashioned to cutting edge once again. And not just because the shopping center is currently being renovated and getting a few new palm trees at its entrances. Time and trends have come back around to Town & Country Village. With indoor malls now on the decline, T & C finds itself once again positioned at the forefront of what the modern shopper desires --- much as it was at its premiere more than fifty years ago. Photo #1: A 1950s postcard of Town & Country looking toward Stickney\'s Restaurant. Photo #2: Same view of Town & Country in 2007. Photo #3: An overhead view of the shopping center, perhaps in the 1960s Photo #4: Town and Country Village as seen in December, 1960. Stanford Stadium is at the bottom of the photograph and the El Camino and Embarcadero intersection can be seen be as well. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Toyota Palo Alto
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Toyota dealership at the corner of Middlefield and San Antonio Road.

properties.name: TraveLodge Palo Alto
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The TraveLodge in a 1950s postcard. Photo #2: Some 50 years later, not much has changed.

properties.name: Tree Removal at Stanford Shopping Center (1950s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A construction truck is removing a tree at the Stanford Shopping Center in the 1950s. Roos Brothers can be seen in the background. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Trinity Lutheran Church
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Trolley Barn (1907-1925)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Built in 1907 and served as the home for the PA Streetcar Line until 1925. "The tracks ran from the campus, down University Avenue, to San Francisquito Creek. A branch line turned south at Waverley Streetand ran nearly to Oregon Avenue. A short spur ran to the trolley barn on Hawthorne Avenue. November 15, 1906 was the grand opening. A school holiday wasdeclared so the students could attend the ‘Gala Day’. A number of the town’s young women acted as streetcar conductors on the first day,collecting the nickel fare which went to benefit the local churches. A balloon ascension and parachute leap were advertised. Therewere games and contests for all ages, including a ‘fat gents’ race forsome of the older men in town, and tug-of-war contests between students of competing schools." -Steve Staiger, Palo Alto Historian Link to PA Historian Steve Staiger talking about the history of the Palo Alto Trolleys. http://blip.tv/file/2538341 Photo #1: The Trolley Barn Building in the 1980s with Tower Well behind it. Photo #2: Town leaders pose with one of the streetcars on November 15th, 1906. Photo #3: The caption on this photo read, "One branch went out Waverley. Home base was the Circle. Street car line on University Avenue. Built in 1906, removed in 1929. Line extended to approximately Bayshore Highway." Photo #4: "Southern Pacific Depot" is where this trolley is headed. (PAHA Collection) This is also the former home of Gymnastics West.

properties.name: Truesdale House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The following is from the Centennial Buildings Tour: "This two-story house with its circular window in the second floor at one side, is a good example of a restrained Queen Anne design. The house was built for W.W. Truesdale, who, in 1893, owned property in this and two other blocks in the city. Commercial ofices and studios were included from 1948 onward, including the studio of Elise and Roland Wolfe, well-established local photographers."

properties.name: Uncle Jim's Cabin (1874)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: The historical plaque for Uncle Jim\'s Cabin is in this spot, although it is more likely that the original Mayfield building stood down the block where the Mayfield Theatre Building now stands. Photo #2: The southwest corner of El Camino and California in the 1940s. Photo #3: A painting of Uncle Jim\'s Cabin. Photo #4: A rather funky ATM machine from the 1980s. Photo #5: This photo shows the corner of El Camino Real and California Avenue in the mid-1980s when the San Francisco Federal Savings Bank was located here. In 2009, this is the home of Citibank.

properties.name: Uncle Jim's Cabin (Built 1853)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Several boys examine damaged cushions on sidewalk outside the Mayfield Theater on April 7th, 1950. Photo #2: This was the original location of Uncle Jim\'s Cabin, the first building in Mayfield, photographed here in 1874. Photo #3: In 1986, this was the Fine Arts Theater. Jean de Florette is playing at the cinema, while next door is the California Barber Shop. (PAHA Collection) Video Link: Steve Staiger discusses the early history of Mayfield: http://blip.tv/file/2399604

properties.name: Unicef-Cards Books & GMS Store (1974-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Unicef store buys from grass-root businesses in developing nations. They also have a collection of UN books, journals and articles. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Union Bank of California
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In this photo the current Union Bank of California is the Bank of Tokyo. (circa 1970)

properties.name: Union Stage Depot (ca. 1940)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The Union Stage Depot at the side of the old Palo Alto Hotel, circa 1940. This later became the site of the bus depot. Passengers are getting on a bus under an overhang.

properties.name: United War Work Campaign (1918)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory On November 11th, 1918, Camp Fremont soldiers marched down University Avenue. Note the flu masks that many are wearing as the march took place during the 1918 flu epidemic. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Unity Palo Alto Community Church
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "In February 1949, the “First Church of Religious Science, Palo Alto” was formed. In 1959, Rev. Docia with the support of her visionary congregants began plans for the building of a church facility. Under her leadership, a church was built at 3391 Middlefield Rd., Palo Alto. This continues as our site to this day. An interesting anecdote is that during the initial construction phase, the church was turned down by several financial institutions for a needed loan of 0,000. Rev. Docia secretly wrote a check for 0,000 to the church, signed it “God,” and put it in her desk where it lay forgotten. Some time later, a loan officer from a local Savings and Loan, reviewing the loan application, was very skeptical and said, “I don’t know how much money you anticipated but all we could loan you would be 0,000.” In 1967, Dr. Raymond Lilley, a Religious Science minister, became the spiritual leader. Under his guidance the church became an Independent New Thought church in 1980 and was known as “Palo Alto Community Church.” In 1990 the “old” church was torn down and a new facility was constructed on the Middlefield site." -Unity Palo Alto Community Church Website

properties.name: University Avenue Bridge (1920)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: University Avenue Looking West (Ca. 1949)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Looking west down University Avenue. The Stanford Theatre is at center and the Bank of America Building is at right. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: University Avenue Overpass Bridge
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This shot circa 1941 look north toward Menlo Park and was taken in the middle of El Camino Real (must have been a lot less busy in those days!).

properties.name: University Avenue Overpass Bridge
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The University Avenue Overpass was completed in 1941. This photo shows the bridge across El Camino Real soon after completion. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: University Avenue Train Station
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1941, in the final years before the great decline of the railroads, Palo Alto got itself a new train station. The Southern Pacific Railroad, then still going strong as a popular way to travel the country’s western coast, decided to replace Palo Alto’s aging depot with a sleek, modern station worthy of the city’s hard-earned hub status. The new station was constructed in the ultra-hip “Streamline Moderne” style, a look that raced with the energy of a new age and looked toward the machines of the future. It turned out to be an ironic twist. While the station’s architecture may have spoken to modernity, the transportation it served would soon nearly become a relic of the past. Photo #1: The train station in 2008. Photo #2: The station soon after opening in 1941. Photo #3: Third-party Presidential candidate John Anderson is speaking to a large crowd from the rear of a railroad car. Photo #4: Commuters wait for the Southern Pacific. El Palo Alto looms in the distance. Photo #5: An SP pulls into the station. Photo #6: Commuters waiting for the train. Photo #7: Commuters wait for the train circa 1950. El Palo Alto can be seen in the distance. A sign reads "ticket office." Photo #8: John McQuarrie’s grand --- perhaps bordering on grandiose --- mural depicts Leland Stanfordsurveying the progression of America’s expansion into the West. Photo #9: Passengers inside the station. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: University Avenue from Overpass Bridge
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Looking east down University Avenue from the overpass bridge through the years. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: University Avenue near Underpass (ca. 1970)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Emerging from the University Avenue underpass, cars head toward Palm Drive at El Camino Real. The sign that says "S.P. Only" refers to the old Southern Pacific railroad. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: University Bank & Trust (1979-1995)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Before the bank was built that currently sits on this site in 1986, this was a supermarket. Known as the Starlite Super, as well as Norm\'s, it was torn down in 1985 as seen in the photograph. It was the site of Greg Brown\'s mural "Aliens." When the new bank went up, Brown was asked to paint a new mural, which resulted in "Return of Aliens," which still graces the backside of the bank. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: University Coffee Cafe (1994-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  271 University Ave, Palo Alto, CA271 University is the ambient rich University Coffee Café. Bearing multiple personalities, this location is juice and coffee bar by morning, caters to the lunch crowd at midday and becomes a romantic sit-down restaurant at night --- no laptops allowed. Open since 1994, the cafe\'s popularity seems to assure its remaining a part of University Avenue\'s scenery for some time. The building at 271 University was built in 1929 for Georgina Ostander, one of the town\'s earliest merchants. She and her son ran a music store at 255-7 University up to the mid \'20s. Georgina died in 1941 and had been the first secretary of the Palo Alto Lawn Bowls Club.

properties.name: University Creamery
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Photo #1: This photo from the 1920s shows the University Creamery next door to the Miller Building. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: University Quality Market
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Two children walk in front of the camera during the May Fete Parade in the 1940s. Behind them on the corner of Waverley and University is the University Quality Market.

properties.name: University and High NE
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: This shot from atop the flagpole on The Circle offers a nice perspective of the buildings on the corners of High Street and University Avenue in 1931. Photo #2: As this parade shot shows, the building at the corner of University and High included Helm Real Estate, and the Waffle Shop. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: University at Cowper (ca. 1969)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Looking east down University Avenue circa 1969. The President Hotel is at the left along with the Varsity Theatre. Note that University Avenue was a four lane street and had parallel parking in those years. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: University at Emerson
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Looking west down University Avenue in the 1940s. Photo #2: Postcard from the 1930s with the Hotel President in the distance at right and the Stanford Theatre to the left. Photo #3: From a little further back in the perhaps the late \'20s. Photo #4: From a little further up the street, circa 1930. In those days the Stanford Theatre was known as the Fox Stanford.

properties.name: University at High
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The photograph indicates that this shot was taken from the flagpole at The Circle in 1931. It gives a good view of the building at High and University across from Fraternal Hall.

properties.name: University at Ramona (ca. 1930)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking east down University Avenue circa 1930. The Ramona Hotel is to the right and the First National Bank building is to the left. The Stanford Bootery is at far left. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: University at the 101 (Ca. 1962)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Looking south from University Avenue at the 101 Freeway.

properties.name: Urban Lane
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The street connecting Wells Avenue and Homer Avenue and leading to the earl;y Corporation Yard was named in honor of William and Joseph Urban, who established a gravel and sand business in Palo Alto in 1926. In 1931, they were among the first to introduce transit mix, later known as ready-mix cement. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Used Car Row
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Until police cracked down in 2008, this stretch of El Camino Real was known as an informal used car row. "Enterprising would-be car sellers — who for decades have used the stretch of El Camino Real from Stanford Avenue to Embarcadero Road as their personal car lot — now have to take their business elsewhere." -Palo Alto Weekly 1/4/08

properties.name: Vandervoort & Co. Wagonmaker and Blacksmith
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Two men pose at the entrance of the shop on Emerson Street with two wagons parked outside. Two horses are tied to the hitching on the Hamilton Avenue side of the building. A young street tree is planted between the sidewalk and the street on the Hamilton side of the building. Photo was taken in 1907. Photo #2: William P. Wrenden Books and neighbors in the late 1970s or early 80s. Photo #2: Hoofprints in the sidewalk denote the corner old mission as a blacksmith building. Photo #3: City Hall looms over these storefronts on Hamilton in 1985 including William P. Wrenden Books. Photo #4: The roof trusses were not tied to the cement block walls of Vandervoort\'s, causing this damage during the 1906 earthquake. Photo #5: This telephone store was located at 212 Hamilton from 1924-1929. Strange how there is a period at the end of the word Telephone on the sign. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Varian Associates
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Varian Associates was the park\'s first tenants when it opened a park lease in 1951. Varian Associates had been founded in 1948 by Russell H. and Sigurd F. Varian, William Webster Hansen, and Edward Ginzton to sell the klystron, the first tube which could generate electromagnetic waves at microwave frequencies, and other electromagnetic equipment. (PAHA Collection) Source: Wikipedia

properties.name: Varian Brothers House (1902-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Built in 1902, this Craftsman house was the home of the Varian brothers, inventors of the klystron tube.

properties.name: Venceremos House (1971-72)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Venceremos had its unofficial headquarters at this location on Channing Avenue. Venceremos was a communist radical group headquartered in and around Palo Alto in the late 60s and early 70s. Founded in 1966 by Aaron Manganiello, the originally Latino left-wing protest organization was named for Che Guevera’s battle cry, “We will prevail!” By 1970, Venceremos had evolved into a multicultural Maoist/Communist revolutionary brigade that was a mainstay at any mid-Peninsula protest in those years. Under the leadership of Stanford Professor and Melville scholar H. Bruce Franklin (fired in 1972 for leading a student takeover of the university’s computer lab), Venceremos took an active role in community issues and demonstrations. And these guys weren’t fooling around. Venceremos believed that “an unarmed people are subject to slavery at any time” and held vast amounts of weaponry to back it up. They had secret stashes of rifles, grenades, pipe bombs, and other explosives and they urged members to stay armed at all times --- advice that was apparently followed. With their rifle logo and violent rhetoric, Venceremos startled the local population and caught the eye of federal law enforcement. Many believed they were one of the largest revolutionary groups in the country and a 1972 House Internal Security Committee Report called the group “a potential threat to the United States.”

properties.name: Ventura Avenue
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This street was originally named San Buenaventura but the U.S. Post Office concluded that name was "too long to write and too difficult to pronounce." Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Ventura Elementary School (1968)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Ventura Elementary School as seen in 1968. Today this is the Ventura Community Center. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Victor Arnautoff Murals
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Palo Alto Medical Foundation\'s Roth Building was the site of some rather controversial murals in 1932 when it first opened. The nudity is said to have caused a local traffic jam and prompted a newspaper editorial in San Francisco. The paintings were created by Diego Rivera disciple Victor Arnautoff.

properties.name: Victor Frost
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Victor Frost is a well-known Palo Alto panhandler who often can be found across from the Whole Foods on Homer Avenue. He has run for City Council a number of times, most recently protesting the extension of the sit-lie ban. In June of 2007, the Palo Alto city council passed a controversial ordinance, nicknamed the "Victor Frost Ordinance", designed to remove him from his spot. He is still fighting the arrest in court.

properties.name: Victorian on Lytton
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: 555 Lytton in 1985. Photo #2: Susan and Max Hall, owners, pose in front of their bed and breakfast at 555 Lytton Avenue in May of 1986. (PAHA Archives)

properties.name: Village Cheese House (1959-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Recently renovated and now under new management, the Village Cheese House is still known all over the city for its great sandwiches. "The Staehnke family opened the Village Cheese House in 1959. They became the premier seller of gourmet cheese and European food items on the Peninsula. Early on in the store\'s history the Old Fashioned sandwich became popular with the Stanford and Palo Alto communities. Eventually Richard and Claudine took over operations of VCH from Richard\'s parents and expanded the selection of specialty food, candy, and beverages. After dedicating their entire careers to the Village Cheese House, they were ready to enjoy their retirement and pass the torch to the Hikens." -theVCH.com

properties.name: Village Stationers
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Village Stationers is a long-time "Best of Palo Alto" winner for best stationary store in the area.

properties.name: Vineyard Lane
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Vineyard Lane recognizes Leland Stanford\'s vineyard which was located on the site of the Stanford Shopping Center. The Stanford Barn was originally his winery. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Vino Locale
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Home of Vino Locale Restaurant. Photo #1: The restaurant hosts parties and private gatherings. Photo #2: Looking very rundown in 1985 with the Palo Alto Office Center behind.

properties.name: Wade-Mahany House (1895-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This house was built on Middlefield Road for Henry Wade-Mahany, but was moved to this location in 1910. Source: Gone Tomorrow

properties.name: Wahoo's Fish Tacos
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Formerly KFC Chicken.

properties.name: Walgreens
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This Walgreens in 2009 was the former location of the Midtown Palo Alto Co-op. Before that it was a Purity Market. There were at least 4 Purity Markets in Palo Alto --- one downtown, one on California Ave, one here and one at Stanford Shopping Center. They all had the Quanset-hut type roofs that still exist on this Walgreen\'s.

properties.name: Walgreens
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory

properties.name: Walgreens Disco Rex Pharmacy
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In the 1930s this was Crow Pharmacy.

properties.name: Walking Bridge to East Palo Alto
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Construction of a walking bridge to East Palo Alto over the San Francisquito Creek.

properties.name: Wallis Court
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Wallis Court was named for Sarah and Joseph Wallis, who came to Mayfield in 1857. Shortly thereafter, Sarah bought the Mayfield Farm of Elisha O. Crosby. Wallis was an Associate Judge in the Santa Clara Court of Sessions and was active in public affairs. Although Mrs. Wallis was involved in the social and civic life of Mayfield, her greatest honor was being elected head of the newly formed State of California Women\'s Suffrage Movement. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Walster's Apparel Dry Goods
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: Walster\'s can be seen in this photo from the 1940s as veterans of the Fire Department march in a parade. Photo #2: Walster\'s on the corner of Florence and University. Photo #3: The Fist National Bank was at this location. Photo #4: The destruction of the Walster\'s/Rapp\'s Shoes building, circa 1968. Photo #5: The staff of Medallion Rug Gallery, which is at this address in 2009. Photo #6: Destruction of the building that once held Rapp\'s Shoes and Walster\'s. Photo #7: The end of Rapp\'s Shoes. The Palo Weekly wrote about Rapp\'s Shoes in 1999 when Louis Rapp died: " Louis Rapp bought a house on Ross Road and leased the shoe department of Walster\'s department store on University Avenue. "He started on a shoestring," said Rapp\'s son, Roxy, a Palo Alto developer. Lou Rapp attended night classes at Palo Alto High School and learned how to build lawn furniture, make wallpaper, and landscape the family\'s back yard. "He was a hard-working man," he said. Within a year, Rapp left Walster\'s and went into business under his own name, opening Rapp\'s Shoes right next door. Striving for a child-friendly store, Rapp built a model railroad, bolted a playground giraffe to the floor, gave a half-dozen birds luxurious housing in a parakeet castle, and taught the store\'s myna bird, Mike, to speak eight sentences, including "I like Rapp\'s." Rapp made sure every child left the store with a balloon and let little girls choose from his selection of "diamond" rings. "He\'d bawl out a salesman for not giving a child a balloon or a diamond ring," recalled Roxy, "but never for missing a sale." If customers couldn\'t afford new shoes, Rapp often gave them shoes for free. "He never took advantage of people," said Roxy, who lives in Portola Valley. "It was very important to him to take care of customers. He knew what it was to be poor, to hurt and struggle, so he was always very generous--even when he couldn\'t afford it." Rapp\'s constant, melodic whistling as he walked to work earned him the nickname "the Whistler" from neighborhood fans. Rapp was also known as "Fabulous Lou" and "the Unofficial Mayor" for his enthusiastic greeting of University Avenue patrons. "He always had a full head of hair, a good tan and the wildest clothes--the brightest ties, the wildest shirts and suits," said Roxy. Rapp loved the sun and took his family to Santa Cruz every weekend. He also loved to dance, play golf and exercise." -PA Weekly 9/8/99 (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Walter Hays Drive
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Walter Hays Drive was named for Dr. Walter Hays (1869-1920), pastor of the Palo Alto Presbyterian Church and member of the Palo Alto School Board. In 1916, he became the first president of the Union High School District. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Walter Hays Elementary School
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Walter Hays School is a Palo Alto elementary school located at the corner of Middlefield and Embarcadero. The older photo shows the school ground in 1926 and students posing in front of a nativity scene. A new school building was erected in the 1950s. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Warren Way
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory A toss of a coin resulted in the name of this street. Two developers William Reed and Kendall Bower were the property developers. Bower was a Democrat and Reed was a Republican. When Reed won the coin toss he named the street after Republican Governor Earl Warren. Source: PAHA\'s Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Waverley Street
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Waverley Street was named for Waverley, a successful novel by Sir Walter Scott, published anonymously in 1814.

properties.name: Waverley Street (1902)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Paving work is being done on Waverly Street using "Aeson", a high grade German cement. In the first photo, the tall man on the left is Richard Keatings. The young man with the wheelbarrow is his son Percy. (PAHA Archives)

properties.name: Waverley at Colorado
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Looking southeast during 1941 flooding.

properties.name: Waverley at Colorado (ca. 1941)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Looking southeast on Waverley during storm.

properties.name: Waverley at Embarcadero (ca. 1990)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Looking south on Waverley towards Embarcadero circa 1990. At far left the male figure in the "Foreign Friends" statue appears to be vandalized. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: We Are All in This Together
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  "Created by artist JOE SAM “We are all in this together” is located in Palo Alto at 33 Encina Ave." -Palo Alto Art commission

properties.name: Webster Street Parking Garage (1987)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  An odd place for a dinner party --- the parking garage between Cowper and Webster in November, 1987. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Webster at Tennyson (1930s)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Corner of Webster and Lowell. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Weisshaar Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "Along with Cameron, Werry, and Mayfield, Weisshaar is one of the four old Mayfield parks. Dating back to 1888, the mini parks, positioned symmetrically, were originally called Berkeley, Hollywood, Hampton, and Eton. In 1968 Hampton was renamed Weisshaar after Frederick W. Weisshaar who arrived in Mayfield in 1862. In 1870 Weisshaar and his friend Peter Spacher bought and farmed 120 acres until the late 1880s when they sold their land to Alexander Gordon who subdivided it into plots that would become College Terrace. Weisshaar was a longtime Mayfield school district trustee and was elected Mayfield’s first treasurer." Source: Palo Alto City Page

properties.name: Wells Fargo
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: 420 Cowper was the location of a branch of the Mid-Peninsula Bank at the time of this photo in 1985. In 2009, it is a Wells Fargo.

properties.name: Werry Park
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Tiny Werry Park is named after William Werry, former Palo Alto postmaster. He also served as the chairman of the ration board during WWII. Werry Park was also briefly home to the Foreign Friends statue before its demise.

properties.name: Wesley Church (1904-1959)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The church occupied these grounds between 1904-1959.

properties.name: Wesley United Methodist Church (1959-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Wesley Methodist was originally founded in old Mayfield (now South Palo Alto) to provide a counterforce to the town\'s many saloons. The church has been at this location since 1959. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Where JFK Stayed While at Stanford (1940)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In mid-September 1940, John F. Kennedy arrived in Palo Alto in his brand new, red-seated, cactus green Buick convertible and checked into the President Hotel on University Avenue. After getting a lay of the land, he rented the one-bedroom cottage behind the campus house of Miss Gertrude Gardiner at 624 Mayfield Road. For sixty bucks a month, it was a pretty good deal, plus he didn’t have to pay for a new bed because he took to sleeping on a plywood board at night to help his back. He would only spend a few months at the Stanford Business School before returning east to help his father.

properties.name: Whole Foods Market
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: This Whole Foods location is the former site of the Paddleford Garage. Photo #2: The Whole Foods salad bar in 1989. Photo #3: The older shot is from inside the garage in the 1940s. Photo #4: Workers build the garage in July of 1927. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Wideman's
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory Photo #1: H.C. Schmidt, proprietor of the Novelty Theatre at 185 University Avenue, stands in the aisle of the empty theater with his hat hanging on a wooden seat. Photo #2: For many years this was the location of Wideman\'s as seen in this photo at the far left. Photo #3: Wideman\'s circa 1920. Photo #4: Wideman\'s circa 1924. The sign indicates that the building is about to come down and that the store\'s temporary location is "at University and High." Photo #5: Wideman\'s before their move down the street. Circa 1940. Photo #6: Indeed, they were not put out of business. Photo #7: This was the originally the home of the Otter Building. The sign indicates that the building was about to be remodeled. Photo #8: In 2008 as the Lavanda Restaurant & Wine Bar. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Wideman's (1965-1994)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Wideman\'s was in this location from 1965-1994. The was located in Palo Alto since 1906. Photo #1: Mendenhall\'s Dry Goods in 1927. Photo #2, #3: Mendenhall\'s ca. 1910 Photo #4: J.F. Hink & Son, better known as Hinks. Photo #5: Atkins circa 1945. Photo #6: Hinks lit up at night. Photo #7: In 1958, we can see the corner is now the Roos-Atkins store. Photo 8:: In 2007, Restoration Hardware is now on the site.

properties.name: Wilde's Vans (ca. 1940)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  This photo shows Wilde\'s Vans across the alley from the old Palo Alto Hotel and the Union Stage Depot. A sign tells customers that they can "Move in Safety."

properties.name: Wilkie Way (1926-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Wilkie Way was named for Robert Max Wilke, owner of an apricot orchard on the corner of Charleston and Wilkie. The name has been misspelled on city maps since 1926.

properties.name: William Shockley's Boyhood Home
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory It is unlikely that any Palo Altan has ever lived a life as important as William Shockley. As a young man during World War II, he won the nation’s highest civilian honor for discoveries that saved thousands of lives. In 1956, he won the Nobel Prize in Physics for the invention of the transistor, a device that either made possible or greatly improved nearly every modern gadget we use today. He then moved west and started the company that became the catalyst for the rise of Silicon Valley. He was even named one of the 100 most important people of the 20th Century by Time Magazine in 1999. And yet despite this resume of accomplishment and his indisputable intelligence, William Shockley always seemed to find a way to allow his personality to spoil his own success. Throughout his 79 years, Shockley threw tantrums, fought petty disputes and turned his friends into enemies. He divorced his first wife, severed relations with his children and forced his brightest employees to leave his company and outshine him elsewhere. Finally, as an angry and bitter man in his retirement years, Shockley became the champion of an angry and bitter theory. His association with it would bring him scorn, ridicule and deep contempt from the scientific community and the broader public. In the end, his reputation in tatters and his accomplishments largely overshadowed, William Shockley would die friendless and ignored, his own worst enemy.

properties.name: World War II Bond Drive
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  A number of kids gather around the "War Bond Jeep" as Humphrey Bogart stars in "The Big Shot" at the Stanford Theatre.

properties.name: X Rated Copenhagen Theatre (1973)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In the mid 1970s the X-rated Copenhagen Theater was in this location. Later was home to the Santa Clara County Democratic Headquarters.

properties.name: Xerox Research Center (1970-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory "Founded in 1970 as a division of Xerox Corporation, PARC has been responsible for such well known and important developments as laser printing, the Ethernet, the modern personal computer graphical user interface (GUI), ubiquitous computing, and advancing very-large-scale-integration (VLSI). Incorporated as a wholly owned subsidiary of Xerox in 2002, PARC currently conducts research into biomedical technologies, "clean technology", user interface design, sensemaking, ubiquitous computing, large area electronics, and embedded and intelligent systems. Most of these developments were included in the Alto, which added the now familiar SRI-developed mouse unifying into a single model most aspects of now-standard personal computer use. The integration of Ethernet prompted the development of the PARC Universal Packet architecture, much like today\'s Internet." Source: Wikipedia Photo #1: King XVI Gustaf of Sweden views Xerox technology at the Xerox Research Center in Palo Alto in 1984. Photo #2: The Alto. Photo #2: Today the research center is known as PARC (Palo Alto Research Center). Photo #3: Bob Taylor and Alan Kay at PARC.

properties.name: YMCA Christmas Tree Lot (1950)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  As seen in this 1950 photograph, the YMCA set up their Christmas tree lot across the street from the old All Saint\'s Church on Hamilton Avenue. The Hotel President sign peeks out at far right. (PAHA Colllection)

properties.name: YMCA until 1960
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  The house that once stood at 637 Cowper was the home of the YMCA until 1960. (PAHA Collection)

properties.name: Yacht Harbor Clubhouse
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The Yacht clubhouse was once located next to the Sea Scout Building at the Palo Alto Yacht Harbor.

properties.name: Ynigo Way (1977-present)
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory  Ynigo Way commemorates Chief Lopes Ynigo, a Christianized Indian from Mission Santa Clara. The creek near the present street is Adobe Creek, but scribbled maps show earlier names including Ynigo. Source: Streets of Palo Alto

properties.name: Zibibbo
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory The intensity of the downtown shopping district in recent years seems to have sprouted down the sidestreets resulting in restaurants set up in old houses like Zibibbo.

properties.name: Zoo at the Junior Museum
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory In 1969, a small zoo featuring bats, snakes, and small animals was added to the Junior Museum. The black and white photo is from the 1980s (PAHA Collection).

properties.name: Zschokke House
properties.description: Posted by Paloaltohistory This is the former location of Anna Zschokke\'s house, the first built in Palo Alto. The photo was taken in the 1940s from across the street inside the Paddleford Garage (now a Whole Foods). The site of Zschokke\'s house is now a parking lot.
